HEADLINE: The Mood? In a Word, Anxiety 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Top U.S. Officials Press Case Linking Iraq to Al Qaeda" (front page, Feb. 12): 
 It is now 17 months since the attack on the World Trade Center. 
In that time, we have managed to beat a third-world country into submission and capture or kill relatively low-level Qaeda operatives.
Osama bin Laden and most of his lieutenants remain at large. Only one person accused of connection to the planning and execution of the 9/11 attacks has been captured.
We are now at a "high" level of terrorism alert and are being warned about likely biological or chemical attacks. 
And our government focuses on Iraq. 
Now, to continue the pressure on Iraq, we are being bombarded with daily "evidence" of the supposed link between Iraq and Al Qaeda. 
At what point will the American public realize that we are being led into a war that will only worsen terrorism -- one against a country that poses no imminent threat to the United States and, at worst, a weak, long-term one?
Yes, Saddam Hussein is evil. But let us focus our energies on the problems that we actually face: a very real Qaeda threat and an economy that is weak and for which the Bush administration has no credible plans. 

MICHAEL G. PARKER
New York, Feb. 12, 2003

HEADLINE: ON STAGE AND OFF 

BYLINE:  By Jesse McKinley 

 BODY:
Big Things Ahead For Lincoln Center
"The Coast of Utopia," Tom Stoppard's nine-hour, three-part epic of love and revolution in 19th-century Russia, is coming to the shores of Lincoln Center Theater along with a series of other ambitious projects, including a new/old Stephen Sondheim musical and a mysterious Martha Clarke piece.
 "Utopia" had its world premiere last fall at the Royal National Theater in London and is to arrive at the Vivian Beaumont Theater with a new director, Jack O'Brien, and a new designer, Bob Crowley, both of whom worked on Mr. Stoppard's "Invention of Love" on Broadway last season. One catch: it won't be here until the spring of 2005. 
 Before then, Mr. Stoppard is expected to be working on the plays, doing some cutting and addressing some issues raised by the London critics, including the play's sometimes lagging momentum. Another part of the long wait has to do with the sheer breadth of the project, which will require a cast of 30 adult actors and a small gaggle of children, with a budget that Andre Bishop, the theater's artistic director, estimates as "lots."
"I dread to think," Mr. Bishop said. "But the Beaumont was really built for these types of shows."
Well, not yet. The theater is undergoing a renovation that will keep it dark until the fall production of "Henry IV," Parts I and II, starring Kevin Kline, Richard Easton and Billy Crudup and directed by none other than Mr. O'Brien. That Shakespeare is to be followed by more Shakespeare and an attempt by one of the great actors of the day to put his stamp on one of the great parts of all time. Christopher Plummer is to play Lear, in a reprise of his performance last year at the Stratford Festival in Ontario. Mr. Plummer, 75, heads the cast from that production at the Beaumont, beginning next February.
Beyond that the schedule for summer 2004 is murkier, but two major projects are moving ahead. The first is "The Frogs," a reimagining of Mr. Sondheim's 1974 farce musical about Dionysos, the Greek god of partying and the theater, heading into Hades to dig up the greatest playwright of all time to resurrect the world theater scene.
The musical's book, by Burt Shevelove, riffing on the ancient text by Aristophanes, has been adapted by Nathan Lane, who is expected to star; Mr. Sondheim is writing new songs as well. Susan Stroman, who did a little show with Mr. Lane called "The Producers," will direct. Early indications, from a private reading last month, are very good. Schedules, however, are tight, and Mr. Lane's new television show, yet to be broadcast, might complicate things further.
The other possibility is an untitled project being cooked up in the basement rehearsal rooms at the theater by the choreographer Martha Clarke. It is based on the life and women of Toulouse-Lautrec and uses 19th-century music and a new text by Charles M. Mee. Beyond that, "I don't know what it all is yet," Mr. Bishop said, "but it seems wonderful to me." The best bet is probably "The Frogs," for a few reasons: 1) the subject matter that includes Shakespeare, which fits nicely with "Henry IV" and "King Lear"; 2) it seems further along; 3) it's by the "Producers" people and Mr. Sondheim. (Duh.)
Which, especially in times of economic trials and budgetary woes, could bring a welcome boost at the box office for a theater with big plans ahead. "It hasn't really affected us yet," Mr. Bishop said of the economic bad times. "But that doesn't mean it won't."

Off Broadway Closings
Two quirky and long-running Off Broadway shows will close in May, instantly putting dozens of flying acrobats and boisterous Italian-American actors out of work.
The first to go is "De La Guarda," which will shutter on May 4 after nearly five years at the Daryl Roth Theater on Union Square. The show, which was developed in Argentina and featured 15 sopping wet bungie cord aerialists, turned a nice profit but was eventually done in by rising operating costs.
Also saying ciao is a show that many people thought would never close, and one that does so only after becoming the second-longest-running show in Off Broadway history, topped only by the 42-year run of "The Fantastiks." It is "Tony and Tina's Wedding," the interactive comedy that opened in February 1988 outside, and later inside, a church on Christopher Street. It later moved to a church on West 46th Street, where it will walk down the aisle for a finaltime on May 18. Produced by Joe and Dan Corcoran, the show, with a cast of 32 actors portraying a gang of rowdy wedding guests, recouped its original investment in 10 months and has been in the black pretty much ever since.

Back to Bleecker Street
Without being too indelicate, Denny Doherty is the only Papa left. John Phillips, one of Mr. Doherty's band mates in the 1960's folk rock band the Mamas and the Papas, died in 2001. Mama Cass died in 1974. Only Mr. Doherty and Michelle Phillips, Mr. Phillips's ex-wife, survive.
But the stories about the band -- full of sex, drugs and folk rock 'n' roll -- are a whole other issue. "It was a soap opera, man," said the jovial Mr. Doherty. "It was 'All My Children' goes to 'General Hospital.' "
Starting March 14, those stories and songs will be recalled by Mr. Doherty and a six-member band in "California Dreamin,' " a musical described as a "multimedia production utilizing state-of-the-art projection technology." (Trippy.)
Written and narrated by Mr. Doherty, "Dreamin' " will play the Village Theater on Bleecker Street. "Forty years later I'm going to be back on the street I started on," Mr. Doherty said. "Talkin' to all those ghosts walking by."

Must Be in the Genes
Jared Harris, the son of the late British actor Richard Harris, will take the title role in the American premiere of "Humble Boy," opening at the Manhattan Theater Club in May.
The play, which was a hit at the National Theater in London and follows the story of a Hamletesque physicist dealing with mother issues, will also star Blair Brown, as said mother. John Caird will direct.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Denny Doherty, of the Mamas and the Papas fame. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Sega to Merge With a Mainstay of Japanese Arcades 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 13 

 BODY:
The Sega Corporation, the video game maker, said today that it would merge with Sammy, a leading manufacturer of pachinko machines. Pachinko, a vertical cousin of pinball, is played in arcades in Japan for prizes, much the way Americans may play slots or poker machines where they are legal. The terms of the merger have not yet been set.
 The deal, to take effect Oct. 1, ends years of speculation about the future direction of one of the oldest names in the game software industry. Sega, which also reduced its profit forecast for the current year by 90 percent, has struggled to compete with Sony, Nintendo and Microsoft, all of which make high-powered video game consoles as well as game software; Sega dropped out of the console-making business in 2001. 
 Microsoft has been looking for partners to make software for its X-Box console and was thought to be interested in an alliance with Sega.
By combining forces with Sammy, though, Sega hopes to concentrate on software for arcade games. Most pachinko machines now incorporate computer chips to determine scores and winnings for each game. The deal also gives Sammy a route to expand beyond the pachinko industry, once thought to be recession-proof, where total revenue has slipped by 10 percent since 1995.
Though Sega is better known internationally and has a market capitalization about 20 percent greater than Sammy's, Sega will take a back seat to Sammy in the combined company. Hajime Satomi, Sammy's president, will lead the combined company, which would have sales of about 371 billion yen ($3.1 billion) and 1,750 employees if it existed today.
The companies hope to "make full use of our synergies developing technology in the amusement and consumer arenas, and combining Sammy's rapid growth with Sega's brand name," Mr. Satomi said in a statement. Sammy's sales have tripled over the last three years, while Sega's have fallen 40 percent. 
Sega has posted losses for the last five years, and today sharply lowered its sights for the current year, which ends March 31. The company now expects a profit of just 500 million yen ($4.1 million) -- it had previously forecast earning 10 times that. It also trimmed its sales forecast by 2.5 percent.
Sega was an early pioneer in the home video industry, but it ran into trouble in the mid-1990's after Sony introduced its PlayStation console.
Sony built on the success of the PlayStation 2, selling 50 million of them so far, and Nintendo did well with its GameBoy and GameCube. In response, Sega spent heavily to develop and produce the DreamCast console and to expand its amusement operations. But the DreamCast did not take off the way PlayStation did, and the company found itself saddled with nearly $3 billion in debt. It started selling or discarding operations to cut losses and raise cash, including shutting down DreamCast production in 2001. 
Sega managed to cut its debts, but sales plunged, and DreamCast owners were left without any new games for their consoles. Sega still produces popular game software like the Sonic the Hedgehog line, but it must now compete head-on with stronger players like Konami and Square.
"Once they abandoned their game platform, they became a video game producer like everyone else," said Ortwin Gierhake, an analyst at West LB Securities in Tokyo. "They are getting killed by Sony and Nintendo."
Two of Sega's rivals also made headlines today. Square, which is 19 percent owned by Sony, said shareholders had accepted a takeover bid from Enix, another game maker. And the largest of Japan's game publishers, Konami, reported 8.1 billion yen ($67 million) in profit for the quarter ended Dec. 31, largely because of strong sales of Yu-Gi-Oh game cards in the United States.

HEADLINE: MY BROOKLYN; 
Racing Upscale At Full Throttle

BYLINE:  By DAVID KIRBY 

 BODY:
I don't remember exactly when I realized that my neighborhood had arrived, but I think it was sometime between the opening of the Japanese tapas bar and the European-style pressed sandwich cafe, a few doors down.
 In Park Slope, Brooklyn, Fifth Avenue has long been the poorer, grittier cousin to Seventh Avenue, the area's main dining and shopping street, which has bustled and thrived for years. Thrive, however, is not a word that's been widely associated with Fifth Avenue, at least until now. 
 I moved to the neighborhood just over three years ago, having traded a cramped Chelsea studio for a spacious flat in a gracious brownstone, complete with lush private garden and, incredibly, my own pear tree. 
At that time (it seems like ancient history now), Fifth Avenue was a rather dingy and sorry affair. Save for a couple of decent watering holes and a few old-neighborhood Italian restaurants that made the area livable, the strip was mostly a string of forlorn storefronts lurking behind shuttered metal gates, some covered in graffiti dating back to the Lindsay administration. 
Still, the place had a kick, a punch and a spirit that instinctively drew me to it. 
Having lived in Latin America for years, I loved the avenue's decidedly Hispanic flavor, from the Mexican greengrocer to the Dominican bodegas and botanicas to the pale pink facade of the Iglesia Pentecostal de Jesus Cristo Inc., whose worshipers' voices fill the air on Sunday afternoons with choruses of "Aleluya!" that rise above the twanging electric guitars and shaking tambourines of what could be described as Latin gospel.
All of those places, and much of the ethnic flavor of the avenue, remain intact. But economic pressures being what they are, and with housing prices heading ever skyward despite hard times, change was inevitable, I suppose, and gentrification was just a mocha latte away.
What astonished me, though, was the lightning speed of the transformation. The upscale home accessory boutiques, the designer jewelry stores, the high-end beer emporium, the pretty French restaurants -- they all appeared almost overnight. In 20 years of living in New York, I had never seen any place gentrify quite so quickly.
For the most part, the long-anticipated renovation of this stretch of Fifth Avenue has not brought about an unrecognizable alteration of the neighborhood, even though at least 25 new businesses have opened their doors between Sterling Place and Seventh Street in the last year. There's been no instant importation of corporate cookie chains, no fast-food franchises. 
There isn't even a Starbucks. That, as they say, is so Seventh Avenue. 
Instead, I would guess that 90 percent of the shops, bars and cafes along Fifth are owned and operated by people who live right in Park Slope. Apparently, like England, this is a small nation of shopkeepers. When you walk through the door, their smiles are genuine because they really are happy to see you.
"There's been extraordinary change, and it's been a huge challenge for us," said Brad Lander, executive director of the 26-year-old Fifth Avenue Committee, whose "Displacement-Free Zone" program is meant to help working-class people stay in the neighborhood. "Much of this area was abandoned to widespread blight and drug dealing." 
So all these new businesses are definite improvements, right?
Yes, Mr. Lander agreed, but only for those who can still afford to live here. "Back then, they certainly didn't have any of the stores catering to yuppies," he said. "Now, you can't swing a cat without hitting one."
I've never seen anyone swing a cat around here, but I have noticed a lot of new, young, mostly white faces appearing in my neighborhood, which still mixes a healthy down-home cocktail of races, religions and, with its sizable gay and lesbian population, sexual orientations. Many peopleare cool here, but nobody is fabulous.

Out on the Avenue
On weekends, the avenue comes alive with activity. It's an odd mix of local homeboys hanging on corners, young couples strolling with fresh-scrubbed toddlers, singles out to carouse, and enterprising chowhounds emerging from the Manhattan subway, here to sample some of the fledgling fare and nascent night life that's popping up along my little stretch of the avenue.
This weekend, love-struck Valentine couples out for a romantic evening will find many suitable spots for mutual eye-gazing and cocktail-glass clinking. The brand-new Gowanus Lounge is a good place to start, with its airy, modern corner bar up front and lounge that's like an opium den in the rear. With plush banquettes and muted lighting, it is quite elegant, for Park Slope.
Loki is another softly lighted spot with a great sound system, pool table and turn-of-the-century appointments. It attracts a stylish young crowd. Other fine places to bend some elbows with the locals include the Gate, with a rotating list chosen from 40 beers, mostly from Europe, and a very friendly pet policy; Bar Reis, with a downstairs lounge, backyard and karaoke night; Great Lakes, which has live rock music Sundays and Mondays; Ginger's, which is more lesbian than gay; and Excelsior, more gay than lesbian.
Park Slope even has its own bona fide, Manhattan-style rock club and dimly lighted, very spacious and comfortable cocktail lounge, known as Southpaw, which opened this fall. Recent acts have included Mooney Suzuki and the Black Kings.
For great coffee and tea, nothing around here beats Ozzie's, the anti-Starbucks. A neighborhood institution since 1999, it has poetry readings, book clubs, political discussion groups and other offerings to a predominantly left-of-center community.

A New Restaurant Row
One of the newest and most exciting culinary arrivals is surely Nana, opened on Dec. 26 by Eric Ong. Its mango- and lime-green-colored tiles behind the open kitchen provide a striking setting for the triumvirate of Thai, Malaysian and Japanese cuisines (with a separate chef for each) on the innovative and reasonably priced menu. The salmon tartare, with spicy pine nut garlic sauce and a raw quail egg on top, is, like Paris, something that's not to be missed before you die.
Nana will compete somewhat with Long Tan, a local favorite Pan-Asian bar and grill. Opened in the summer of 2001, it's one of the oldest newcomers on the street. Long Tan is terrific for its lively bar and live D.J. on Friday and Saturday nights, late-night dinners of delicious affordable food, a hip-but-not-trendy ambience and the best mojitos this side of Havana. It might seem odd that an Asian restaurant would serve Caribbean cocktails. But when you consider that the founders, Rory Dwyer and Jamie Webb, are from Ireland and Australia, respectively (yes, they have kangaroo on the menu), it all starts to make sense. (Mr. Dwyer bought out Mr. Webb two weeks ago.)
Across the street is Tamari, the Japanese tapas and sake bar. It was opened last May by Ken Kikuchi, who immigrated to Bedford-Stuyvesant from Yokohama via, of all places, Madrid (hence the combination). Japanese tapas, here at least, are small, reasonably priced treasures served in a tranquil, clean, cozy environment. In addition to 25 sakes, Tamari always has great specials. A recent example: sardine tempura with apple-mango salad and Indian spices.
Cocotte, which opened in September under the loving stewardship of Christine and William Snell, who live in Park Slope, is my favorite restaurant on the avenue.
Ms. Snell, who is from Brittany, calls the menu "French coastal comfort food," which means lots of shellfish and cream, with yummy accouterments like leeks, lardons and potatoes. Diet food it is not, but it is warm, wonderful and delicious. Besides, the romantic wood-paneled room will make you forget about calories.
The street has three Italian restaurants in a cluster. There is the venerable and pricey Cucina, with its authentic Tuscan cuisine, elegant minimalist decor and doting service. It's been around since the Middle Ages, otherwise known as 1988. Nearby is Al di La, a tin-ceilinged corner trattoria opened in November 1998 by Anna Klinger and her husband, Emiliano Coppa, who live nearby. They serve tasty home-cooked Venetian fare in a lively atmosphere. Across the street is a beloved old war horse, Aunt Suzie's, which has been cooking up vast pots of tangy marinara and southern-Italian-style pasta since 1987.
Another Italian place, Trattoria Mulino, just opened in October. Luis Mulina, one of the owners, came to New York from Ecuador in 1986 and worked his way up from dishwasher through a number of Italian restaurants in the city. He is also a co-owner of Los Pollitos across the street, which has delicious fresh tacos and roast chicken to go or to eat in.
Chip Shop and Curry Shop are at Sixth Street. (The two are connected inside.) Chip Shop fries up crisp, battered cod and haddock, bakes a mean steak-and-onion pie and actually makes Yorkshire pudding. Try it with beef and Old Speckled Hen stew (named for a British ale). The owners, Christopher and Victoria Sell (he is from Rugby, England), live around the corner. Walk into Curry Shop, with its pungent, enticing smells, and you're transported straight to London. "I wanted to go against the notion that English food was awful," Mr. Sell said. He's succeeding.
The food doesn't stop there. Beso has nouvelle Latin American food; 200 Fifth is great for burgers, pasta and bar fare, and it has a new music and sports television club next door, with live salsa and jazz. Sweet Mama's Griddle just opened as part of the Rising Cafe, for delicious Southern food accompanied by live folk, jazz and bluegrass; Bonnie's Grill griddles American home cooking in a cozy setting.
Blue Ribbon, part of a Manhattan chain, packs them in for outstandingly fresh oysters and eclectic dining in a fraternal atmosphere; Blue Ribbon Sushi just opened next door. Press 195 presses European-style hot sandwiches using freshly roasted meats and Hudson Valley foodstuffs, topped by a good wine list. Coco Roco, an old standby, still makes colorful, tangy Peruvian food in a lively and decidedly South American atmosphere.
I left town for less than two weeks in January, and by the time I got back, there was another new arrival: Moutarde, a surprisingly reasonable old-style French bistro that prides itself on a selection of flavored mustards.

Our Own Fifth Avenue
For weekend window shopping, or maybe for a little last-minute Valentine's indulgence, I can't think of a better Brooklyn thoroughfare than Fifth. And what better place to start than Diana Kane, a store that opened in August, selling only jewelry and lingerie?
The boutique is owned by Diana English (Kane is her maiden name), a jewelry designer who keeps a studio in the back while opening the front to sell her own intricate earrings, necklaces and bracelets, made from sterling silver and high-quality crystal. So what's with the high-end lingerie? "I couldn't find any nice underwear out here," said Ms. English, who lives nearby.
Otherplaces for clothes and accessories include Eidolon, a cooperative boutique owned by three designers. "It's very much a labor of love around here," said Andrea Fisher, who designs and sells blouses and dresses. Amara Felice makes wallets, clutches and crocheted hats, while Yukie Ohta turns out Ultrasuede handbags.
There's also the brand-new Serene Rose, a lovely, homey place painted pale yellow and owned by Hermian Charles and Gilbert Midonnet, who are husband and wife. It features locally designed clothing and accessories, as well as artwork ("as local as possible," Mr. Midonnet said). Albert & Piccolo combines clothing with collectibles and local artwork.
For custom-designed women's fashions and gifts, there's Kimera (selling in-stock and made-to-order items). For vintage clothing, accessories and collectibles, you can try Bopkat, Beacon's Closet, Reverse Vintage (also a bookstore) or Somethin' Else, run by Suzanne Tully, whose husband, Anthony Roman, operates the record section downstairs.
"It's stuff that needs to be out there but isn't available in bigger record stores," Mr. Roman said. "We didn't want a Seventh Avenue-style store. Fifth is more our speed, and this is more our kind of store. We like it a little grittier and edgier."
Children's clothing and toys can be found at the new Bumblez; Lulu's Cuts and Toys, which is also a children's hair salon; and at the very cute Go Fish. 
For gifts and housewares, the number of tiny outlets selling highly eclectic, artistic items not found in other stores seems to increase by the week. One of the newest is Extraordinary, which manages to live up to its name. It's a narrow, modern-looking shop with shelves laden with housewares, all unusual and handmade, with a decidedly Asian flair. 
Su Casa, a delightfully outfitted home shop owned by Amanda Nelson, a Park Slope native, carries linens, bathroom accessories, towels, shower curtains, rugs, mirrors and skin products.
Cog & Pearl sells so many different things, it's hard to pin down what kind of store it is. "We have highly unusual items," said Kristin Overson, a co-owner, in the understatement of the avenue. The cards, gifts, jewelry and other wares are all beautiful, and "as local as we could find them," she said.
Across the street is Patrias, owned by Paulina Perez Bemporad, whose family is from Colombia. The store, a small, sparkling jewel box filled with sequins and colored tin, carries handmade folk art from Mexico, Guatemala, Peru, Haiti, El Salvador and, of course, Colombia. Right next door is Brooklyn Frameworks, which specializes in old images from around the borough, as well as many nice prints and lithographs.
Other great cards and gifts can be found at Bob & Judi's Coolectibles, one of my favorite places in Brooklyn; Nancy Nancy, with amusing tchotchkes like sequined tiaras and space-alien salt shakers; and Scaredy Kat, which also has gifts for babies.
And barely two weeks ago, on Feb. 1, Donna Regii moved her Slang Betty clothing and accessories boutique down here after six years just off Seventh Avenue. 

Fresh Provisions at Hand
If you want to grab a little something to nibble or sip to take home to your sweetheart, who is probably wisely staying warm by the fire, there are any number of gourmet stores.
For wine, Darrin Siegfried, a helpful connoisseur, stocks his Red White & Bubbly with a wide selection of worldwide vintages.
Pollio (established 1930) and A. S. Pork Store are throwbacks to the time when this neighborhood was settled by Italian immigrant families. Panorama Fine Foods, owned by Pat Ciesla and Sammy Boudina, is small but very European in its outlook and quality. The Fifth Avenue Bageltique Cafe has been there seemingly forever.
Finally, last year Daphne and Richard Scholz opened Bierkraft, where they offer one of the biggest and finest selections of top-end food and beer in the borough. They like to buy from small producers and also offer exquisite oils, breads and fresh and deli meats. With the store's more than 600 kinds of beer and 200 types of cheese, the discerning palates of Park Slope will not go unsatisfied. Also, the owners are my next-door neighbors.

Curry and Karaoke, but No Starbucks

Restaurants, clubs and shops on Fifth Avenue in Park Slope in the article on Brooklyn.

Restaurants

HEADLINE: South Korea Has Big Plans For the Area Around Seoul 

BYLINE:  By DON KIRK 

DATELINE: INCHON, South Korea, Feb. 11 

 BODY:
The sprawling urban region around South Korea's capital is determined to plunge ahead with ambitious plans to make itself a business hub for the Pacific Rim -- never mind that the tense and heavily militarized border with North Korea is just a long-range artillery shot away.
 "Seoul can become the financial center of Northeast Asia," said Lee Myung Bak, the former chairman of a construction company who was elected mayor of Seoul last year. "That means more than making policies and preparing tasks. We have to compete with China and Hong Kong." 
Along with the mayor of the port of Inchon, 30 miles from Seoul, and the governor of Kyonggi Province, Mr. Lee laid out a vision of glory for a gathering of foreign officials and business executives at the new Inchon International Airport last week, seemingly oblivious to the mounting international tensions over North Korea's nuclear weapons program and the possibility of military conflict between the North and the United States.
Even South Korea's president-elect, Roh Moo Hyun, stuck to much the same script, making only a brief allusion to the situation at the end of the meeting when he said with a smile, "At any rate, I am going to prevent war on this peninsula."
Some foreigners have trouble feeling so sanguine. Moody's Investors Service, the credit rating agency, switched its long-term outlook for South Korea from positive to negative this week. 
Thomas Byrne, Moody's vice president for sovereign risk, said South Korea was still creditworthy, with an A3 rating, but that the uncertainties of the political situation were offsetting the progress the country had made recovering from the financial crisis of 1997. "The outlook change was the sharpest we could make," he said.
As for the dreams of turning Seoul and Inchon into an international hub to rival Hong Kong or Singapore, Mr. Byrne said the plans were "not totally unrealistic, but you need a system with low political risk -- you have to have a resolution of the North Korean crisis."
Other Western analysts echoed that view. "The nuclear standoff with North Korea is costing South Korea plenty," said David Roddy, who edits a newsletter on South Korean finance. He said that at least $56 billion in market capitalization had been erased from Korean companies since early December as stock prices have fallen. "If the nuclear crisis continues," Mr. Roddy said, "it could sabotage some of the significant gains that the Korean economy has made." 
Such concerns do not feature in the excited discussions about the plan among local South Korean leaders, who tend to brush the confrontation with the North aside as a transitory problem. Neither is much said about gathering signs that the economy is slowing down, like the recent Bank of Korea survey that found business confidence at a two-year low.
For Mr. Roh, turning the Seoul-Inchon metropolis into a regional center is as high on his agenda as restructuring the economy or, for that matter, dealing with North Korea. Speaking at the airport gathering, he warned officials of the government he would soon lead that he wants action on the plan. "If they don't do something, there will be trouble," he said. "I will make sure all the ministries will have positive thoughts."
If the promoters of the idea seemed to be whistling past a nuclear graveyard, South Korea's economy has confounded skeptics before, rising rapidly from the ashes of the Korean War, developing companies like Hyundai Motor and Samsung Electronics that can compete globally, springing back from the abyss of the 1997-98 financial meltdown and making much quicker progress in dealing with a huge overhang of bad debts in its banking system than Japan.
"We have great potential," Mr. Roh told foreign executives here. "We have made everything possible. We have readied ourself for the new era, so please don't worry about investing in Korea."
In their presentation, the mayors and the governor noted that the Seoul-Inchon metropolis is home to 24 million people, half the country's population, and that it is situated between Japan and China, the Russian Far East and Taiwan. To capitalize, the planners want to expand the new airport, build a huge new seaport, and reclaim mud flats to provide new sites for commercial development.
"Seoul and Inchon as a metropolitan city will be a beachhead for international companies to make their way into China and Northeast Asia," said Ahn Sang Soo, the mayor of Inchon. Though China is emerging as a rival as well as a customer for South Korea, said Song Hak Kyu, the governor of Kyonggi Province, "we are looking forward to infinite competition." 
Lee Soo Young, chairman of the Inchon Chamber of Commerce, said Seoul's great opportunity was to become the Hong Kong for northern China. "In order to win in Northeast Asia, we have to recognize that China is becoming the manufacturing center of the world," he said. By expanding the port and completing a rail link between South and North Korea, he said, the country could become the shipment point for Chinese goods bound for the rest of the region, and perhaps, by way of the Trans-Siberian Railway, even Europe.

GRAPHIC: Photo: South Korea's president-elect, Roh Moo Hyun, right, laid out ambitious plans before foreign officials and business executives gathered in Inchon last week. Little concern was expressed over North Korea. (Bloomberg News)

HEADLINE: More Children In New York Are Homeless, Report Finds 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
The number of homeless children in New York City has increased sharply over the last decade. Even with the boom economy of the late 1990's, the percentage of children living in poverty rose, and more than half a million children in the city are now impoverished.
 But the lives of children in the city have improved in a few areas where the government has invested money and resources: the infant mortality rate has fallen, teenage pregnancy has dropped, and fewer children have been placed in foster care now that the city works harder to keep families together. 
 Those are some of the findings of "Keeping Track of New York City's Children," a 291-page compendium of facts and figures that was released yesterday by the Citizens' Committee for Children of New York, a nonprofit group.
The report offers an encyclopedic look at the city's nearly two million children and pays special attention to the wide disparities among children based on their race, ethnicity and where they live. Although the report is updated every two years, elected officials and advocates said that the one issued yesterday should be seen as a plea for more resources at a time when both the city and the state are cutting services to balance their budgets.
The report notes that African-Americans have higher infant mortality rates than any other racial group: 11.1 deaths per 1,000 births. Nearly 9 percent of African-American mothers receive inadequate or no prenatal care. Nearly 40 percent of Hispanic children are now born into families living below the poverty level, more than half of all teenage mothers are Hispanic, and more than a quarter of all Hispanic students drop out of high school.
Nearly a quarter of Asian children are born below the poverty level. 
Gail B. Nayowith, the executive director of the Citizens' Committee for Children, said the report showed what government could do when it applied itself to specific problems.
She pointed to two areas: the infant mortality rate, which fell 42 percent in the 1990's, and the percentage of teenage mothers, which dropped 15 percent. "This shows that targeted investments can improve the well-being of children," she said. But she also said the report showed how much need remains, especially with rising unemployment and a dearth of low-income housing. 
The release of the report came as many social service providers are gearing up for what promises to be a nasty budget fight in the coming months. Although Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's preliminary budget plan for the next fiscal year seeks to preserve many services, it relies on more than $2 billion in help from the state that may not materialize. 
If it does not, severe cuts will have to be considered, officials agree. 
Speaker Gifford Miller of the City Council presided over the City Hall news conference at which the report was released, and called for restoring money that would be cut from state aid to city schools. Councilwoman Margarita Lopez of Manhattan said that some of the figures in the report made her want to cry. And Councilman Bill de Blasio of Brooklyn said that the report showed that the city should restore planned cuts to preventive services.

HEADLINE: Despite Quarter Loss, A.I.G. Chief Sees Big Profits This Year 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
Maurice R. Greenberg, the long-time chief executive of the American International Group, shrugged off a fourth-quarter loss yesterday brought on by a huge one-time increase in reserves and said his company was well on its way to big profits this year.
 Mr. Greenberg said that with prices soaring, premiums in A.I.G.'s biggest commercial property unit jumped 50 percent in January. After expenses, he said, the company's property casualty businesses netted $1 billion in cash in the first month, almost as much as in the entire first quarter last year. 
 "We're off to a tremendous start," Mr. Greenberg told analysts and investors in a conference call. "We do not see any letup yet in the pricing environment. We believe it will continue for some time."
The company's stock jumped more than 3 percent yesterday, to $47.97. It is still down drastically from its high of about $100 two years ago, but has recovered somewhat from a sharp decline last week in reaction to the announcement of a $3.5 billion increase in reserves for unexpected liability claims.
Analysts said they expected the stock to continue to suffer along with the markets and the economy, but they said that once the economy began to recover it was likely to do well.
"Their capitalization is extremely strong and they are able to take advantage of opportunities that others can't," said Ira L. Zuckerman, an analyst at Nutmeg Securities in Fairfield, Conn. "A.I.G. is also poised to take advantage of the troubles that a lot of big European insurers are having."
In a move that analysts said contributed to the jump in the stock price, Mr. Greenberg veered from his usual refusal to project results for the coming year and said he expected the company to earn $3.78 to $3.92 a share in 2003, higher than analysts' consensus of $3.75. But Alice Schroeder, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, noted in a report to investors that the estimate was based on the important caveats that there would be no major political or economic shocks and no more than the usual run of natural catastrophes.
"These are caveats that could swing the dial significantly," she said.
The company reported a loss of $103.8 million for the fourth quarter of 2002 as a result of a net charge of $1.8 billion for increased reserves -- after taxes and reimbursements by other insurers known as reinsurers. That compares with profit of $1.87 billion for the 2001 quarter.
Even with the losing quarter, however, A.I.G. managed to earn $5.5 billion for the year, up 2.9 percent from 2001. "When you look at all the charges, we earned more money than any other financial-insurance company in the world, with the exception of Citigroup, and they're no longer in the insurance business," Mr. Greenberg said.
In a far-ranging discussion for over an hour with the analysts and investors, Mr. Greenberg said "an epidemic of lawsuits" led to the big increase in reserves for coverage sold from 1997 to 2001 and he said A.I.G. and other insurers were mounting a major campaign for changes in the legal system. "Most members of Congress recognize that change has to take place," he said. "It's inevitable. Not just at the federal level, but a lot is going on at the state level."
Mr. Greenberg led the successful effort to get the government to pay most of the costs in a major terrorist attack. That legislation required all commercial insurers to begin offering terrorism coverage. But such coverage remains extremely expensive, and Mr. Greenberg said few customers were buying it. 
"The only ones taking it up," he said, are owners of "high-profile properties." Examples, he said, were stadiums, big office buildings and any prominent structure that might be regarded as "a trophy building."
Mr. Greenberg has been predicting a short, swift war with Iraq. "Once the war is over," he said, "I think the economy will benefit psychologically."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Down Again, but Deep Early Losses Are Trimmed

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks fell for the third consecutive session yesterday, as Wall Street's anxiety over war and terrorism deepened with the arrests of three people at airports in Britain. 
 Late-day bargain hunting lifted the Dow Jones industrial average from a deficit of 129 points. But the major indexes still finished with losses, an expected outcome amid the selling that has dominated Wall Street for weeks. 
 "War worries continue to be the overwhelming deterrent for investors," said Alan Ackerman, executive vice president at Fahnestock & Company. 
The Dow closed down 8.30 points, or 0.1 percent, at 7,749.87. The blue chips dropped 161.94 in the previous two days. Yesterday's decline was the seventh in eight sessions. 
The broader market fell but also managed to stave off bigger losses. The Nasdaq composite index slipped 1.53 points, or 0.1 percent, to 1,277.44, recovering from an earlier deficit of 17.18 points. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 1.31 points, or 0.2 percent, to 817.37, having lost as much as 12.39 earlier. 
"There is still absolutely no reason to put money to work, to buy something," said Tony Cecin, head of institutional trading at US Bancorp Piper Jaffray in Minneapolis. "It is what I would call a buyers' strike."
War jitters have been the driving force behind the market's slide in 2003, costing the Dow nearly 1,100 points since Jan. 14, when the blue chips stood at 8,842.62, their high for 2003. 
So far this year, the Dow and the S.& P. 500 have each dropped 7.1 percent, while the Nasdaq has lost 4.4 percent. 
Fears of more terrorism have also been weighing on investors. Yesterday's losses widened as the police in Britain arrested a man at Gatwick Airport, near London, with a grenade in his luggage, and two other suspects were taken into custody near Heathrow Airport, outside London, where troops have been on patrol after a terrorist threat. 
On the economic front, the Commerce Department reported that retail sales fell by 0.9 percent in January, a larger drop than the 0.6 percent decline analysts had anticipated. The market has been particularly sensitive to news about consumers, whose spending accounts for two-thirds of the economy. 
But excluding automobile sales, which can vary widely from month to month, retail sales rose by 1.3 percent, stronger than the 0.5 percent increase that economists had been expecting. 
Still, investors are afraid that a possible war with Iraq might prompt consumers to further curtail their spending. 
Retailing and auto stocks traded lower yesterday. Pacific Sunwear dropped 34 cents, to $17.08; the Gap fell 50 cents, to $14.68; and Limited declined 20 cents, to $11.30. UBS Warburg downgraded the retailers to neutral from buy.
General Motors fell 37 cents, to $33.65, and Ford declined 31 cents, to $8.44.
Among the gainers, Hasbro, the toymaker, increased 51 cents, to $11.80, on fourth-quarter earnings that beat expectations by 4 cents a share. 
Dell Computer rose 31 cents, to $23.25, ahead of quarterly earnings. After the market closed, the company reported profits that met Wall Street's expectations, and its shares rose in after-hours trading.
In the bond market yesterday, the 10-year Treasury note rose 15/32, to 99 31/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, dropped to 3.88 percent from 3.96 percent on Wednesday. 
The 30-year bond rose 19/32, to 108 21/32. Its yield fell to 4.81 percent from 4.85 percent.

HEADLINE: Weak Response on Global Warming 

 BODY:
In a transparent bit of salesmanship that should not be mistaken for a serious policy, the Bush administration announced Wednesday that it had persuaded several major industries to make voluntary reductions in the rate at which they produce carbon dioxide and other gases that contribute to global warming. It was the administration's latest effort to show that voluntary controls will make unnecessary the mandatory reductions called for by many scientists, environmentalists and members of Congress -- as well as by the 1997 Kyoto Protocol that Mr. Bush rejected after taking office. 
 There are two main problems with the Bush policy. First, he is asking almost nothing in the way of real sacrifice. A serious approach would request net reductions in emissions. Mr. Bush asks only for a decrease in what he calls "carbon intensity," under which emissions can grow as long as they increase more slowly than the economy itself. That of course misses the point. The atmospheric buildup of carbon, already alarmingly high, is cumulative. Thus the name of the game is to start reducing emissions, not merely to slow their rate of growth. Indeed, by Mr. Bush's own calculations, his program would translate into an actual increase in emissions of 14 percent over the next 10 years. 
 Second, voluntarism won't do the job. The only strategy that makes economic and environmental sense, as the successful acid rain program has shown, is one that sets mandatory national limits on emissions and asks everyone to do his part. For one thing, companies are unlikely to spend millions of dollars on pollution control equipment if their competitors aren't doing likewise. For another, emissions trading -- which is seen as a way to reduce the overall costs -- will not work properly without a nationwide cap.
For all these reasons, an increasing number of legislators, most recently Senators John McCain and Joseph Lieberman, are lining up behind the idea of mandatory reductions as the only effective answer to warming. They would like nothing better than to see Mr. Bush at the head of this parade, but so far he shows no inclination even to join it.

HEADLINE: Trade Center Would Keep Retail Space Underground 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Plans for an underground concourse at the World Trade Center would allow for the building of several hundred thousand square feet of retail space below ground, or nearly as much as existed at the site before the 2001 attack, officials from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday.
 Testifying at a City Council hearing, the officials said that no decisions had been made yet about how the retail space at the trade center would be divided between above and below ground. 
 But in raising the possibility that a large amount of the site's retail stores might be located underground, along the passageways connecting the PATH commuter line, various subway lines and the World Financial Center, the Port Authority brought to light a looming conflict with city officials and many downtown residents.
The authority officials also said that their preliminary designs for the transportation hub at the trade center site, including the underground concourses, would work with either of the two designs being considered as finalists -- if the architects made several proposed modifications to allow for underground parking, transit stations and other structures at the site. 
The Port Authority also discussed its plans last night with an advisory council of family members of victims. Several family members objected to the proposal to put a bus parking lot beneath the planned memorial, saying it would be a security risk. Since the trade center was destroyed, downtown residents and civic groups have said retail space at and around the site should be built at ground level. Doing so, they have said, would reinvigorate street life downtown, something that an indoor mall would not do.
Westfield America, a shopping-mall company that, as a partner of Silverstein Properties, holds the rights to lease retail space at the trade center, favors enclosed retail space, much like that in the former concourse at the site.
Anthony G. Cracchiolo, the Port Authority's director of priority capital programs, told a joint meeting of the City Council's Transportation and Lower Manhattan Redevelopment Committees, "We're looking at options both above and below grade.
"We believe the retail development could occur both as part of the transportation facilities, as it occurs in Grand Central Station, for example, and above grade, integrating with the street life," Mr. Cracchiolo said.
But he also noted that thanks to moving walkways, the system of concourses that would stretch nearly half a mile from the World Financial Center to the Fulton Transit Center would enable commuters to shave 10 minutes off the walk from the No. 4 and No. 5 subways to the American Express building.
Robert Davidson, the Port Authority's chief architect, said the plans for underground retail space were not intended to conflict with street life, but rather to enhance it.
"All we're doing is offering up a viable alternative on those days where if you can help it you don't want to be out there" on the street, usually because of bad weather," Mr. Davidson said. "That is not to say this is the only way to do it. This is about choices, and it all depends on how we integrate what is happening at the street level with how you move from that street zone down into the transportation."
The two teams of architects whose plans are finalists for the design of the trade center site planned for hundreds of thousands of square feet of retail space underground. The Think plan would place three-quarters of its 1.1 million square feet of shops there, and the Studio Daniel Libeskind proposal would create 900,000 square feet of retail space, almost two-thirds of it underground. 
That disappointed city officials. Daniel L. Doctoroff, the deputy mayor for economic development and rebuilding, said yesterday that while the city did not have a specific preference for the amount of retail space in one location or the other, "Our top priority is to restore the vitality to the streets that surround the World Trade center site."
Restoring that vitality will depend on the efforts by the city and the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation to remake the character of Fulton Street and Broadway, he said. "In general, our preference is to have as little retail underground as makes sense," Mr. Doctoroff said.

HEADLINE: Auto Sales Off Markedly; Other Retail Sales Rise 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 

 BODY:
Retail sales for January fell 0.9 percent, the Commerce Department said today, pulled down by a sharp drop in demand for cars as automakers cut back on financial incentives.
 But sales outside the auto industry posted the biggest rise in more than two years. Excluding motor vehicles and parts, sales increased 1.3 percent, far ahead of forecasts of a 0.5 percent rise. 
 In a separate report, the Labor Department said that the number of Americans seeking jobless benefits for the first time dropped last week, a small ray of hope in a gloomy labor market. Initial claims fell by 18,000, to a seasonally adjusted 377,000, in the week ended Feb. 8. Wall Street economists had expected claims to dip to 389,000.
But the four-week moving average of claims, which smooths out weekly fluctuations, rose 3,500, to 389,000.
Analysts take some solace from seeing the four-week average hold below 400,000 for several weeks. Some economists view claims above that level as a sign of a deteriorating job market.
In the retail sales report, the Commerce Department said car sales dropped 7.5 percent in January, the largest decline since November 2001, but consumers otherwise spent money on a wide variety of goods.
Sales at building material and gardening equipment stores climbed 2.9 percent. There was also solid demand at food and beverage stores, and at health and personal care outlets. Sales at clothing and accessories stores rose a modest 0.3 percent.
"American consumers are holding up not only the U.S. economy but the global economy as well," said Bill Cheney of John Hancock Financial Services. "Their spending will remain crucial because the conflict with Iraq and the broader geopolitical uncertainties are keeping businesses on the sideline."
And Carey Leahey, senior United States economist at Deutsche Bank Securities, said, "The labor market is moving sideways, but this gives you some hope that there is some firming up in the labor market data, which could make us feel a little better about the recovery." 
The Labor Department said import prices increased sharply in January, largely from a 12.4 percent rise in oil prices. The risk of an Iraq war and the strike in Venezuela have driven oil prices up more than 30 percent since the end of November.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: A DANGER TO COMMERCE; 
Old Trading Partners Are Concerned About Effects of the Split Over War

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Feb. 13 

 BODY:
To celebrate its 100th anniversary, the American Chamber of Commerce in Germany gathered 1,000 business people last Tuesday at a Baroque palace on the banks of Rhine River in Wiesbaden near here for Champagne, canapes, and a rousing speech about German-American friendship, delivered by a local conservative leader, Roland Koch. 
 The talk in the crowd, however, was about the bitter rift between Berlin and Washington -- a political feud that many business people fear could sunder the countries' close commercial links. 
 "Germans initially found the dispute amusing," said Fred B. Irwin, the chairman of the chamber and an executive at Citibank in Frankfurt. "But this is no longer amusing. This has become extremely serious." 
Republican members of Congress are calling for punitive gestures like moving American troops out of Germany, or placing health restrictions on imported bottled water from France. 
However sulfurous the words from Washington officials, Germany and France are, along with Britain, the dominant partners in the world's most durable trading relationship. The emerging economies of Poland, Hungary, and the Czech Republic barely register in trans-Atlantic trade statistics. Even Spain and Portugal are relative minnows. 
Germany exported $56 billion worth of cars and other goods to the United States last year, making it the fifth largest exporter, after China. Poland's exports barely totaled $1 billion. While Poland, one of the countries whose leaders are close to President Bush, imported about $620 million worth of American goods, Germany imported more than $24 billion. 
With a gross domestic product of more than $1.3 trillion, France's economy is larger than the combined economies of Spain, Portugal, Poland, Hungary, Slovakia, and the Czech Republic. The German economy, the world's third largest, is twice the size of all those countries together.
"It's wonderful to have Poland and Hungary and the Czech Republic supporting us," said Felix Rohatyn, the investment banker and former American ambassador to Paris. "But it's also unrealistic in the extreme to equate the weight of these three countries with Germany and France."
"Germany makes Mercedes; the Czech Republic makes Skodas," Mr. Rohatyn said, referring to the utilitarian Czech cars that are the country's major export, and since 1993, a subsidiary of Volkswagen. Mr. Rohatyn said he believed Germany and France were making a "historical mistake" in opposing the United States. But he said the rift should not be allowed to unravel a web of commercial ties spun over half a century. 
Though there is no evidence of that yet, executives here worry that American companies might steer future investments away from France and Germany to southern and eastern European countries, which have pledged fealty to the Bush administration. 
"Only a demagogue would say, 'Don't buy German' or 'Don't buy French,' " said Norbert Quinkert, the chairman of Motorola Germany. "The danger is that investment decisions could be changed because of the public pressure. Companies might say, 'Why should I go to Germany?' " 
Like other executives here, Mr. Quinkert is pleading for cooler heads to prevail. "I'm proud to be part of this 'old Europe,' which has been working for hundreds of years, despite our wars," Mr. Quinkert said. His reference was to Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld's recent remark that France and Germany symbolize yesterday's Europe -- a line that has caused much debate, and more than a little anger, here. 
Both sides have much invested in the relationship. German carmakers like Mercedes-Benz and BMW depend on American customers to offset their depressed home market. Porsche sells nearly half its high-octane cars in the United States, and is rolling out a sport utility vehicle tailored for American tastes. 
But the risks are not all on one side. Mercedes and BMW have built sprawling assembly plants in Alabama and South Carolina. They also buy parts from American suppliers. Motorola, for example, supplies the microprocessors that run the gadgetry in BMW's 7-series sedans. For that matter, one of Detroit's Big Three, Chrysler, is owned by DaimlerChrysler of Stuttgart. 
Fifty years after the United States rebuilt Germany through the Marshall Plan, American business still has a huge presence here: 1,800 companies, employing 800,000 people, with combined sales of $583 billion. Ford and General Motors each generate $16 billion in sales from their German automotive divisions, which employ 63,000 workers. 
With their high costs and rigid labor markets, Germany and France are already vulnerable to losing American investment. Motorola considered closing a factory in the northern German city of Flensburg, which makes cellphones. Mr. Quinkert saved the plant, arguing that the skills of his German workers still outweighed the lower costs in countries like Malaysia. 
"I'm sure he's worried that the next time, he won't be able to do it," said Mr. Kornblum, who is now chairman of the German office of Lazard Freres, the French-American investment bank. 
In France, where the government has instituted a 35-hour workweek and strict policies against layoffs, the business environment for American companies is already so hostile that some executives say privately they doubt the political clash could make matters any worse. "I think it is going to be a non-event because no one is going to ask the question, 'Should we invest another $1 billion in France?' " said an American executive in Paris. 
Whether France's loss would be Eastern Europe's gain is an open question. But business people are already rubbing their hands together. Poland will join the European Union next year and Mr. Bush warmly greeted the Polish prime minister, Leszek Miller, last week at the White House. 
"Instead of seeing Poland mentioned with Lithuania and Slovakia, it's now being mentioned with Britain and Spain," said Tony Housh, an American board member of a vodka distribution company in Warsaw. 
Mr. Housh acknowledged that Eastern European countries still had impediments to business -- not least, endless red tape -- which could overshadow the glow of their newfound coziness with the United States. 
Nor are the "old Europeans" giving up without a fight. German industrialists plan to visit the United States to talk up the value of the German-American relationship. Atlantik-Brucke, a private German group that promotes closer trans-Atlantic ties, has reserved a full-page advertisement in The New York Times this Sunday.. 
Mr. Irwin, a gregarious former army captain who has lived in Germany since the 1960's, is putting himself through an intensive series of meetings, conferences, and press interviews to try to bridge the gap. 
"To me, the crisis could be turned into an advantage," he said, with unflagging enthusiasm. "It might be an opportunity to re-examine the German-American relationship since German reunification."

HEADLINE: Japan's Economy Expands For 4th Consecutive Quarter 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 14 

 BODY:
Japan's economy expanded at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 2 percent in the quarter ended Dec. 31, compared with the previous quarter, the government said today, defying expectations that growth had stalled and that the fourth recession in a decade had begun.
 As in other quarters in 2002, growth was driven by strong exports and steady gains in consumer spending and capital investment, which offset declines in new-home starts and government spending. 
 The string of four consecutive quarterly expansions, though, may come to a halt this year if the global economy slows and the government's campaign to purge the financial system of its nonperforming loans gathers steam. Any setbacks would intensify calls on Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, whose popularity is fading, to find more ways to stimulate the sagging economy with more public spending and a more relaxed monetary policy. Such measures have only softened the slowdown in recent years, not generated a robust expansion. 
In the latest quarter, the economy grew 2.4 percent, compared with the fourth quarter of 2001, when the previous recession was just ending. For all of 2002, Japan's economy grew 0.3 percent. The stronger-than-expected figures gave stock prices a lift. The benchmark Nikkei 225-stock index jumped 1.5 percent just after the numbers were released. The yen also gained ground against the dollar.
Despite the surprisingly upbeat quarterly figures, which are notoriously volatile, government ministers have tempered their optimism about the potential for further growth this year. Indeed, gloomy signs are everywhere in Japan. Unemployment is higher than it has been at any time since World War II and is still rising, while wages and household spending are sliding. As in the United States, consumer and corporate confidence has been further damaged by rising geopolitical tensions.
Those tensions, ranging from faraway Iraq to nearby North Korea, threaten to sever the one economic lifeline still supporting Japan's economy: exports. Shipments of cars, machinery and semiconductors to the United States and elsewhere in Asia have been buoying manufacturers whose domestic sales have slumped. That has kept profits up at global brand-name companies, that benefited from a 4.5 percent rise in exports in the October-December period. But with competition from lower-cost rivals in South Korea, China and elsewhere, Japanese managers have been reluctant to use their profits to pay workers more or to hire new ones. This has cast a shadow over the economy.
"At best, the economy will be close to zero in the first half of 2003 and will hit bottom in the third or fourth quarter," said Mikihiro Matsuoka, an economist with Deutsche Securities in Tokyo. "Even then, I don't expect a sharp recovery."
The government, which is sometimes accused of pumping up its forecasts to deflate critics, says it does not expect much of a recovery either. For the fiscal year beginning April 1, the government is planning on growth of 0.6 percent in real terms; at nominal prices, before adjusting for deflation, the forecast is for a contraction of 0.2 percent.
Even these anemic estimates may prove to be too rosy, some analysts say. Consumer spending was surprisingly resilient last year despite rising unemployment and a sharp decline in bonuses, but the only demographic group that increased its spending in 2002 was people older than 60. "Consumer spending defied gravity last year, but older Japanese are going to start feeling heat," said Frank Packer, an economist at Nikko Salomon Smith Barney.
Other Japanese already have. The government survey of consumer confidence fell for the fifth month running in January. Winter bonuses, which have typically been equal to two to three months' salary for many workers, shrank 3.1 percent on average in 2002. Spending by households headed by a salaried worker contracted by a staggering 12.2 percent in the fourth quarter from the third.
Japanese companies plan to trim their capital spending plans by 7.9 percent in the current fiscal year, a cabinet survey found.
The grim news has led to calls for Mr. Koizumi to abandon his policy of trying to rein in new public spending, and the weak G.D.P. figures released today may provide his opponents with the "smoking gun" they need.
But the prime minister, backed by officials in the Finance Ministry, is reluctant to abandon his fiscal austerity program. Instead, he has called on the Bank of Japan to ease monetary policy further, even though the bank's interest rates are already effectively zero.
Mr. Koizumi has also promised to choose a "deflation fighter" to succeed the bank's departing governor, Masaru Hayami, who is set to step down March 19. Mr. Hayami has resisted calls for radical measures, insisting that easier monetary conditions would accomplish little unless accompanied by steps to clean up the debt-hobbled financial industry. He is unlikely to recommend any fresh action at the bank's two-day policy board meeting, which ends today.
However aggressive his successor may be, big changes are unlikely to be made overnight. Like many entrenched bureaucracies, the Bank of Japan tries to preserve the continuity of its policies, so any big shift toward trying to bolster the economy would take months, Mr. Matsuoka of Deutsche Securities said. "You can't suddenly subscribe to Buddhism if you've been a Christian," he said.

HEADLINE: Office Depot Matches Wall St. Expectations 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: DELRAY BEACH, Fla., Feb. 13 

 BODY:
Office Depot Inc., the office supplies retailer, said today that its earnings rose 56 percent in the fourth quarter on a small increase in sales. 
 But the company, which is based in Delray Beach, said it expected earnings growth this year to be limited by a sagging economy. 
 Earnings were $62.9 million, or 20 cents a share, in the October-December period, up from $40.3 million, or 13 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. 
Excluding one-time items, it earned 22 cents a share, matching the forecast of Wall Street analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. 
Revenue rose to $2.84 billion from $2.78 billion. 
Although sales at United States and Canadian retail stores fell 1 percent, business sales grew 4 percent and international sales rose 17 percent. 
Office Depot's chief executive, Bruce Nelson, was not as hopeful for this year.
"As we look forward to 2003, we do not see many encouraging signs that we can expect a significant improvement in the overall economic environment during the first half of the year," Mr. Nelson said.

HEADLINE: Bankers Opposing New State Curbs On Unfair Loans 

BYLINE:  By DIANA B. HENRIQUES with JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The banking industry has stepped up a fight to block new state laws aimed at curbing unscrupulous mortgage lending.
 Disappointed with federal efforts, a number of states, including New York, have adopted their own laws over the last three years to combat mortgages that carry unjustly high fees or rates that can cost some borrowers their homes. 
 But bankers are warning that the emerging patchwork of state rules could seriously disrupt the marketplace that supplies credit to home buyers across the country. And yesterday, a Republican congressman proposed a new federal law that would pre-empt the state statutes entirely.
Although both sides expect New York and Washington to emerge as the next hot spots in this struggle, the focus right now is Georgia. Last year, Georgia enacted what consumer advocates call the nation's toughest law against this kind of lending, known as predatory lending. But in recent weeks, a grueling battle has been waged in the Georgia Legislature over how to address Wall Street's concerns without weakening protections for homeowners. 
The Georgia Fair Lending Act, the rope in this bitter tug of war, was intended to prevent what is happening now to Mildred White, a 76-year-old retired school cafeteria worker. As lobbyists worked the halls at the state Capitol last Tuesday, Ms. White was in Federal Bankruptcy Court a few blocks away trying to save her home from foreclosure.
Her troubles began in 1999, when a local mortgage broker persuaded her to refinance her home. The new mortgage left her nearly $70,000 in debt, with monthly payments that consume more than half of her monthly income of $1,100. "I haven't had a good night's sleep since this happened," said Ms. White, who relies on a church food pantry.
A mortgage like Ms. White's would probably be illegal today under the new law, said William J. Brennan Jr. of the Atlanta Legal Aid Society. For one thing, the law prohibits loans made without regard to the borrower's ability to repay and requires counseling before closing, which would probably have warned Ms. White away, he said.
But most important, the law allows borrowers to sue not only the original lender but anyone who subsequently buys the mortgage. Like most mortgages, Ms. White's loan was sold by the original lender and became part of a pool of mortgages overseen by Citibank as the trustee.
"If she were subject to the new law, I think she'd have a claim, and she could assert it against Citibank," said Mr. Brennan, who is assisting Ms. White. "But I can't do that now. All we can do for her is file a bankruptcy petition."
It is, though, exactly that provision of the new law -- an arrangement that lawyers call assignee liability -- that has alarmed Wall Street and prompted the local banks and home builders to predict that mortgage money in Georgia will dry up unless the law is rewritten.
Although nearly a dozen states have adopted predatory lending laws, lawyers say the only other statute that clearly imposes assignee liability is the one that goes into effect in New York on April 1. But similar provisions are being considered in other states, including New Jersey.
Those state laws would all be moot, of course, if Wall Street persuaded Congress to adopt a federal response to predatory lending. Yesterday, Representative Bob Ney, Republican of Ohio, filed a bill that would amend the Home Ownership and Equity Protection Act of 1994, which regulates high-cost mortgage loans, to pre-empt the new local laws. Like the Georgia law, the federal law holds loan buyers liable for violations by original lenders, but rating-agency lawyers say the federal liability is more limited and predictable.
A large coalition of consumers, community groups, unions and civil rights organizations opposes the Ney bill, which they say will weaken or eliminate the federal language about liability. And without that protection, they say, abusive lenders can simply sell their loans and fold their tents, leaving a homeowner facing foreclosure for defaulting on an illegal loan.
"Without assignee liability, you might as well just throw the law out," said J. Michael Vaughan, a lawyer in Kansas City who has filed a class-action suit on behalf of Missouri homeowners who say they were charged excessive origination fees. The defendants in the cases include several banks and mortgage buyers that bought those disputed loans from the original lenders. 
But investment bankers say that assignee liability -- at least, the version built into the Georgia law -- strikes at the heart of the process Wall Street uses to raise money to finance home mortgages.
That process, called securitization, begins with the creation of a corporate shell called a trust. Like mutual funds that sell shares and use the money to invest in stocks, these trusts sell bonds, called mortgage-backed securities, and use the money to buy mortgages from lenders across the country. By selling their loans to these trusts, lenders raise capital to make new loans, which makes credit more available in the mortgage market.
Last month, Standard & Poor's, the rating agency, rocked Georgia and Wall Street by announcing that it would no longer give credit ratings to securitization trusts that buy any home loans from Georgia. Moody's Investors Service and Fitch Ratings have followed suit.
The rating agencies say the new law's liability provision, and its ambiguous language about which loans are subject to that provision, make it impossible to assess the riskiness of mortgage-backed securities backed by Georgia loans. Their concern, they said, is that the trusts could face unlimited punitive damages if they inadvertently buy even a few loans that turn out to have been illegal.
Securities issued by an unrated trust would be at a disadvantage in the marketplace because many institutional investors are not allowed to buy unrated securities.
Some lenders say that the secondary market for Georgia loans has since been in turmoil. On Feb. 1, the giant Residential Funding Corporation, a unit of G.M.A.C. that specializes in higher-cost loans, stopped buying such loans in Georgia, citing the uncertainty caused by the rating agencies' actions. Other mortgage buyers have expressed similar concerns, especially about loans made to less creditworthy borrowers.
"Georgia has shot itself in the foot," said Thomas H. Meyer, chief executive of the Homebuilders Financial Network, which provides mortgage services for major home builders. "This may become a major impediment to the growth of the real estate industry in Georgia."
With support from a local coalition of banks and credit unions, the state's House of Representatives unanimously adopted a bill last week that calls for substantial revisions to the assignee liability language and other provisions that lenders find onerous.
While supporters of the existing law acknowledged that the rating agencies' concern should be addressed, they are concerned that Wall Street is using that issue "as a smoke screen to gut the law,"' said Kathy Floyd, a lobbyist for AARP in Georgia. Her organization supports a bill adopted on Wednesday by the State Senate, which limits the liability facing loan buyers and clarifies some of the law's terms and definitions, but leaves it otherwise intact.
Consumer groups outside Georgia say that banks and underwriters are already citing the state's fears of a credit drought to challenge tough predatory lending bills elsewhere.
"They are in the process now of launching a huge campaign to wipe out everything we have done," said Bertha Lewis, of the New York chapter of Acorn, an advocacy group that supports the local initiatives. "We are quite concerned about 'the death of a thousand cuts' for predatory lending laws across the country."
The debate over a federal solution is just as heated. Consumer groups say the Ney bill could weaken the liability provisions in the federal law, leaving states with what one lawyer called "the worst of both worlds -- a federal law that doesn't work but that makes it impossible for states to enact laws that do work."
But mortgage market competitors are growing increasingly concerned about way the Georgia fight is affecting business. "At this juncture, the sharpening differences among federal, state and local laws make a long look at federal pre-emption an idea that should be carefully considered," said Michael Seats, general counsel for the Residential Funding Corporation.
Jeffrey Zeltzer, executive director of the National Home Equity Mortgage Association, which represents lenders serving less creditworthy borrowers, favors the Ney bill but insists that it will not weaken federal law.
"There is no doubt that consumer protection needs to be bolstered," Mr. Zeltzer said. "But the mortgage market is a national market, and our concern is that there should be one clear national standard."
