HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut; 
After Long Drought, High-End Housing for Hartford

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES 

DATELINE: HARTFORD 

 BODY:
HARTFORD lost much of its middle and upper middle class to the suburbs in the last part of the 20th century, but there are signs that the exodus may be ending.
 Developers of residential real estate who have shunned Connecticut's capital for years are sensing a change and buying property on which to build high-end homes in or near downtown, with easy access not only to offices on State Street but also to the Hartford Symphony at the Bushnell Performing Arts Center, the Hartford Stage and the Wadsworth Atheneum. 
 Two major properties now under development are restorations at the historic Goodwin Estate and the Colt Armory complex, both designed to appeal to professionals and well-to-do empty nesters.
The first site seems an unlikely one, a 17,000-square-foot mansion so ruined that its condition brings to mind downtown Dresden after the World War II bombings. The slate roof is gone and the upper portion of the 12-inch-thick brick walls are shattered, leaving the interior exposed to the elements. The windows are a distant memory and whatever a 1996 fire failed to damage past redemption, vandals accomplished. During the years that the property has been vacant, the 17-acre grounds, which contains scores of specimen trees and shrubs, have reverted to wilderness. 
Nevertheless, the historic Goodwin Estate, built in 1903 at 1280 Asylum Avenue, will be restored by the Ginsburg Development Company of Hawthorne, N.Y., with seven condominium flats offered along with 56 new town houses to be built on the property as Hartford's first new high-end housing in 20 years. 
The estate has been listed on the National Register of Historic Places as part of the Prospect Street Historic District since 1985. Consequently, restoration of the mansion is central to the $20 million redevelopment. The deed requires the Connecticut Historical Commission to approve any demolition or alterations, but none of any consequence are expected.
Amenta Emma, architects for the project, have no drawings or plans as guides in reconstructing what was lost, so they are using old photographs of the house in trying to replicate the exterior. The interior will be reconfigured for six two-bedroom units and one with three bedrooms, a fitness center, community room with kitchen and bar and residents' lockers for the outdoor pool to be built in the mansion's enclosed courtyard. The original paneled library escaped serious damage and will be preserved for the use of residents. 
The three-bedroom town houses will be constructed in groupings of two or four units in 18 buildings in a landscaped semicircle around the mansion's rear sides and back, echoing its traditional architecture and its red brick exterior walls with white wood trim. A faux slate material will be used for the roof, since real slate would be prohibitively expensive.
Because of the sloping terrain, almost all of the town houses will have walkout lower level patios and decks above them, as well as two-car garages. Flats in the mansion will have outdoor covered parking. A new road beginning and ending on Asylum Avenue will wind into and around the cluster of homes.
"Some trees will be cleared to provide a view of the mansion from Asylum Avenue," said Robert Emma, "lighted in a restrained way at night." Wildlife will continue to occupy the remaining 10 acres of unspoiled meadows, woods and wetlands in perpetuity, but the developed areas will have extensive landscaping by Henry Withers, a principal in CR3, a firm in Simsbury.
Estimated prices are modest by comparison with similar homes built by Ginsburg in other places. The company sells three-bedroom town houses in Fairfield County for around $650,000, but the Goodwin homes will vary from $250,000 for a 1,500-square-foot flat to $450,000 for a 3,000-square-foot town house. Common charges are estimated at $225 a month.
Although site work has barely begun and at least a year of work lies ahead before the first units are completed, the project, which is two blocks from the governor's residence in Hartford's exclusive West End, has already attracted a list of almost two dozen buyers, including several members of the State Legislature. Other prospective owners are scaling down from larger homes or want the convenience of living near where they work.
Ginsburg Development acquired the estate in December from the city for $409,500, a fraction of the $1.9 million the city paid to purchase it from the state in 1989. The state was given the property by the Goodwin family in 1953 to be used for educational purposes, and the University of Connecticut held classes there until 1989. 
THE city's timing of the acquisition could hardly have been worse, as real estate prices collapsed in the late 80's and early 90's and the property became a white elephant. "We couldn't dispose of it," said Bruno Mazzulla, Hartford's director of housing and community development.
A request for proposals from developers was sent out and brought no responses. A second request, issued two years ago, generated four proposals, including Ginsburg's. Its cluster plan won over the other three, which featured single-family homes on large lots.
"We're pretty excited about finding a developer of this caliber to do this," Mr. Mazzulla said. He estimates that the city will receive $450,000 a year in property taxes when the project is completed.
"We have an undersupplied market in Hartford for the kind of housing we build," said Martin Ginsburg, co-principal of the development company with his brother Samuel. "We are very selective about where we go," he said, "and we design specifically for the site and its relationship to the community."
The 38-year-old company, which has a number of successful developments in Westchester and Fairfield Counties, New Jersey and Florida, has been moving deeper into Connecticut. It has projects completed or under construction in Redding, Newtown and Danbury and projects pending in Farmington and West Hartford, according to Thomas Gissen, executive vice president at the Connecticut division headquarters in Danbury. 
The move into the capital city, however, is noteworthy. "Private developers have not seen fit to invest in Hartford since the 80's," said Matt Fleury, director of communications for the Capital City Economic Development Authority, a quasi-public organization established to carry out Gov. John G. Rowland's Six Pillars Revitalization Plan for Hartford. The "pillars" are a convention center, parking, riverfront improvement, civic center revitalization, downtown renewal and housing -- specifically the creation of 1,000 new market rate units downtown.
Increased investment in home ownership is the goal, in a city where only 25 to 30 percent of the homes are occupied by their owners. "The Goodwin project," he said, "is an example of 100 percent private developments that are starting to follow the subsidized projects and spark a long-term sense of confidence in this market."
Four subsidized downtown residential developments that will include market-rate rental apartments have been approved. A development on Trumbull Street is already in the works; construction at the former Sage-Allen department store, Adriaen's Landing and the site of the Civic Center Mall, which is to be torn down, will break ground this summer.
Each project will contain 100 or more units and have shops and restaurants at street level. The city, reimbursed by the state, will invest $60,000 per unit, with the remaining costs borne by the developers. 
In addition to the Goodwin project, a second major upscale redevelopment is getting under way at the former Colt Armory complex, whose star-spangled blue onion dome overlooking Interstate 91 has been a marker for travelers since the highway was built in the late 50's.
Built in the early 1850's, the armory is part of the Colt Industrial District, placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1976. Late last month it was purchased for $5.7 million from Coltsville Heritage Park Inc., a nonprofit entity, by Colt Gateway L.L.C., a venture of Homes for America Holdings Inc. of Yonkers. 
FOR the past few decades, the Colt factory's 700,000 square feet of space in 12 buildings have been partially occupied by a variety of tenants, including artists, some of whom maintain live-work units; small manufacturers; and commercial businesses. "There are 110 tenants," said Robert Kohn, chief operating officer of Homes for America. "We are trying to relocate them within the complex. We believe the people who live and work there have kept the property alive."
Some smaller buildings with structural faults will be taken down, Mr. Kohn said, but the $110 million conversion into a residential, office, retail and restaurant complex will not involve new construction. "We will work with what is there," he said. There will be 300 apartments, 650 to 1,400 square feet, and lofts with plumbing and electricity installed will measure 1,000 to 2,500 square feet.
The developers were encouraged to take on the project by the effort already under way at Adriaen's Landing, the city's long-delayed, mixed-use development on the Connecticut River of residences, hotels, retail, recreation and entertainment. "Having the city and state do their work at Adriaen's Landing opened the door for us to come in," Mr. Kohn said. "If there was no master plan and additional apartments coming in, we would have felt the timing was not right."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey; 
Developing Software for Managing Real Estate

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN 

 BODY:
A GROUP of eight real estate companies, including some of New York and New Jersey's major players, is investing money, ideas and hands-on experience in the creation of a Web-based computer software product tailored to suit the particular needs of property managers. 
 The software being developed by Integrated Business Systems of Fairfield, N.J., incorporates a Web browser that provides access to a company's central database via any Internet connection and employs the Internet's speed and agility for complex business tasks. For large diversified real estate companies, this means that offices in different places and divisions handling different kinds of business have a live connection to consolidated information and can generate instant reports and analysis, said Robert Entin, president of Integrated Business Systems. 
 The software, to be called IBS 10.0i -- following tradition, since the current IBS product is named 10.0 -- is being designed to be "as deep as it is wide," said Mr. Entin. "It is scalable, so it can be used to serve the particular needs of smaller companies as well as large corporations. And it can meet the specific requirements of individual department heads working in the New York metropolitan area." 
For managers of a large shopping mall, for instance, it will automatically determine how much each tenant pays in rent for the mall's common areas according to an extraordinarily complicated government formula, Mr. Entin said.
And for residential property managers, the software will automate compliance with New York City's rent regulations and controls, rent renewal procedure, agency registration requirements, fuel surcharges and taxes -- with the correct government forms popping up on the screen at the time they are needed, he said.
"Some of the other large, bulky pieces of software can get the big jobs done," Mr. Entin said, "but it's like covering the wall with a paint roller. I think ours is really the one that is so detailed. It will be like paint-by-number with incredibly small boxes."
"This area has the most demanding property owners anywhere," he asserted, "and the toughest lease market to service, because the level of complexity of New York leases is way higher than it is elsewhere. We are working on a software that will understand the nuances, for both residential and commercial property owners."
The investor group financing the $3 million to $5 million software development project consists of the Mack-Cali Realty Corporation, Vornado Realty Trust, the Reckson Associates Realty Corporation, Jack Resnick & Sons, the Feil Organization, the Donald Zucker Organization, Koeppel & Koeppel and Pantzer Properties. The companies became preferred stockholders in I.B.S., and all have had a say in determining what features IBS 10.0i will offer, according to Mr. Entin. They will, however, pay fees touse it, as they do for IBS 10.0, he said.
Software for property management is a highly competitive field. Other software companies with products specifically tailored for property owners and managers include Yardi Systems, TTI, MRI and J. D. Edwards, some of them specifically designed for property managers, and a few -- Yardi's Enterprise Voyager, for example -- also incorporating Web browsers.
Gualberto Medina, the former New Jersey commissioner of Commerce and Economic Development who now directs Cushman & Wakefield's team working to stimulate high-tech business development in New Jersey, said the I.B.S. software project signifies the cresting of a trend. "Right now, every service organization is looking for this type of solution," he said, "comprehensive, agile software that operates from anywhere, from any network, any device."
Some companies are looking for narrower solutions, said Jonathan B. Schultz, president of the Woodbridge-based Shultz Oganization. His real estate company's technology team is working on developing Web-enabled software that focuses on leasing and works with a device that scans written leases into a computer, then automates aspects of the leasing process.
MORE than 120 real estate firms in the region, owning or managing a total of 500 million square feet of residential and commercial property, use products developed by I.B.S., which was founded 22 years ago, Mr. Entin said.
He began devoting his time solely to development of the new application a year and a half ago, Mr. Entin said, and quickly assembled teams of programmers to work on aspects of the project. Because the technology market has been hit so hard, he said, many highly qualified people were available -- and the work proceeded "speedily and efficiently." 
The real estate companies that invested in developing the 10.0i software each had a say over the past year and half of development about specific features they wanted, he said. 
The Jack Parker Corporation is field testing the new software alongside 10.0, said its chief operating officer, Jean-Pierre Vaganay. His company is not among the investors but has been using I.B.S. products for 14 years.
Speaking of the new version, Mr. Vaganay said: "We are very impressed. It has a user-friendly browser and icons, within a highly integrated real estate package that permits you to effectively run your business, from construction to accounting, and through the leasing process."
"With the assistance of this system," he said, "our financial people can deliver consolidated financial statements on the entire empire by the 10th of each month."
Mr. Entin said that because Jack Parker's holdings are so diverse and far-flung, it was an excellent company to test the new application. The company, based in Queens, owns and manages a range of types of property across the Northeast and Florida, including more than 4,000 apartment units, 5 million square feet of office and industrial space, and two New York hotels. In New Jersey, Jack Parker owns and manages Parker Plaza, a Class A office building in Fort Lee that is currently 98 percent occupied. The company also has a full-service construction division, which builds both commercial and residential structures.
Jack Parker's president, Adam Glick, who is the third generation to run his family's business, told Integrated Business Systems that what he wanted was "complete technology integration" for the separate businesses that make up the large corporation, Mr. Entin said. "For I.B.S.," he said, "this meant implementing connections and fostering compatibilitybetween the company's New York City hotels and residential buildings, its New York-area commercial properties, its industrial sites in Raleigh and its Tampa-based residential and construction operations."
Another investor in the software's development, Edward S. Pantzer, president of Pantzer Properties, said one of his aims was making the tool user friendly. The software, he said, "is going to make retrieval of data so much simpler. We employ nearly 175 people who would be using it, so user-friendliness is very important to us."
Pantzer owns more than 6,000 apartment units and three office buildings in five states. Mr. Pantzer noted that his company considered switching to some other company's software if it could generate better, faster reports. But his company is enthusiastic about the I.B.S. software's real-estate accounting applications, he said -- and besides, he added, converting to a new program is "agony."
"We chose to invest, and to be closely involved in the development of the new software, so that our needs will be met for the foreseeable future," he said.
Mr. Pantzer said his company's focus is on multifamily housing and it needs to generate continuous reports on leasing activity, apartment availability and expenditures made by landlords and managers. Mr. Entin said the new software would deliver reports graphically laid out in the particular manner Pantzer prefers.
Mr. Entin said I.B.S.'s history covers both the residential and commercial real estate fields. "From the beginning, we had two different perspectives and developed the two separate residential/commercial systems," he said. "My grandfather was a property owner-developer," he added, "and I was a computer engineer, so we had both perspectives in that way too."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert Entin, president, says 120 real estate firms in the region use Integrated Business Systems software. (Richard L. Harbus for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Even in a Harsh Job Market, Veterans Find a Welcome 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOEPPEL 

 BODY:
AFTER 20 years as a career naval officer, Richard S. Richard Jr. did not expect his transition from military to civilian life to go quite so smoothly.
 Mr. Richard joined the Navy in 1982, right out of high school, and spent the next two decades crisscrossing the country from San Diego to Groton, Conn., to Bremerton, Wash., his final posting. Then, at 38, he retired from the military last November and embarked on the first job search of his life. 
 He assumed that the naval training he had received in data systems and electronics and the leadership skills he had acquired as a chief petty officer would give him an edge in a weak economy. What he did not foresee was the esteem that his military background would inspire.
"Everybody I spoke with seemed to believe it was a plus," Mr. Richard said. "My maturity and hard-won experience in difficult environments, that's something that the average college guy doesn't have." Since the Persian Gulf war, the public's perception of the military "has changed for the better, and it's been strong ever since," he said.
Within three months, Mr. Richard received several job offers. Though he and his wife wanted to return to their native Long Island to raise their 3-year-old twin sons, he reluctantly turned down a $60,000 position with the Brookhaven National Laboratory there to accept the same salary as an information technology analyst in Virginia Beach, where the money would stretch further.
Many corporate recruiters who specialize in placing former military personnel agree with Mr. Richard's assessment. They say that despite the uncertain economic outlook, it is a good time to be a veteran looking for work in the private sector, particularly for those with strong technology skills.
And, they say, with the nation on a war footing and patriotism on the rise, corporate America is taking an increasingly sympathetic look at the intangibles of leadership, teamwork and trustworthiness that are the mark of military life. That is good news for the estimated 250,000 men and women who leave the armed services every year.
Ted Daywalt, president of VetJobs.com, one of the largest Internet job sites for veterans, said that those with strong technology skills, health care experience and sales ability are in demand, while those seeking administrative and human resource positions are having a more difficult time.
There were 38 new job listings for the New York metropolitan area posted on VetJobs.com in January, with companies like Home Depot, Philip Morris and Young & Rubicam seeking applicants for management, sales and finance positions. Combined Insurance Company of America, a unit of the Aon Corporation, hired 115 veterans who posted resumes on the job site, many in its New Jersey office, according to Mr. Daywalt.
Home Depot has been particularly aggressive in courting veterans, and has teamed with the Department of Labor and military headhunters to lure them into its two-year management training program.
"Leading a platoon is like leading a store," said John Simley, a spokesman for Home Depot. "There's a fine line between combat and retail, but both have the same objective, to beat the competition. Both require creativity and improvisation and understanding of risks and rewards."
Last year, the U.S. Alliance Group, a corporate recruiter with offices in New York and Virginia, placed about 100 candidates in the Home Depot program, according to its president, Alfred Schreiber.
"I think 9/11 was a double-edged sword for the military," said Mr. Schreiber, whose firm specializes in matching employers with military personnel. "It was a tragedy that woke people up to the contribution the military can make."
It is not that all employers have dropped all their reservations about soldiers. Recruiters say some hiring managers persist in viewing military men and women as being too "dictatorial" and having trouble "developing consensus." And, said Mr. Daywalt, himself a former Navy captain, an executive once surprised him by asserting that veterans lacked "real-world experience."
One problem, he said, is that many human resources managers do not know anyone in the military. "For many, there's still an image of a gun-toting John Wayne or an incompetent Beetle Bailey," he said. "It's so far removed from the reality."
To combat such preconceptions, Mr. Schreiber advises clients to unlearn some of their military ways, like excessive formality. And they should shed military jargon, especially as it can mask their accomplishments. A fire control technician on a submarine, for example, might be misperceived merely as someone who can put out fires, whereas in reality the job requires familiarity with sophisticated technology like missile-guidance radar systems.
Unemployment among former military personnel has stayed fairly consistent over the last five years, at a half point or so lower than the general population. The preliminary figure for last year was 4.7 percent, compared with 5.2 percent for nonveterans, though in New York State it was 4.6 percent, slightly higher than the jobless rate of 4.4 percent for nonveterans.
While veterans with technical expertise or management skills are doing well, lower-level soldiers and sailors are having a tougher time of it. Wesley Poriotis, the chairman of Wesley, Brown & Bartle, a New York executive search firm, and the founder of the Center for Military and Private Sector Initiatives, a nonprofit organization and advocacy group, says veterans sometimes have difficulty getting licensing for the same tasks, like driving trucks, programming computers and repairing aircraft engines, that they mastered in the military.
Frederico Juarbe Jr., assistant secretary of labor for veterans employment and training, said his agency was working to ensure that licensing officials give greater recognition to the accomplishments of servicemen and servicewomen.
Gordon Berg, a spokesman for Mr. Juarbe's division, summed up his position. "Clearly, we're trying to eliminate the redundancies," he said. "If someone can fix jet aircrafts, clearly they can fix a 737. But the F.A.A. says they have to prove it."
Mr. Juarbe says that the image of veterans has improved a great deal since the Sept. 11 attacks, and many former military members say they have noticed the change.
"There's a better appreciation of what uniform veterans bring to the work force," he said. "Punctuality, leadership experience, experience in teams. It translates into greater value that they bring to employment."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard S. Richard Jr., at home in Virginia Beach, left the military last November and says he has encountered an esteem for experience in the military on his job search. (Gary Knapp for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: YOUR TAXES: TAX TIPS; 
Benefit Cuts May Bring Deductions

BYLINE:  By JAN M. ROSEN 

 BODY:
TAXPAYERS who explore the nooks and crannies of the tax code, which is full of provisions applying to many special situations, may be able to pare their bills, both on 2002 returns and in the future.
 Because of the current economic slowdown, some employers are cutting back on benefits, as well as paring payrolls. As a result, some people can claim deductions for which they did not qualify in past years, said Avery E. Neumark, the partner in charge of employee benefits and executive compensation at Rosen Seymour Shapss Martin & Company, an accounting firm in New York. 

MEDICAL EXPENSES -- These costs, including medical insurance premiums, are deductible only to the extent that they exceed 7.5 percent of adjusted gross income, he noted. Taxpayers may more easily qualify for the deduction if their income is down or if they have to pay a greater share of their insurance costs.
MISCELLANEOUS DEDUCTIONS -- These costs, which include unreimbursed employee expenses, are deductible only to the extent that they exceed 2 percent of adjusted gross income. To keep their jobs in a tight job market, some people are bearing expenses that their employers would have borne in the past, Mr. Neumark said.

DEDUCTIBLE I.R.A.'S -- Mr. Neumark also advised eligible taxpayers to make deductible contributions to I.R.A.'s or retirement plans for the self-employed before filing their 2002 tax returns. I.R.A. contributions for 2002 must be made by this April 15, even by taxpayers who get extensions to file their returns. "It may be your last opportunity for a deductible contribution," he said, referring to President Bush's proposal to replace deductible accounts with Retirement Savings Accounts that would be funded with after-tax money.
For 2002, up to $3,000 can be put into an I.R.A. ($3,500 if you are 50 or older), and the contribution is deductible if you are not covered by a pension plan. Even if you are covered by such a plan, the contribution is fully deductible if you are single and if your modified adjusted gross income is below $34,000; the deduction phases out at $44,000. For married people filing jointly, the limits are $54,000 and $64,000. 

RETIREMENT SAVINGS CONTRIBUTION CREDIT -- New for the 2002 tax year, this credit is for lower-income workers. A single person who contributed to either an employer-sponsored retirement plan or an I.R.A. may be entitled to up to $1,000, Mr. Neumark noted. A single person can claim a credit of up to 50 percent of the contribution if his or her adjusted gross income is not more than $15,000; the credit phases out at $25,000 of income. The credit and the income limits double for couples.

ADOPTION CREDIT -- A credit of up to $10,000 for qualifying expenses is available to people who adopted children in 2002, noted Sidney Kess, a New York tax lawyer and accountant. The full credit is available to people whose adjusted gross income is $150,000 or less; the credit phases out at $190,000. The credit limit is twice that of previous years. A special tax form, 8839, must be attached to the tax return in order to claim the credit.

TWO NEW EDUCATION DEDUCTIONS -- Teachers who spent out-of-pocket money for classroom expenses can deduct up to $250, while people who incurred higher-education costs can deduct up to $3,000 in 2002 and 2003, if their adjusted gross income does not exceed $65,000 for single filers or $130,000 for couples filing jointly.
In addition to reducing taxes for 2002, taxpayers can plan their personal finances to gain tax benefits in future years. Bernard S. Kent, personal financial services partner for PricewaterhouseCoopers in Detroit, discussed two ways to do that.

EMPLOYER-PROVIDED EDUCATION ASSISTANCE -- Employees are not taxed on up to $5,250 a year of education assistance paid by an employer. "This is a nice benefit to have, particularly for people who do not have degrees," Mr. Kent said. Beginning last year, the benefit also applied to graduate, as well as undergraduate, courses.

DEFERRED COMPENSATION -- If tax rates drop this year or if your income drops, putting you in a lower tax bracket, you can realize significant tax savings by deferring compensation. But Mr. Kent offered an important caveat: be sure that your employer is financially sound before entering into any deferred-compensation arrangement. If the employer files for bankruptcy, as a number of big companies did in 2002, you could lose your deferred pay or get just pennies on the dollar. That is because the deferred-compensation agreement makes you a general unsecured creditor of your employer. JAN M. ROSEN

HEADLINE: Your Taxes; 
College Savings Plans: You'll Need a Scorecard

BYLINE:  By HILARY APPELMAN 

 BODY:
MORGAN LUNT, 20, and Toby Lunt, 17, began working for their father's plumbing contracting business in Emeryville, Calif., even before they were teenagers. "They started around the office, organizing paperwork and materials around the shop," said Jim Lunt, their father. "As they got older, they were able to go out and actually assist in the field."
 Mr. Lunt's company could deduct Morgan's and Toby's wages as business expenses, while their low incomes meant that they were only lightly taxed on their earnings. Encouraged by matching funds from their father, the brothers socked away thousands of dollars in I.R.A. savings. 
 When Morgan enrolled at Dartmouth College, Mr. Lunt stopped claiming him as a dependent on his tax return, enabling Morgan to qualify for a Hope Scholarship credit on his own return. The credit offset all of Morgan's taxes. 
Mr. Lunt also took advantage of the hottest trend in education savings, state-sponsored college savings plans, opening accounts for both sons with California's Golden State ScholarShare College Savings Trust. The savings plans, commonly called 529 plans after the section of the tax code that authorized them, grew vastly more appealing when Congress made their earnings tax-free, effective in 2002.
The 529 plans may be the most popular game in town, but they are far from the only one. Parents looking to shave their tax bills and save for college face a bewildering array of investment options and tax credits, each with a different set of regulations and income restrictions. 
"There are more choices than there ever were," said Steven Calvelli, a partner in the personal financial services group at the PricewaterhouseCoopers office in Florham Park, N.J. "It's a very complex maze, and you have to figure out where you fit in."
New for 2002, Congress quadrupled the annual contribution limit to education I.R.A.'s, now called Coverdell Education Savings Accounts, to $2,000. It also allowed use of the accounts' tax-free distributions for elementary and secondary school tuition and expenses as well as for higher education.
If the Bush administration wins Congressional approval for its proposed Lifetime Savings Accounts, the options will change again next year. Under the proposal, individuals could save $7,500 a year -- couples $15,000 -- for any purpose. As in a 529 plan, after-tax money would go in, and earnings, when withdrawn, would be free of tax. Under the administration proposal, 529 plans, Coverdell accounts and Archer medical savings accounts could be converted to the new Lifetime Savings Accounts before Jan. 1, 2004.
In this filing season, people are realizing some of the changes enacted in the 2001 tax law. Child tax credits will gradually rise from $600 for 2002 to $1,000 in 2010, and a new deduction of up to $3,000 for higher education expenses is allowed on 2002 returns. Also starting for 2002 returns, the time limit for deducting interest on student loans has been repealed. The law also provided higher income limits for many educational tax benefits and eased restrictions on combining tax breaks in the same year.
Section 529 plans, which are popular because of their lack of income restrictions and their high contribution ceilings -- more than $300,000 in some states -- became hard to beat once Congress made their earnings tax-free, Mr. Calvelli said. In addition, more than 20 states allow full or partial tax deduction of contributions to in-state 529's. Mr.Calvelli said, however, that the new Lifetime Savings Accounts would be even more attractive for most taxpayers.
The 529's are one of the few education tax breaks available to high-income taxpayers. Contributions count toward the annual gift tax exclusion -- $11,000 from any one donor to one recipient. But the law allows five years' worth of contributions -- up to $55,000, or $110,000 from a married couple -- to be made at once.
That front-loading provision makes the 529 a good estate planning tool, said Meloni Hallock, a partner in the Los Angeles office of Ernst & Young. "That $110,000 is now out of your estate," she said. "It's a wonderful device, so I have a lot of clients who do it." 
Julie and Michael Stapleton of Penfield, N.Y., a suburb of Rochester, initially bought individual stocks for their children, ages 1, 3 and 5, but recently decided to open 529 accounts instead. The couple, whose fourth child is due in June, cashed in savings bonds that the children had received from grandparents and other relatives and suggested that future gifts go into the accounts as well. "Our life is very hectic," said Mr. Stapleton, a nurse manager. "I'd rather have it all in one account."
Philip Johnson, a financial planner in Clifton Park, N.Y., who specializes in education planning, recommends that families leave a significant percentage of their savings in all-purpose investments available for other needs -- a concern that the Lifetime Savings Accounts would address. "A good 529 plan is a very good tool," he said, "but it isn't the whole toolbox."
ANOTHER attractive possibility for middle-income people is Series EE and I Savings Bonds. They can be bought in an adult's name and redeemed tax-free to pay college expenses -- subject to restrictions on adjusted gross income in the year of redemption. On 2002 returns, the limits are $57,600 for single filers and $86,400 for married couples for income to be fully tax-free. The phase-out range for the interest exclusion is $15,000 for single people and $30,000 for joint filers.
Parents can also invest in growth stocks, then transfer them to their child to sell before tuition payments are due and take advantage of the child's lower tax rate.
Nancy Flint-Budde, a financial planner also in Clifton Park, N.Y., is using that strategy to help save for her three sons, now 10, 12 and 15. Ms. Flint-Budde's husband inherited some highly appreciated General Electric stock eight years ago. When their oldest son turned 14, she and her husband gave him $6,000 worth of the stock. When it is sold, her son will be eligible for a new 8 percent capital gains tax rate -- less than half the 20 percent rate she and her husband would pay. "Next year my second-oldest boy will turn 14," she said, "and we'll do the same thing with him."
Children 14 and older are taxed at the regular single taxpayer rate -- 10 percent on the first $6,000 of taxable income and 15 percent up to $27,950. Taxpayers in those brackets pay 10 percent tax on long-term capital gains or 8 percent on property held more than five years. Unearned income of more than $1,500 held by children under 14 is taxed at the parents' top rate -- the so-called "kiddie tax."
Small-business owners can do what Jim Lunt did: hire their own children, even young ones in a family owned business. The wages are a deductible business expense, and for this year children can earn up to the standard deduction of $4,750 before owing tax -- or up to $7,750 if they put the difference into an I.R.A. If the business is a sole proprietorship or partnership of the child's parents, children under 18 are exempt from Social Security and Medicare taxes and children under 21 from federal unemployment tax. Experts caution that the children must perform real work for reasonable wages, and parents should be prepared to show documentation to prove it.
For parents with children already in college, tax breaks include the Hope Scholarship credit -- up to $1,500 a student for the first two years of college. There is also the Lifetime Learning credit -- up to $1,000 a household for higher education expenses; it will double this year. But full credits are available only to single filers with modified adjusted gross income below $41,000 and to couples with less than $82,000. The phase-out limits are $51,000 for singles and $102,000 for couples.
If parents whose income is too high forgo claiming the children as dependents, financial advisers note, the students may be able to take the credits on their own returns. If a student would not be not taxed enough to offset the credit, parents can give an asset to the child who can sell it to generate a capital gains tax, Mr. Calvelli said. But he warned parents to make sure that "emancipating" a child did not have side effects like making the child ineligible for the parents' health care coverage.
 OTHER sources of tax-advantaged college funds include home equity loans and student loans, both of which have tax-deductible interest. Early I.R.A. withdrawals can be made without penalty for qualified higher education expenses, but any taxes would still be due. Roth I.R.A.'s are a better option because withdrawals, up to the amount originally contributed, can be made free of tax and penalty.
"As a general rule, people want to save for their own retirement as their No. 1 priority," noted Joseph Hurley, founder and chief executive of Savingforcollege.com, a Web site that compares and evaluates 529 plans. "If you have to, it can be tapped for college. You're not going to get financial aid for retirement, and you might get it for college."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Julie and Michael Stapleton of Penfield, N.Y., a suburb of Rochester, have decided to open Section 529 plans for, from left, Moira, Daniel and Tim. (Kevin Rivoli for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Business; 
Who's Blocking the Xbox? Sony and Its Games

BYLINE:  By MATT RICHTEL 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO 

 BODY:
XBOX, the video game console that Microsoft introduced nearly 14 months ago, is technologically sophisticated and, by many accounts, the best way to play games against competitors over the Internet.
 But the advantages have not translated into the returns Microsoft had hoped for. It has sold nine million Xbox consoles, on the low end of its projections; it continues to lose money on each one it sells; and it remains desperately behind Sony, whose PlayStation 2 is selling at a record pace. Wall Street analysts have mixed opinions about whether Microsoft's early effort has been successful, but they agree that it has a way to go. 
 Avid game players like Brian Green, 26, who spends hours each week on both consoles, have a simple explanation for why Microsoft has yet to make the inroads it sought. "The Xbox is cool," he said, "but the PlayStation is where the games are at." 
That is not good news for Microsoft, because people tend to buy electronics based on the amount of software they can use. Sony learned that lesson two decades ago, when its technically superior Betamax video recorders were swamped by VHS machines that had more tapes available.
Makers of video games are starting to produce more games for Xbox, but the 2-to-1 gap with PlayStation will take some time to close. And while Microsoft, which has more than $40 billion in cash on hand, can afford to be patient, analysts and investors wonder how much time and money it is willing to invest before it starts to turn a profit.
The issue is of no small significance. The market for consoles and video games is worth more than $9 billion a year. Even while losing on selling consoles, Microsoft could still make a lot of money from game makers. They pay the console makers about $10 for each copy of the games they manufacture -- and they made well in excess of 50 million games in the United States last year. Games typically sell at retail for $50.
For now, though, there are only losses for Microsoft. It declines to say how much it loses on each console, but industry analysts estimate the figureat close to $100. Sony, by contrast, does not sell PlayStation 2's below cost.
Part of Microsoft's problem is the ambitious design of Xbox: its chipsets and other electronic components are more expensive than those of the PlayStation. Microsoft has also been unable to realize certain economies of scale because sales have not been as robust as expected.
Joseph Osha, a semiconductor analyst at Merrill Lynch who follows Nvidia, a company that makes the graphics processing chips for the Xbox, said Microsoft had had to "pull back sharply" on its orders. He estimated that Microsoft had 1 million to 1.5 million unsold Xbox chipsets, which are the brains used in Xbox consoles.
Microsoft is too big to have its stock price move significantly on sales of Xbox. But the effect of all that idle Xbox inventory is evident on its profit-and-loss statement. In a recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Microsoft said its home and entertainment segment, which includes the Xbox and television divisions, lost $348 million in its most recent quarter on sales of $1.28 billion. In the period a year earlier, the home and entertainment unit lost $180 million on sales of $833 million.
On a micro level, investors "don't like it because they lose money on every piece of hardware they sell," said Michael P. Wallace, a video game industry analyst at UBS Warburg. But, he added, "on a macro level, they're in the No. 2 spot."
In addition to overtaking Nintendo, which makes the GameCube console, as the second-place console maker, Microsoft has put itself in a position to compete with Sony for years to come, Mr. Wallace said.
When Microsoft introduced the Xbox in January 2001, it promised to put $2 billion into the product -- $500 million in advertising alone. It may well need to spend it all. In 2002, according to UBS Warburg, Sony sold 18.3 million PlayStation 2 consoles, while Microsoft sold 5.2 million Xbox machines and Nintendo sold 4.7 million GameCubes. These figures reflect consoles sold to consumers, not consoles that the manufacturers ship to wholesalers or retailers.
THE good news for Microsoft is that industry experts expect it to widen its lead over Nintendo this year. Electronic Arts, the world's largest game maker, is projecting that in North America in 2003, Sony will sell 9 million to 10 million PlayStation 2's, Microsoft will sell 2.5 million to 3 million Xbox consoles and Nintendo will sell 2 million to 2.5 million machines.
Electronic Arts also projects that Microsoft will beat Nintendo in Europe, the second-biggest market after the United States. Still, Microsoft is particularly struggling in Japan, where it has been virtually shut out of the market, selling a mere 300,000 consoles, according to the company. Throughout all of Asia, Microsoft has sold only 500,000 Xbox consoles, according to UBS Warburg, compared with Sony's sales of 3.67 million PlayStation 2's.
Microsoft officials say they are hampered in Asia because Sony and Nintendo, both Japanese companies, have entrenched positions and great control over distribution and sales channels there. But industry analysts say Microsoft should come up with more than excuses.
"If Xbox has any chance of closing the gap against PlayStation, Microsoft is going to need a better Japanese strategy," said Michael Gartenberg, an analyst at Jupiter Research. He said it needed to have better games and to burrow into the Japanese distribution channel.
Microsoft said it was already making progress on games, introducing in Japan a game called DOA Xtreme Beach Volleyball. The 80,000 games sold out within two days.
Robert J. Bach, a senior vice president for the home and entertainment division, acknowledged that the Xbox was continuing to lose money, but he said that such losses were natural with a new business. A better picture of the situation, he said, is how the company is performing relative to its business plan. "We're doing very well on that basis," he said.
Analysts said Microsoft must also persuade video game makers to produce versions of their products for the Xbox. According to figures provided by Microsoft but compiled by NPD Funworld, an industry research group, there are 458 games available for the PlayStation 2, versus 207 for the Xbox and 168 for the Nintendo GameCube.
Microsoft faces a chicken-and-egg problem: makers of video games won't make versions of their games for a given console unless the machine has a wide installed base, but it is hard to build a base without a lot of games.
Some big game makers have made versions only for the PlayStation 2. Most notable has been Grand Theft Auto, the most popular game the last two years. Microsoft said it is in discussions with the game's maker, Take Two Interactive, to persuade it to produce a version for the Xbox.
Xbox also suffers because video game publishers will sometimes release a PlayStation 2 version of a game first, then deliver an Xbox version months later. That happened last year with Medal of Honor, a top-selling game from Electronic Arts that came out some six months earlier on the PlayStation 2. Jeff Brown, a spokesman for Electronic Arts, said, however, that the company was increasingly releasing games concurrently for the two platforms.
Industry analysts like Mr. Wallace of UBS Warburg said Microsoft needed to find video game makers that would produce hit titles exclusively for its console. 
To bolster its game portfolio, Microsoft has been in discussions to buy Vivendi Universal Games. Microsoft would not comment on the issue.
In the meantime, Microsoft has quietly begun to make inroads with a feature that cuts across individual games: Xbox Live. This is a $50 attachment that lets console owners play games against one another over the Internet. Microsoft, citing figures from NPD Funworld, said it sold 350,000 Xbox Live kits since introducing the service in November. Sony has sold 438,000 of its own online kit, said Microsoft, citing NPD Funworld figures, but Sony has been selling its kit for almost twice as long, since August.
Mr. Bach said that these kinds of numbers showed that Microsoft, by sticking to its plan, could succeed, and he has said so to Microsoft's chairman, Bill Gates, and its chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer. "In the conversations I have with Bill and Steve, they want to know where we are on that plan," he said. "We're on that plan."
The question is whether Brian Green and other gamers are on board, too.

HEADLINE: GRASS-ROOTS BUSINESS; 
From Beehive To Kitchen Table To Mass Production

BYLINE:  By JANE TANNER 

DATELINE: DURHAM, N.C. 

 BODY:
ROXANNE QUIMBY was just looking for a little extra income when she teamed up in 1989 with Burt Shavitz, a local beekeeper, and started a kitchen-table production line to bottle honey and make beeswax candles in rural Maine.
 In 1991, when Ms. Quimby began making beeswax lip balm, sales soared, so she added other personal care products. She called the company Burt's Bees and packaged its ointments and shampoos in distinctive bright yellow tins and bottles. She sold them through a network of natural food stores, and they were even picked up by Bloomingdale's. 
 Within three years, she had outgrown the makeshift factory and moved Burt's Bees to this central North Carolina city, the home of Duke University. Sales reached $43.5 million last year, up 30 percent from 2001. Burt's Bees is among the fastest-growing companies in the natural personal care industry, which itself is expanding rapidly. 
Now Burt's Bees, like the three or four other natural body-care companies that have built sales to more than $30 million, faces the difficult task of moving into the mass market without compromising its commitment to pure ingredients, its employees and the environment.
Sales of body-care products made exclusively or nearly exclusively from natural ingredients rose 10 percent last year, to $4.5 billion, said Patrick Rea, who follows the category for the Nutrition Business Journal.
The niche, which includes creams, soaps and shampoos made with ingredients like rosemary leaf, willow bark extract and comfrey root, captures about 10 percent of overall personal care sales, Mr. Rea said. It has also drawn attention from bigger companies like Tower Records, Books-A-Million and Urban Outfitters.
"Companies like Burt's Bees will come head to head with larger companies in only a few more years," Mr. Rea said. "They can only ignore it for so long."
Paddy Spence, who runs Spins Natural Track, which compiles and analyzes sales data for natural products, said companies like Burt's Bees, Tom's of Maine and Nature's Gate have gained market share quickly as they expanded distribution outside of the traditional, fervent customer base at the nation's 7,000 natural food stores.
Mr. Spence credits Burt's Bees with having the most diverse range of retail outlets. "Roxanne has managed to get the products in all different types of stores," he said. The products are sold in 6,000 outlets, as various as car washes, Nordstrom stores and the L. L. Bean catalog.
Dozens of small companies have piled into the market for natural body-care products, including the W. S. Badger Company, which mixes creams, balms and salves in Gilsum, N.H., and Evergreen Research, a San Diego company that makes skin cream from olive oil produced in the Peloponnesian region of Greece. But only a handful, including Burt's Bees, have sales of at least $30 million.
Burt's Bees churns out 144 products in its automated plant here. Ms. Quimby's original partner, Mr. Shavitz, got out years ago to live contently in a converted turkey coop in Maine. But his bearded face is still featured on cream and ointment tins.
National chains have lined up to sellMs. Quimby's products. Yet her strong views on many topics often clash with conventional business practices. She describes herself as a 1960's radical who was a back-to-the-land homesteader in Maine before becoming an entrepreneur in 1989.
Consider the collapse of talks last month with the Target Corporation, over its requirement to package two Burt's Bees items in a box, to conform to Target's distribution system. Ms. Quimby rejected the idea as wasteful. "We started adding up all these boxes and decided this is too much," she said.
A Target spokesman declined to comment on talks with Burt's Bees, but said the company "keeps an eye on these emerging new-age and health-oriented trends."
Sometimes Ms. Quimby manages to straddle her principles and business ambitions. A few years ago, she agonized over whether to start a cosmetics line. Her business instincts dictated a move into highly profitable beauty products, even though makeup ran counter to her feminist sensibilities. "I thought makeup was a mask," she said.
In the end, Ms. Quimby calmed her worries by featuring regular women instead of models in Burt's Bees advertising and on packaging. A 40-year-old waitress and part-owner of a restaurant in Asheville, N.C., modeled for Burt's Bees tinted moisturizers. One of Ms. Quimby's 24-year-old twin daughters, Hanna, the company's New England territory manager, posed for photographs for Burt's Bees lipstick and other products. Even the scraggly bearded Burt appears on the Web site, incongruously advertising shaving soap and after-shave lotion.
"They have a more human quality," Ms. Quimby, 52, said of her just-folks models. "They are not perfect."
Big companies in the industry, meanwhile, are edging in to capture a share of the demand for natural body products. Some flaunt "natural" and "plant derived" on packaging when all but a speck of the ingredients are synthetic, said Darrin C. Duber-Smith, the strategic marketing director at the Natural Marketing Institute, a research and consulting firm in Harleysville, Pa.
The Food and Drug Administration regulates only the list of ingredients on the back of packages, so companies take liberties with words like "natural" on the front, Mr. Rea of the Nutrition Journal said. " 'Natural' is losing its value with consumers," he said.
Burt's Bees products contain at least 91.6 percent natural ingredients, Ms. Quimby said; most have more than 95 percent. Of companies with more than $30 million in sales, only one, Aubrey Organics of Tampa, Fla., produces 100 percent organic products. The company's shampoo, conditioner and skin creams are blended in small quantities -- 50-gallon batches -- and whisked to stores to avoid down time in warehouses, where they might go bad.
Conventional retailers are realizing that growing numbers of shoppers will pay more for products made with natural ingredients, said Tom Chappell, founder of Tom's of Maine, the maker of natural toothpastes and mouthwash.
"There was one language that we could share with the CVS's and the Hannaford Brothers of the world," Mr. Chappell said, referring to drugstore and supermarket chains in the eastern United States. "They wanted to serve our kind of customer, who is looking for value in what's inside the product, not what it's priced."
Bath and Body Works, a unit of Limited Brands, began carrying Burt's Bees products in 20 stores on a trial basis during the holiday season. Similar market trials are under way at Hannaford Brothers in New England and Publix Super Markets and Winn-Dixie Stores in the South.
IN the mid-1980's, Tom's of Maine was the first maker of natural body-care products to break into the mass market; its products are now sold in 30,000 retail outlets, including Walgreens, Target and Wal-Mart, Mr. Chappell said. In 1968, two years after college, he bailed out of a career in insurance and moved from Philadelphia to rural Kennebunk, Me., where Tom's is based.
Mr. Chappell and Ms. Quimby both say they do not offer volume discounts. Other retailers and a retail consultant say it is hard to imagine that Wal-Mart pays the same per-unit price for a tube of Tom's of Maine toothpaste as a local health food store does, but Mr. Chappell says he does not adjust his prices even for fast payment of invoices. Officials at Wal-Mart declined to comment.
Ms. Quimby says large chains eventually accept the terms "because, at the end of the day, it sells."
In running Burt's Bees, Ms. Quimby keeps costs down and refuses to take on debt. She credits eight years of raising her twins in a rustic cabin in the woods as great discipline for economizing. Until recently, Burt's Bees bought only second-hand equipment, including a giant mixer from a cafeteria at Duke. Every Wednesday, the staff meets to review a spreadsheet that lists every slip-up and its exact dollar cost.
But she insists that containers be made from recycled plastic. Burt's Bees pays a premium of 7 percent to 10 percent to use discarded milk containers in packaging, said Thomas Loeper, president of Tel Pak Inc., one of the company's suppliers. Ms. Quimby said her pretax margins run from 25 percent to 30 percent.
She continues to live in Maine, in a small house in Winter Harbor, a fishing village of 500 people. She flies to Durham every other week and otherwise stays in touch through e-mail.
One day, she said, she expects to find a buyer who will continue to operate the company with the same values. Then, after selling, she said, she will devote herself full time to land conservation.
"It's going to take everything I've learned so far," she said. "It will be a real benefit and not just about wrinkles or shiny hair."

HEADLINE: Faulty Deficit Logic 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Representative Sue Myrick and her Republican Study Committee are not fond of the deficit, but, you report, "they say it plays a useful role in fighting off something they like even less -- government spending" ("Conservatives Now See Deficits as a Tool to Fight Spending," Washington Talk, Feb. 11). 
 Representative Myrick's financial formula is equivalent to a family's carrying heavy credit-card debt as a way of holding down further spending. She must know, as we all do, that it doesn't work. 
To carry the comparison further, this is a family that insists on cutting its own income along the way. The inevitable result is poverty, bankruptcy or, in the case of government, inflation.

DAVID S. WACHSMAN
New York, Feb. 11, 2003

HEADLINE: Your Taxes; 
Breaks for Those in Retirement, or Gaining on It

BYLINE:  By DAN CUFF 

 BODY:
THESE days of economic difficulty may not seem the best time to increase your contributions to retirement plans. Nor may they seem the best time to take money out, although the law requires you to start withdrawing money from tax-deferred accounts after you have reached age 70 1/2.
 The 401(k) retirement plans and individual retirement accounts of many Americans have been battered by the falling stock market, so adding money to them or having to withdraw from a depleted account may be especially painful right now. 
 "I was required to take the minimum distribution" from an account at Merrill Lynch, said Hartley E. Grundstrom of Hampden, Mass., who reached the magic age recently. "Merrill Lynch will give me a check every year whether I want it or not from my seriously depleted I.R.A. account. Big Brother wins again." 
Ouch. But Mr. Grundstrom and others in his boat owe one to Big Brother nevertheless. The Internal Revenue Service issued final regulations on required minimum distributions from retirement plans last April, and now "the bottom line is that you can take less money out," said Nicholas Kaster of CCH Inc., a provider of tax and pension information. The smaller withdrawals mean less taxes to pay and leave more money in the account to grow on a tax-deferred basis.
As for the people who would like to be in Mr. Grundstrom's shoes and have such an account to provide money in their old age, the 2001 tax law increased the amounts they can add to a variety of retirement accounts, beginning last year, and allowed those 50 and over to make additional "catch-up contributions." And if the Bush administration's latest proposals are enacted, they will be able to save even more -- up to $7,500 annually in new Retirement Savings Accounts that would replace I.R.A.'s.
Contribution limits for the proposed Employer Retirement Savings Accounts, which would replace several plans, would be $12,000, rising to $15,000 by 2006; those ceilings are the same as for current 401(k)'s but higher than for some other plans. Employees 50 and over could save an additional $2,000 a year, rising to $5,000 in 2006.
Both types of proposed accounts would work similarly to Roth I.R.A.'s today: after-tax money would go in, but withdrawals after age 58 would be free of tax.
Because of the retreat of defined-benefit pension plans, in which companies pay retirees a set pension each month, employees have to look out for themselves when it comes to retirement savings -- a much harder task now than it was before the financial markets' three-year slide. And Social Security checks are not enough. "If all you have to live on is Social Security, you will be living at the poverty level or below," said Douglas P. Stives, a partner at Curchin & Company in Red Bank, N.J.
Mr. Stives tells his clients that they have no alternative to saving as much as possible in their retirement accounts. "The whole concept of saving for yourself has been woefully ignored," he said.
But after watching their accounts shrink, many savers may be asking, "Why throw good money after bad?"
Because, Mr. Stives said, the money put into the accounts is tax-deferred. "If you're nervous about the market, buy a C.D. or Treasury bills or put it in a money market fund," he said. "At least you are not paying income tax on the money before it goes in."
The stock market, he fears, will not recover for a while because many people, still reeling from recent losses, are reluctant to invest in it again. He predicts that a large number of traditional pension plans at companies may fail, and that the government may not have enough money to bail them out. "What the company promised may not be there," he said.
Indeed, the federal agency that insures company pension plans, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, reported an unexpectedly large $3.6 billion deficit last month, its biggest ever. In contrast, it finished 2001 with a $7.7 billion surplus. The deficit reflects the declining health, particularly in the steel industry, of the many company plans that the government now insures. The agency estimates that these plans owe a total of $300 billion more to current and future retirees than they can afford to pay. 
One saver who plans to take advantage of the new rules is Laurance W. Fader, a violist in the New York City Ballet Orchestra and the New York City Opera Orchestra. He said he believed that would be the best use of his extra cash. "We don't have anything that we really need to spend it on," said Mr. Fader, whose children are grown. "Getting the tax deferral is the best deal."
For this year, as for 2002, individuals can contribute up to $3,000 to either a traditional tax-deferred I.R.A. or a Roth I.R.A. In 2005 through 2007, that becomes $4,000, and in later years, $5,000.
 THERE are other rules. Anyone who does not participate in an employer-sponsored retirement plan like a 401(k) can contribute to a traditional I.R.A., but single people who are in employer-sponsored plans can earn up to $34,000 and joint filers up to $54,000 and still take a full traditional I.R.A. deduction. Partial deductions are allowed for people with a bit more income, but they phase out with $10,000 more in income. (A good explanation of this complex business is found in an article in CCH's online book "Whole Ball of Tax 2003" at cch.com/wbot2003/007retirement.htm.)
For 2003, employees can defer up to $12,000 in 401(k) and similar plans like a 403(b) plan for employees of nonprofit organizations or 457 plans for government employees, with the maximum amount increasing in later years. CCH advises contributing the maximum to one of these accounts before putting money into other retirement accounts. The employer often matches the contribution in a 401(k), and employees can borrow from their accounts. But only employers that amend their plan rules -- they are not required to do so -- will make all the changes available to employees. For example, a company with a 401(k) plan may not want to match the higher contributions now allowed.
As for mandatory withdrawal of money after age 70 1/2, the I.R.S. has made the rules friendlier to taxpayers by adopting a simple and uniform distribution table, replacing the former single and joint life expectancies. The new rules took effect officially on Jan. 1, although I.R.A. holders were allowed to use them in 2002. For a person who is 70 1/2, the rules assume a life expectancy of 27.4 years -- a year longer than was on the tables in 2001. The I.R.S. says that because Americans are living longer, less money can be withdrawn each year so people can live longer on their nest eggs.
Other changes, mostly stemming from the Tax Reconciliation Act of 2001, allow employees of small businesses to participate in simplified employee pension plans known as SEP-IRA's and saving incentive match plans called Simple. But these plans, like 401(k) and similar plans, could be replaced by Employer Retirement Savings Accounts if the administration's proposal becomes law.
People 50 and older are allowed to make additional "catch-up" contributions for most retirement accounts, and lower-income workers may qualify for a tax credit to help them invest more money in them.
Individuals can contribute to Roth I.R.A.'s whether or not they are in an employer-sponsored plan, but there are income limits. A single person's adjusted gross income must be below $95,000, with benefits phasing out completely at $110,000. For married people filing jointly, the figures are $150,000 and $160,000.
Whether Roth I.R.A.'s are superior to traditional I.R.A.'s is a battle for the accountants. Mr. Kaster of CCH says most practitioners favor the Roth, but arguments can be made both ways.
Kenneth G. Rocky of Little Silver, N.J., found a solution through Mr. Stives. Mr. Rocky had a heavy year of medical deductions as guardian for his aging parents. He was able to take more than $100,000 out of his 401(k) plan and roll it over to a regular I.R.A. and then to a Roth, using the medical deductions to offset the taxes he had to pay on the conversion. Withdrawals are not required from a Roth after age 70 1/2, so he will be free to delay them until he needs the money or to leave it for his beneficiaries and not have to pay a single penny of tax on it.

HEADLINE: Economy and Sprawl 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 What is most remarkable in your Feb. 9 news article about the impact of the economic downturn on public attitudes toward protecting open space, and insisting on smart growth rather than sprawl, is how little evidence you found of a backlash. 
 In Habersham County, Ga., the voters this fall elected a slow-growth County Commission. In Erie, Colo., developers spent a fortune trying to unseat Mayor Barbara Connors and failed. In Loudon County, Va., speculators who weren't able to win their case in the court of public opinion are turning to the courts.
While land-use lawyers and real estate interests are, as always, eagerly proclaiming that bad times for Americans are good times for sprawl, the American people appear, quite sensibly, to be insisting that growth be smart, planned and good for them and their families -- not just profitable for speculators.

CARL POPE
Executive Director, Sierra Club
San Francisco, Feb. 11, 2003

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: Anton V. Schutz; 
Burnham Financial Services Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
ANTON V. SCHUTZ, who runs the $90 million Burnham Financial Services fund, has invested nimbly in a sector whose many components respond very differently to the same economic conditions.
 One part of the financial services industry is savings institutions, which have had the wind at their sails despite the weak economy. That is because the Federal Reserve has been lowering interest rates in recent years, reducing their cost of money, Mr. Schutz said. 
 But asset managers, another part of the sector, have been hurt as the stock market has slumped, he said, and many consumer finance companies have suffered because their customers have defaulted on loans.
"You have some haves and some have-nots in one sector," he said.
His fund returned 36.2 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Thursday, placing first among 77 financial services funds tracked by Morningstar Inc. The group returned 5.1 percent a year, on average, during that time, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 15 percent, on average.
The fund returned 12.1 percent in the last 12 months, versus losses of 15.7 percent for its group and 25.7 percent for the index.
Mr. Schutz, 38, is based in Rochester and is president of Mendon Capital Advisors, which runs the fund for Burnham Asset Management in New York. The fund's Class A shares, sold with a 5 percent load, or sales charge, through brokers and financial advisers, are available without a load through fund supermarkets like those operated by Charles Schwab and Fidelity Investments.
To pick the 50 to 70 stocks in the fund, Mr. Schutz starts by evaluating interest rates, earnings, global events and other macroeconomic factors. The overall economy is now very murky, he said.
"It's not easy to see whether the U.S. economy will be recovering soon or falling into an abyss," he said. "Then there's a question about Iraq."
His macro analysis is largely keeping him away from savings institutions, where the easy money has already been made, he said, and pointing him toward life insurers and broker-dealers, which are trading at low prices because of the weak economy.
Next, he reviews company-specific factors. Among life insurers, for example, he reviews the types of products they sell and the companies' own investment portfolios.
In October, he began buying shares of Federated Investors, the asset management company based in Pittsburgh. The stock trades for about 12 times the company's projected 2003 earnings, he said, compared with a multiple of 16 for its group. Mr. Schutz said investors believe that because about one-third of Federated's revenue comes from its money market funds, the company will miss an upturn in the stock market. But the company is introducing more stock mutual funds and managed accounts, he said, and is a good acquisition target.
He paid $25.99, on average, for his shares; they now trade at $24.68.
Another holding is First Niagara Financial, a savings institution based in Lockport, N.Y. The company has an unusually strong balance sheet, Mr. Schutz said; its ratio of equity to assets is 20 percent, versus 8 percent for its competitors. 
First Niagara's management has much commercial banking experience, he said, and its earnings from high-yielding business loans have made it less vulnerable to interest rate shifts. He first bought shares in January 2001, paying $8.16, on average; they now trade at $11.11.
ANOTHER holding is Prudential Financial, the insurer and money manager based in Newark. The company is working to shed Prudential's losing operations and to cut costs, Mr. Schutz said, to increase its return on equity and earnings. In December, Prudential announced its acquisition of the American operations of Skandia; the deal is expected to close by June. Because Skandia has a big business in variable annuities, the move will give Prudential more exposure to a recovery in the capital markets, Mr. Schutz said. 
He bought shares starting in December 2001, paying $30.52, on average. They now trade at $30.72.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Dreary Winterfor British Shares

BYLINE:  By CONRAD DE AENLLE 

DATELINE: LONDON 

 BODY:
THE latest interest-rate cut by the Bank of England surprised the British stock market, but not pleasantly. The move was widely viewed as a good-will gesture to investors whose confidence had evaporated with share values. But the reaction has generally been "thanks, but no thanks."
 After a fleeting gain just after the cut was announced at noon on Feb. 6, the benchmark Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index fell about 2 percent over the rest of the afternoon, and it remains at about that level. 
 With home prices having raced ahead 22 percent last year, economists and professional investors treated the central bank's action, reducing its benchmark rate to a 48-year low of 3.75 percent from 4 percent, as a cure for which there is no known disease.
"The move looks bizarre," said Helen Roberts, a portfolio manager at the London investment firm F&C Management. "Despite weak survey data in the U.K. recently, the housing market remains strong. The move has more to do with the lurch down" in the stock market, she said, than with "an evident sharp slowdown in the economy."
As for the limp response from the stock market, she added: "That is a bad sign."
The market decline was hardly a reversal of fortune. British stocks lost more than any other major market in January. The FTSE-100, which comprises the 100 largest British companies, nearly one-third of which trade on the New York Stock Exchange, fell for 11 consecutive days, the first time that has happened in the 19-year history of the index.
The steep decline has been attributed largely to selling by life insurance companies trying to meet solvency requirements. As share prices fell, the insurers were forced to sell, which drove prices down further, forcing more sales. The drop compelled regulators to suspend enforcement of the rules, and the stock market began to recover. It has gained about 1.2 percent in the first two weeks of February.
The insurance companies "were not selling because they thought the market was expensive; they were selling because they had to," said Sacha Sadan, a manager of British equity funds at Gartmore Investment Management. "The good news about that is it means there's more value out there, and people are stepping in to buy."
The relentless selling last month left British stocks at valuations that, by at least one measure, are close to their cheapest since 1959. That was the last time that the dividend yield on the stock market was as high as the yield on 10-year government bonds, which is about 4.2 percent.
"There are compelling valuation arguments, with 53 percent of the FTSE-100 yielding more than 10-year bonds," said Alan Custis, who runs portfolios of large British stocks for JP Morgan Fleming Asset Management. 
Mr. Custis looks for stocks of companies with "strong cash flow, high sustainable yields and a catalyst for change in the business." The sectors where these criteria are being met best, he said, include banking, construction, health care and oil.
Among the companies he likes is HSBC Holdings, "a very solid bank with strong management" that exploits its scale to make the most of acquisitions, like the deal announced in November to add Household International. Mr. Custis noted that HSBC trades at just 10 times its annual earnings and yields 5.2 percent, good value for "one of the major banks of the world."
Other favorites include Wolseley, a construction company mainly involved in the American plumbing and lumber businesses, and the drug maker AstraZeneca. Wolseley has "huge cash flow" of $:8 billion to $:9 billion a year ($12.9 billion to $14.5 billion) and is "extremely well run and cheap," Mr. Custis said, noting that the company has recorded 25 straight years of earnings growth.
He said AstraZeneca's pipeline of drugs under development "is one of the strongest for any of the major pharmaceutical companies." It plans to begin sales this year of Crestor, which it forecasts to take 20 percent of the $24 billion annual market in cholesterol-lowering drugs.
Mr. Custis recommended two telephone companies, the Vodafone Group and the BT Group, which he called "self-help stories" for the restraint they have shown in cleaning up their balance sheets by paying down debt and selling assets, or at least shunning costly acquisitions. He noted that Vodafone sells at 14 times earnings, "not expensive for the largest mobile telecommunications company in the world."
His preferred oil company is BP, which Mr. Sadan also likes. "At these levels," Mr. Sadan said, "it trades at a huge discount to Exxon." To demonstrate BP's financial strength, he noted that it is buying back $3 billion of stock, and that it announced plans last week to invest $6.75 billion for a 50 percent stake in a new company that will be the third-largest oil producer in Russia. "It's not one or the other, but both," he said.
Two financial stocks that Mr. Sadan holds in his portfolios are the Lloyds TSB Group and the life insurer Prudential P.L.C., which is not connected to Prudential Financial of the United States. "Prudential got very oversold; there was a lot of talk that it was going to go bankrupt" if the stock market continued to fall, he said, "but it's still got great cash flow and it's paying dividends, and if the market has any kind of rally, it will lead it."
Mr. Sadan said he is generally optimistic about British stocks. "There are really good blue-chip stocks at reasonable valuations and with high yields, and you know they're going to pay those yields year in and year out."
