HEADLINE: A Writing Life 

BYLINE:  By JOANNA SMITH RAKOFF; Joanna Smith Rakoff is a contributing editor and columnist at Poets and Writers, a New York magazine.

 BODY:
ON the corkboard above Beth Ann Bauman's desk, a washed-out photograph hangs from a tack: Ms. Bauman, age 2, stares out at the camera, her blue eyes stubborn and searching, her mouth pressed into a resolute line. "I love how stoic I look," she said, fingering the edge of the picture. 
 At 38, Ms. Bauman knows something of stoicism. Like so many young men and women over the years, she came to New York to be a writer. For the past decade, she has lived in a West Village studio and worked as an $11-an-hour temp to support herself, barely. She has watched her friends publish books, have babies, buy houses, get tenure. 
 She has spent her days sending faxes and watering plants for lawyers and junior vice presidents in the city's anonymous office towers, among them the World Trade Center, in a 105th-floor office of Cantor Fitzgerald where she worked until just a few days before the attack of Sept. 11. Her nights were spent at her desk working on draft after draft of stories about funny, smart young women, many of them New Yorkers, in various stages of life. 
Finally, those nights have paid off, and Ms. Bauman has become one of those few writers whose labors see daylight. Next month, her first book, a collection of stories titled "Beautiful Girls," will be published by MacAdam/Cage, a small San Francisco firm. The stories have been nearly 10 years in the making, a period in which Ms. Bauman has sacrificed much of her social and financial life. 
"I'm so consumed by this, by writing stories, by trying to arrive somewhere as a writer," she said. "Sometimes, when I look back on everything, on how long it took me to get where I am, I'm just overwhelmed."
In 1992, Ms. Bauman moved to New York to write a novel, armed with a master of fine arts degree, a dossier of stories praised by her professors and an unwavering belief in her own abilities. "I began temping because I don't have any skills," she explained. "Writing was it." 
A waiflike blonde, Ms. Bauman in person is rather like her stories. She moves around her little apartment like a slender cat, making cups of peppermint tea, laying out plates of cookies that she will not eat (refined sugar rarely passes her lips), pulling well-worn photographs from a carefully organized box of memorabilia. 
Outside her apartment, which is on Seventh Avenue near 14th Street, sirens wail and car horns blare. Ms. Bauman has learned to shut out the racket and enter the world of her stories, which she writes, at times, on her soft brown couch, a pad on her lap, clad in pajamas. 
Writing was the last thing her parents expected, or hoped, she would do to make a living. Ms. Bauman grew up in Metuchen, N.J.; her father was a police officer, her mother a secretary. A writing workshop at Richard Stockton College in southern New Jersey made her want to be a writer. After graduation, she moved back in with her parents, wrote stories and waited on tables. 
The following year, she entered Brooklyn College's master of fine arts program, didn't like it much and transferred to the University of Arizona. In 1992, after three years in Arizona, she moved to New York.
The novelistMary Elsie Robertson, Ms. Bauman's mentor at Arizona, had pegged her as one of the few who would make it. 
"At a place like Arizona, the students are all fairly talented," Ms. Robertson said, "but there was something really special about Beth's work. There was a quirky quality to it. But she also has that absolute persistence. She is a writer, she has to write and she will, at all costs."
Ms. Robertson didn't imagine, however, that it would be more than a dozen years before her prize student published a book. She assumed Ms. Bauman would follow the traditional route for M.F.A. graduates: publish stories in small literary magazines, land an agent, publish stories in glossy magazines, teach, publish a novel. 
Soon after Ms. Bauman's arrival in New York, that's the way things were headed. In 1994, she took a writing workshop with the novelist Michael Cunningham, a few years before "The Hours" propelled him to the upper echelons of literary fame. ("She clearly had a gift," Mr. Cunningham said recently of his student, "and she became a sort of monster of determination.") 
In class she met a Daily News reporter, Karen Avenoso, who was so taken with Ms. Bauman's work that she called an agent friend named Tina Bennett. Ms. Bennett, of Janklow & Nesbit Associates, later became famous for securing a $1 million advance for Malcolm Gladwell's book "The Tipping Point," but at the time she was pretty much of an unknown.
"I was just starting out then," Ms. Bennett recalled. "Karen said: 'There is this writer in the group who is just so much better than the others. You've got to take a look at her stuff.' Beth sent me her stories, and I loved them."
But short story collections are hard sells. Ms. Bennett told Ms. Bauman that she wasn't interested in taking on a collection, but asked her to send along the novel she was working on when it was done. 
"I called it 'the long thing,"' Ms. Bauman said with a laugh. "Tina would call and check in with me. She would say, 'How's that long thing coming?"'
The long thing never came to be. Ms. Bauman went back to writing stories, and author and agent mostly fell out of touch.

Poverty Becomes Less Cute
The years passed. Weeks and months blurred into one another: days at the office, nights at the computer. 
"Everyone around her was getting published first," said Alice Elliott Dark, the author of the much-praised story collection "In the Gloaming" and one of Ms. Bauman's teachers in a writing workshop. "I've seen this happen to a number of really talented people. It's very flukey."
Finally, in the spring of 2000, Ms. Bauman realized that she had enough new, strong stories for a collection. She called Ms. Bennett. "I didn't think she would want to see it," Ms. Bauman said, "but I thought she could put me in touch with someone who might. She surprised me. She said, 'Send it to me."' 
Ms. Bennett liked Ms. Bauman's stories as much as ever, but felt that the collection as a whole needed work: two of the stories didn't fit thematically with the rest. If the author would replace those stories, Ms. Bennett would try to sell the collection. 
Ms. Bauman got to work. Or tried to. At the time, she was working as a temp in the legal department of Cantor Fitzgerald. While she liked the job, temping was becoming increasingly draining, and she was finding it harder to write when she got home at night. She was 36. Poverty and instability no longer held quite the same charm. 
"When you're in your 20's and you're writing short stories, it's cool to be poor," said Sara Eckel, a freelance writer and a close friend of Ms. Bauman's. "Everyone's doing it. Then, at a certain point, people drop out. Because it's not much fun in your 30's. Suddenly your friends can go to dinner in nice restaurants and go skiing in Colorado. And poverty is just not cute anymore."
In the spring of 2001, while Ms. Bauman fretted over the new stories, Ms. Bennett sent Ms. Bauman's older stories to Bill Buford, then the fiction editor of The New Yorker, who was seeking stories for the magazine's debut fiction issue, devoted to previously unpublished writers. The stories made it to the fiercely competitive final rounds of the selection -- the short list of finalists had 200 names -- but didn't survive the final cut. 
Virtually all the chosen writers became superstars overnight, and for Ms. Bauman, the rejection was devastating. "I wanted it so badly," she admitted with a nervous laugh. "I had to really get over my disappointment, my damn disappointment." 
Ms. Bauman was still temping at Cantor Fitzgerald in August 2001 when an easygoing executive offered her a long-term assignment, working as his secretary. Ambivalent about making a commitment to something other than writing, she decided to finish her current assignment. The executive hired a temp to fill in. The temp did a great job. The executive decided to keep her on.
September 2001 found Ms. Bauman nearly broke and panicking. Her assignment at Cantor Fitzgerald was over, and the temp agency had nothing more for her. She e-mailed a friend at Cantor, telling him of her plight. You should come back and work for us, the friend replied. O.K., she said, O.K.
You know the end of this story: A few days later, the friend was killed, along with almost all the other co-workers in Ms. Bauman's department, including the woman who had accepted the job offered to her. 
"If I had taken that job, I would be dead," she said. "I knew so many people who died. I still can't wrap my brain around it. The sheer numbers. I think: Debby and Fred and Fran and Anna and Steve and Monique. The list goes on and on." 
As a long-term temp she found herself at once a part of the Cantor Fitzgerald family and an outsider, albeit one with a singular perspective on her co-workers' lives. 
"As a temp," she said, "you sit at people's desks and you take on their lives for a few days. You see their pictures. Anna had this 2-year-old boy. His photograph was her screen saver. I stared at it all day. I can still see it."

Heading West With $20
Before the Sept. 11 attack, Ms. Bauman had been awarded a fellowship allowing her to spend a month in a house in the tiny Minnesota town of New York Mills, where she could write in complete solitude. On Oct. 1, with $20 to her name, she got on a plane heading west.
The residents of New York Mills proved warm and friendly and interested, of course, in Ms. Bauman's experiences in New York. "She was just so quiet," said Heather Price, who runs the residency program. "My feeling was: 'Don't push, don't pry. This is someone who's very fragile."'
The break provided a brief respite. But back in New York, Ms. Bauman became overwhelmed, faced with the slowly recovering city, the sinking economy and her own tattered finances. In December, she went back to work as a temp at Cantor Fitzgerald in the firm's new office on Park Avenue.
She didn't have much choice. The market for temps had dried up after the attack. She took what she could get. Ms. Bauman avoided writing about Sept. 11 itself; yet her anger and sadness made her determined to finish those last two stories. She began writing and revising intensively, working around the clock. In March 2002, two full years after she had sent Ms. Bennett the collection and eight years after the two were initially in touch, she finished the new stories, titled the collection "Beautiful Girls" and sent them on. 
"Because I'd been working for so long in obscurity, when I sent her those last stories, I wasn't quite sure what she was going to think," Ms. Bauman said. "I wasn't quite sure what I thought. Two days later she called and said, 'We're ready to go."' 
Ms. Bennett sent the manuscript to a slew of editors, thinking that they would love Ms. Bauman's voice as much as she did. Editors did, in fact, love the book, but most were nervous about taking on a short story collection, no matter how charming and accessible. 
Toward the end of April, as the rejections piled up, Ms. Bauman's apartment was burglarized, and she lost, among other things, her laptop. Though she had copies of her stories, she didn't have renter's insurance, or money to replace her stolen belongings. 
The collection, she thought, had to sell soon. 
In August, the stories landed on the desk of Anika Streitfeld, a young editor at MacAdam/Cage, a hip San Francisco publishing house that was started five years ago as a showcase for literary fiction. It has made waves in the publishing world for its unusual business model: rather than handing out massive advances, the company spends up to $40,000 -- an extraordinary sum for a typical first-time author -- on marketing the book. 
The approach seems to work: A disproportionate number of the company's titles have been selected for Barnes & Noble's Discover series, Borders's Original Voices program and the prestigious BookSense 76, a list of recommendations from independent booksellers. Recent MacAdam/Cage hits include Mark Dunn's "Ella Minnow Pea," a lavishly praised epistolary novel, and Katherine Towler's "Snow Island," a novel set in New Hampshire during World War II.
Ms. Streitfeld said she read "Beautiful Girls" the day it arrived, proclaimed the stories "one little miracle after another," called Ms. Bennett and said, "I have to have this book." By Sept. 11, 2002, a deal had been worked out. Ms. Bauman grieved on the 11th, the anniversary of the attack, and celebrated two days later.

Hoping to Beat the Odds
Hundreds of short-story collections are published each year, and most sell, at best, only a few thousand copies. First efforts are especially risky. 
"I love short stories, but debut fiction tends to sell modestly in the first place, and debut collections tend to sell sub-modestly," said Michael Pietsch, publisher of Little Brown & Company. 
"Most readers are looking to settle into something deep," he added. "Usually what you -- the publisher, that is -- are selling is a story. You're persuading people that they're going to be drawn into this deep, complex narrative, in which they'll meet new and interesting chracters. It's much harder to do that when you're describing 12 discreet stories."
MacAdam/Cage is hoping that Ms. Bauman will beat the odds and that her book will appeal to the women who gobbled up "The Girls' Guide to Hunting and Fishing," Melissa Bank's best-selling stories about a wisecracking young woman seeking love in the West Village. Ms. Bauman received only a modest $3,000 advance. But her publisher is planning a first printing of 16,000 copies of the book, whose cover features a slightly provocative photograph showing the legs of a young woman clad in slouchy, knee-high stockings. Sigrid Estrada, a star in the author-photograph firmament, took Ms. Bauman's picture. 
"We're putting more behind this book than any other book that we've ever published," said David Poindexter, MacAdam/Cage's publisher. "We're going to do anything and everything that makes any sense at all, short of standing on a street corner and screaming its praises."
Early response has been encouraging. Barnes & Noble placed a large order; women's magazines are calling about excerpts, and places like Barnes & Noble and the KGB Bar, the hip writers' outpost on East Fourth Street, have booked Ms. Bauman to read. The first advance review, from Kirkus Reviews, compared Ms. Bauman to Mary Robison and Grace Paley, calling "Beautiful Girls" a "powerful start." 
Most of the stories are about women 25 and under, slowly awakening to the world around them. In "Wash, Rinse, Spin," based loosely on the death of Ms. Bauman's father, a Manhattan lawyer makes daily treks from her pointless "no-job job" at an anonymous Midtown corporation to the New Jersey hospital where her father is dying of cancer, never quite finding the time to do her laundry. "Wildlife of America" follows an aging hipster who leaves her life in New York to "rehabilitate" at her sister's and brother-in-law's house in a suburban town, where she rides a bike, dates a local criminal and, ultimately, realizes she has to return to Manhattan, to her real life. 
"All of the characters are waiting for something," Ms. Bauman said. "They're all waiting for their lives to unfurl."
Which is, of course, exactly what she has been doing all these years.
"I have," she agreed eagerly. "I have been waiting, feeling trapped by my circumstances -- the day job, never having enough time to write, wanting something larger and more comfortable, a better life. Maybe not a better life, but just wanting to arrive somewhere."

EXCERPT
Village Girl
I either slept 12 to 14 hours a night or couldn't keep still. I couldn't bear to be in my apartment on Cherry Lane. I couldn't bear to sleep in my bed. I wrestled with the ancient two-ton sofa bed in my living room and finally managed to open it, but it had a powerful defective spring and sprang shut like a venus flytrap, capturing me in the mattress. I shimmied out, but every muscle in my body hurt for days.
I called in sick to work and bought stacks of magazines. I limped to Washington Square Park, furiously flipping pages but unable to concentrate. A pigeon flew up into my face, and I swatted it in the head with a copy of The Economist. I railed at Patty and Dean late at night, alone in my apartment. I handled the whole thing terribly; of course, terrible was my only option. Initially, I had our friend's sympathy but after a while I lost their company. Around the holidays a few friends told me I was a drag to be around. They told me I had to get over it already. "Easy for you to say," I spewed, feeling my words roil with something rank and foamy. "No one's saying its easy," they'd counter. Couldn't they see I'd been thrown to the ground and didn't know how to get up?
 "From Wildlife of America"

HEADLINE: The World: A Nation Unbuilt; 
Where Did All That Money in Bosnia Go?

BYLINE:  By DANIEL SIMPSON 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina 

 BODY:
AS Western officials descended on Bosnia in 1996 to reconstruct a nation that was almost wiped off the map by its neighbors, the man in charge, Carl Bildt, withdrew $210,000 from a Brussels bank and carried the cash to Sarajevo in his briefcase to get started.
 Since then, billions of dollars have flowed into Bosnia, sustaining so many overlapping international missions that officials are unwilling to guess exactly how much has been spent to rebuild the economy. 
 Leaving aside the cost of stationing tens of thousands of NATO soldiers here over seven years (there are now fewer than than 20,000, perhaps 3,000 of them Americans), as well as humanitarian aid and the resettlement of a million refugees, the answer lies somewhere between an original World Bank target of $5.1 billion and about $15 billion, according to estimates by economists. How much came from Washington is unclear. 
If spent more effectively, critics of international reconstruction strategies argue, this money could have had a greater impact. But so many obstacles to development exist in Bosnia that few sustainable benefits can be seen yet, other than the absence of war and the gradual rebuilding of roads, power plants and other basics.
In the center of Sarajevo, which sustained a 43-month siege by Bosnian Serbs from 1992 to 1995, wartime scars are slowly disappearing, although more gutted homes are noticeable outside the city center.
But reconstruction consists of far more than rebuilding property, particularly in a country of smokestack industries and Communist central planning before its bloody separation from Yugoslavia ruined both of these mainstays of the economy.
Despite the return of many refugees to their prewar homes, Bosnia remains divided along its ethnic fault lines: split into two semi-autonomous halves by the Dayton peace accords, governed at all levels by unwieldy combinations of Muslim, Serb and Croat nationalists, and utterly reliant on international aid and oversight.
Paddy Ashdown, a British politician who last year became the fourth high representative of the international community -- effectively the Western powers' proconsul in Bosnia -- knows that his omnipotent office cannot be dismantled and the country left to fend for itself -- the ultimate goal -- without an overhaul of the economy. But with other missions to support, including the follow-up to a potential invasion of Iraq, international money and patience are running out.
"The whole economic recovery program that we're pushing through now is almost too late," Mr. Ashdown said. "We have three years to convert an aid-dependent economy into an export-driven one."
The strategy sounds straightforward: build a market economy based on the rule of law and privatize state assets to attract foreign investment that can create jobs. But in the words of Joseph Ingram, the World Bank's country director for Bosnia, "This is a tall order."
Having grown frustrated with the intransigence of elected local leaders, international officials now rely heavily on the high representative's powers to impose legislation. But this makes many reforms harder to carry out. Moreover, Bosnia has a heavy debt load and a ballooning trade deficit, making it hard for the government to become creditworthy by the end of the decade -- a target set by the international lending agencies on whom Bosnia now depends. "Unless they can attract new foreign investment at a rate of $250 to $300 million a year, then they're in trouble," Mr. Ingram said.
Retailers from neighboring Croatia and Slovenia have started to move into the Bosnian market. But investors from Western Europe see few incentives.
Given these drawbacks, many in Bosnia wonder what happened to all the money that poured in from countries eager to make amends for not intervening earlier to stop a war that claimed more than 200,000 lives.
"A lot of time and money has been wasted here on poorly coordinated projects that have done nothing to increase Bosnia's productive capacity," said Zarko Papic, an economist and prominent critic of international support strategies.
Aid often has its own agenda. Saudi Arabia, for example, has spent more than $500 million on humanitarian and religious projects. According to both Bosnian and foreign officials, the aim is to spread its rigid interpretation of Islam in a land where most Muslims are not conspicuously pious.
Meanwhile, international donors and lenders see no future in reviving rusting industrial works, unless private investors want to buy them. But without an influx of foreign capital, alternative sources of employment are difficult to find -- other than in what is euphemistically termed "the gray economy," which covers everything from smuggling electronics to not declaring employees to the tax authorities. Little wonder that young people line up outside Western embassies to seek a new life abroad.
There have been a few isolated successes, like an aluminum plant in Mostar that accounts for 25 percent of Bosnia's exports and keeps Mercedes-Benzes supplied with hubcaps. But other state-owned industries have been so neglected they can be sold only for a nominal fee.
HOPING to make inroads into an official unemployment rate of 40 percent, the World Bank and other international organizations are providing small loans to potential entrepreneurs. Yet even these recipients, who number more than 150,000, complain.
"The international community should have invested more in the factories," said Mehida Usanovic, a 46-year-old hair stylist who has taken out three loans, the biggest worth $5,000, to build up her Sarajevo salon. "Who's going to visit the hairdresser if they can't pay their utility bills?"
Mark Wheeler, who monitors Bosnia for the International Crisis Group, said: "We're really on the knife-edge now as to whether this experiment in putting a country back together will succeed or fail. As long as half the people here live in poverty, it will be difficult to deal with all the most intractable problems."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Reconstruction in Bosnia has many faces: a Sarajevo mosque (top) is an example of many Saudi-financed projects, including religious schools and hospitals, depicted in a model (bottom). At center, traffic has replaced sniper fire in central Sarajevo. (Photographs by Kael Alford for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
Some Dot-Coms Have Youth on Their Side

BYLINE:  By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN 

 BODY:
The Internet bubble has burst, but survivors like eBay, Amazon and Yahoo may have reason to smile for years. They have done what retailers usually only dream of: build a base of young customers. 
 According to comScore Media Metrix, more than eight million Internet users ages 12 to 17 visited Yahoo sites in December, putting Yahoo in striking distance of AOL, the struggling Internet giant. Four million went to Google and 2.8 million to eBay. Even among children ages 2 to 11, those sites had heavy traffic, with a surprising 1.6 million going to eBay. 
Teenage Research Unlimited has found that teenagers use the Internet primarily for e-mail, but some also screen-shop. Thirty-nine percent like to look for things to buy and 12 percent have made purchases online. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

HEADLINE: Alta Journal; 
Mayor's Passion Is Protecting a Utah Ski Haven

BYLINE:  By KATE ZERNIKE 

DATELINE: ALTA, Utah 

 BODY:
He kept out the Olympics. He has kept out the snowboarders. And now, as the world seems increasingly full of uncertainty and doom, well, then, Bill Levitt will do his best to keep that out, too.
 Mr. Levitt is the mayor of this tiny silver-mining-turned-ski town -- population 400, skiing population 5,000 -- which sits above Salt Lake City at the highest reaches of Little Cottonwood Canyon, between the snowy pate of Mount Baldy and the imposing crag of Mount Superior. 
 Down in the Salt Lake Valley, the streets are named for their distance and direction from the Mormon temple. Up here, it is the Brooklyn-born Mr. Levitt who sets the compass. Because of its elevation, Alta gets more and fluffier snow than any ski area in the country, an average annual snowfall of 500 inches -- making it a developer's dream.
But in 33 years in office, Mr. Levitt has been the guiding force in keeping Alta Alta.
There are no high-rises here, almost no condominiums. What bars there are, in the town's five simple lodges, close by 11 p.m.; the only noise that bursts through the starry night comes from the guns shooting down avalanches. When the lift lines get too long, the operators slow the chairs to keep the 2,200 acres of slopes from becoming crowded. 
If all this runs counter to the economics of a faltering ski industry, it has earned Mr. Levitt the loyalty of local residents and generations of skiers who return here each year. And lately, Mr. Levitt, has been arguing that preserving Alta is not just about making a nice place to ski. It is about saving the kind of refuge the world could use more of.
"Lets face it, the world is going to hell in a handbasket," Mr. Levitt says, beginning a pitch he has made often over the last year or so. "So I tell people who come here: 'You're an Alta person now. When the world gets to be too much, you feel like you have to flee, you just come to the bottom of the canyon. We'll have your name on a list, we'll close the gates, we'll point the avalanche guns down the canyon. The bad guys won't come up after you.' "
He is joking, of course. But it is a sign of the national mood that people who hear this believe him, or want to. "My first thought was, 'Can our kids come?' " said Gayle Rothschild from Washington, D.C. With war looming, even Mr. Levitt says, "These days, I'm beginning to wonder if I'm prophetic."
And he is not joking about the importance of preserving this place of natural wonder, where Nabokov, according to legend, once discovered a kind of butterfly, where you can still spot ermine popping up from the snow.
Comfortably clear of the age to qualify for a free season ski pass, which is 80, Mr. Levitt has long defended Alta againstdevelopers. But he began thinking about the challenge differently after the attacks of Sept. 11, when a regular guest from New York called to cancel her annual Thanksgiving stay at the Alta Lodge, which Mr. Levitt bought in 1959. She had watched the towers collapse and could not bear to travel. She called again, two days before the holiday, to change her mind. Arriving, she pushed through the door of the lodge and collapsed in tears.
"That's when I started to realize, this is a haven for people," Mr. Levitt said. "It's important for people to have a place like this. This atmosphere gives people a chance to breathe -- in their minds, not just in their chests. When you wake up in the morning and there's fresh snow and the sun's coming out over Superior, it just makes you want to go out and yip," he said. "How many times in life can you do that?"
Alta opened as a ski resort in 1939. Mr. Levitt discovered it in 1954, in the way so many other people have. Someone suggested that if he really wanted to ski, he ski out west, and if he wanted to ski out west, the best snow was in Alta. "Where?" he asked, then, finding out, fell in love. 
Early in his tenure as mayor, he persuaded voters to reject a sewer system, which would have opened the town to development. Most decisions have followed in that vein: in the last decade, the town has cut the number of buses bringing skiers from the valley below to 5 a day from 50; it prohibited snowboarding, making Alta one of a handful of ski resorts that does so.
Before Salt Lake City could use tax money to bid for the 2002 Olympics, Mr. Levitt pushed for a state referendum that ensured no events would be held in this canyon or its twin, Big Cottonwood. And Alta has remained relatively affordable -- $40 a day compared with almost double that at other resorts.
"Alta is a a real local treasure, and there would be a huge uproar if it ever moved toward the classic ski resort development by out-of-staters," said Mayor Rocky Anderson of Salt Lake City. "We've got enough of those kind of places."
Mr. Levitt, too, has become something of a local treasure, blessed by Mormon leaders, honored by government associations across the state. He insists he will not step down until he spots a successor as passionate as he is about preserving Alta. "Everyone needs to escape from something, sometime," he said. "Even I do. But I'm a mayor."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bill Levitt, mayor of Alta, Utah, for 33 years, has held the world at bay. (Ruth Fremson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Economic Crisis and Vocal Opposition Test Bolivia's President 

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 15 

 BODY:
President Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada of Bolivia had to be smuggled out of the bullet-riddled presidential palace in an ambulance earlier this week as gunshots whizzed across the main square while looters rampaged through the historic heart of the administrative capital, La Paz. 
 By week's end, Mr. Sanchez de Lozada went on television to announce that "calm and peace have been restored throughout our national territory." 
 But as Bolivians took stock of the violence that gripped their nation -- 29 people killed, with government ministries and downtown businesses looted and set on fire in the main city, whose name means peace -- the fact is that Mr. Sanchez de Lozada's six-month-old presidency is in clear danger of collapse. 
The president's decision to withdraw plans for a tax increase, the ostensible spark for violent protests, only served to bring a tenuous peace. The roots of the problem, a deepening economic crisis and an energetic opposition, remain ever-present and signal more trouble for a leader who won the presidency with only 22.5 percent of the vote.
"He's got a big, serious problem," said Eduardo Gamarra, an expert on Bolivia at Miami's Florida International University who recently spoke with the president. "He has four and a half years left in his term. How is he going to last four and a half years?"
Indeed, Mr. Sanchez de Lozada, 72, a former filmmaker and wealthy businessman who is known by the nickname Goni, is standing alone against an array of forces that makes governing nearly impossible.
On the left, he is dealing with the increasingly influential Evo Morales, an Aymara Indian and leader of a coca workers federation, who rails against free-market reforms while pushing for an end of American-backed eradication efforts of Bolivia's coca crops. To his right is the International Monetary Fund, which had called for belt-tightening measures that led Mr. Sanchez de Lozada's government to consider a tax that had little political support.
The president has had little room to maneuver, faced with trying to placate increasingly vocal and influential nationalists while trying to meet difficult requirements leveled on a poor country by international lenders. The situation was made even more combustible by an increasingly violent series of standoffs between the police and coca farmers in recent weeks that have led to several deaths.
Though Bolivia is isolated and poor, with just 8.3 million people, the ramifications are enormous if Mr. Sanchez de Lozada is forced out, because he is not the only president in Latin America facing politically destabilizing streets protests.
"I think this sets a very disturbing precedent," said Michael Shifter, who tracks Latin American politics for the Washington-based Inter-American Dialogue. "It is disturbing that when you have this kind of protest and violence that people can call for a president to step down. I don't think that's very helpful for democracy."
In Bolivia, though, there seems to be little sympathy for Mr. Sanchez de Lozada, who was the architect of the free-market reforms in the 1980's and was president from 1993 to 1997. Many there feel that those reforms, dictated from Washington, brought poverty, not prosperity.
"There has been an accumulation of frustration with the economic model," said Gustavo Luna, a researcher with a labor analysis group in La Paz. "They were left with no choice but to protest."
Meanwhile, Mr. Sanchez de Lozada faced politically difficult decisions after the International Monetary Fund called for the government to lower the country's deficit to 5.5 percent of its $8 billion-a-year gross domestic product from 8.6 percent. After failing to obtain the political support for a gasoline tax, the president then opted for an income tax. That move infuriated Bolivians, particularly the middle class, which is Mr. Sanchez de Lozada's only bloc of solid support.
To make matters worse, the country's police force had started to rebel because the government not only had failed to pay salaries in January, but had ignored demands for a 40 percent pay increase.
It still remains unclear what led to the violence that began Wednesday and rocked the country for two straight days. The government maintains that a conspiracy was at work. Many in Bolivia say it was simply a spontaneous outburst.
What is clear is that the violence, the worst since Bolivia's return to democracy in 1982, could not be contained. That raises questions about how the government could survive another outburst, which could well be brewing.
The president's opponents, including Mr. Morales, are demanding his resignation while some street protesters have resorted to demanding, "resign or die, those are your options."

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
Businesswomen Get Another Advocacy Group

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
THREE years ago, Linda McCabe learned that the two brothers who owned the auto glass company where she worked in Islip planned to dissolve the business. Having worked for others throughout her career, including the Long Island Association, where she marketed a health-insurance program for members, Ms. McCabe decided the time was right to go into business for herself.
 After the glass company closed, she opened a new company in the same location, handling the same work. She named the company American Patriot Glass, and she hired some of her old co-workers. Many customers probably never noticed the difference. Neither did bill collectors and lien holders, Ms. McCabe said, and they were not mollified when she told them she had no business connections to the old owners. 
 "I didn't realize there would be repercussions," she said. "Creditors were calling me, and people coming to me with liens all the time. People called me a carpetbagger. I had a hard time of it at first." 
She said that in hindsight, advice from a seasoned mentor would have prevented this misstep. Like her, other businesswomen have found that there is a shortage of role models and other women to turn to for advice. For this reason, Ms. McCabe was in Mineola last Tuesday for the announcement of the formation of the New York State affiliate of the U.S. Women's Chamber of Commerce. The Long Island chapter will be the first in the state. Ms. McCabe is the president of both the state affiliate and the Long Island chapter.
The state affiliate is the latest expansion of a national organization, which was formed in October 2001 by Margot Dorfman and Terry Williams, the publishers of a women's networking newspaper in Phoenix. The group, which is based in Washington and has eight state chapters, with about 1,500 members, is not connected with the U.S. Chamber of Commerce.
The group seeks to bring successful women togetherand to encourage them to act as mentors to others. The chamber also helps its members to register their businesses as being owned by women, which paves the way for them to participate in certification programs aimed at expanding the number of women and minorities who bid on government and corporate contracts. 
Women's business organizations are nothing new on Long Island, of course. LIWomen.com, a Web site for professionals and entrepreneurs, lists more than a dozen such groups, including the Long Island Women's Agenda, which orchestrates the activities of the various groups to avoid redundancy and scheduling conflicts.
While a number of prominent women have agreed to serve as volunteers on the advisory board formed by Ms. McCabe, so far only three companies, including Ms. McCabe's, have joined as members.
The group's welcome may not be the warmest. "I don't know Linda McCabe, and I know everyone!" said Christine Sheahan, who publishes Networking Magazine from Westhampton Beach. It has about 23,000 subscribers, most of them women. 
Jane Gitlin, a founder of the Long Island Women's Agenda and a longtime advocate on women's issues, said of Ms. McCabe and her new group: "I wish her luck, but I see this as another way of fragmenting the women's market. Do we really need a women's chamber of commerce when we have organizations like the Women's Economic Developers of Long Island, the National Association of Women Business Owners, and the Long Island Center for Business and Professional Women, to name just a few?"
"The organization seems to lack a raison d'etre," said Ms. Gitlin, who published the Women's Business Record, in Greenvale, from 1975 to 1983. "It seems kind of superfluous."
Dana Friedman, the president of Women on the Job, an economic advocacy group in Port Washington, said that the region already had a number of organizations that seemed to address the same issues as the Women's Chamber of Commerce. "My hesitation is that we are already stepping on each other's toes trying to raise money," she said.
Ms. McCabe said that the Women's Chamber of Commerce was not interested in usurping the role of the region's well-established women's groups. "Everybody keeps asking me the same question, 'Why another women's business group?"' she said. "My question is, with all the chambers of commerce and all the business associations and all the women's groups, why are women still lagging behind when it comes to economic power and leadership influence and career advancement?" "We are not in competition with other groups," she added. "We want to bring people together and to leverage opportunities for women. Many members on our advisory board are active in all the other women's groups Ms. Friedman agreed that the issue of economic opportunities for women remains largely unresolved. For her, a particular area of concern is the paucity of women on corporate boards: among Long Island companies, the rate has held steady at about 4 percent for some years, she said. 
"That's very low, comparatively," she said. "At the level of the Fortune 500, the rate is almost 15 percent. In many ways Long Island is behind the times on the corporate level, in terms of awareness of issues that affect women."
"This is a very provincial environment in terms of human-resource policies, diversity and work-life balance," she continued. "That's a big part of the reason women go out and form businesses of their own. And women who are career-focused often leave the local work force and commute to Manhattan, which is far more progressive."
Despite the naysayers, othersbelieve that the Women's Chamber of Commerce will fill a niche. Mindy Ferrentino, the marketing director for Meyer, Suozzi, English & Klein, the Mineola law firm, and a board member of the Long Island Center of Business and Professional Women, said she joined Ms. McCabe's advisory board because the women's chamber serves unmet needs.
"The primary purpose of the Long Island Center for Business and Professional Women is to promote networking," she said. "The chamber is not a networking organization per se. Its function is to help businesswomen by focusing on the big issues, like finance, and becoming a leader in your field."
On a national level, the Women's Chamber of Commerce has focused on bringing in men as members and leaders, and the local affiliates are doing likewise, said Ms. Dorfman, the national group's co-founder and its chief executive.
Douglas Rowe, a partner in Certilman Balin Adler & Hyman,an East Meadow law firm, is a member of the Long Island chapter's advisory board. "I have a wife and two daughters, and any organization that promotes business skills for women is welcome from my perspective," he said. 
Lucy Rosen, a management consultant in Garden City who is also serving on the advisory board, said that Long Island can use a group like the Women's Chamber.
"If another park were being built, I don't think we would say, 'Does Long Island need another park?' said Ms. Rosen, who runs a Web group called Women on the Fast Track. "When a Thai restaurant opens, I don't think we ask if we need another Thai restaurant. If people use the park and go to the restaurant, that proves there is a need. I think there's a need for this group, too."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Margot Dorfman, left, a founder and the chief executive of the U.S. Women's Chamber of Commerce, and Linda McCabe, the president of the chamber's New York State affiliate and Long Island chapter. Their formation was announced last Tuesday. (Phil Marino for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Deals That Were Struck 

BYLINE:  By MAREK FUCHS 

 BODY:
WHEN a company is offered benefits through Westchester County's Industrial Development Agency, public notice is given and a public hearing is held within 30 days. If the benefits are approved, the agency enters into an agreement with the company in which the firm leases the property to be bought to the agency and then the agency leases it back. This process enables sales tax and mortgage tax abatement, and also gives the agency a degree of control. The company signs an agreement to return certain benefits if it moves jobs out of the county during the period of the agreement. 
 County officials said that Texaco returned benefits it had receivedwhen it left Westchester in 2001 after merging with Chevron. 
 Here are some examples of companies and organizations that have worked with the Industrial Development Agency in the last few years, and the deals they have struck: 
Fortunoff was issued $70.95 million in taxable bonds by the agency for the purchase of the former Saks Fifth Avenue site in White Plains and the construction of 260,000 square feet of additional space. In addition, Fortunoff is eligible for up to $3.24 million in tax abatements. 
Fuji, in Mount Pleasant, was offered $540,000 in sales tax abatement over a period of five years. The company had been in Elmsford and was looking for new space in both New Jersey and Westchester. 
Datalan, an information technology company, was the first company to use the agency's small business benefit program, begun in 2001. It can receive $30,000 in sales tax abatement over the next five years.
Heineken USA received $250,000 in state and local sales tax relief for office equipment, furniture and fixtures after taking a new space in White Plains, instead of moving to Connecticut. 
The Masters School, a private school in Dobbs Ferry, was issued $17.65 million in bonds by the agency for construction of a science building, a gymnasium, dormitories and other renovations.
Jacob Burns Film Center in Pleasantville was issued $4.5 million in bonds by the agency when it was created in 2000.

HEADLINE: Multiplication Problem 

BYLINE:  By CARIN RUBENSTEIN 

 BODY:
TO take advantage of every square inch of space, nearly all of the storage closets in the John Jay Middle School in Cross River have been converted to unventilated, windowless classrooms, where teachers disinfect surfaces daily with Lysol, to get rid of germs that have no way out. 
 In Irvington, 486 sixth, seventh and eighth graders are crammed into a middle school that was built in 1912 to hold about 300 students. The hallways are littered with notebooks, papers, broken pencils and backpacks that are too bulky to fit into the school's narrow, outdated lockers. Here, too, closets have been reinvented, and students buy school supplies out of a former storage closet for Spanish books, now a busy office that is 3 feet wide and 20 feet long. 
 And at the fortresslike Yonkers Middle and High School, which is almost as big as Bloomingdale's in White Plains, there is supremely synchronized chaos every 42 minutes, when all 1,900 students change classrooms. It is a process so complex, rehearsed and supervised that an assistant principal compares it to the changing of the guard at Buckingham Palace. 
This is Westchester County's largely unspoken secret: nearly every school district, large and small, well-financed or not, is struggling with the problem of seriously overcrowded schools. Many districts are responding to the crisis with expensive, locally financed construction projects, but the situation has taken on a new urgency since late January, when Gov. George E. Pataki proposed a state budget that would significantly reduce state building aid for schools.
During the last decade, 38 of the 40 Westchester school districts have had double-digit enrollment growth, according to figures collected by the Westchester-Putnam School Boards Association. With the exception of the Greenburgh 7 and Tuckahoe school districts, average enrollment has risen 36 percent during this period, an increase not equaled since the early 1960's, much higher than the 6 percent that Westchester County grew between 1991 and 2001. "Most school districts in Westchester are experiencing overgrowth, growing faster than school facilities can accommodate," said Lloyd Bishop, an educational consultant who has been conducting demographic projections for school districts in the New York metropolitan area for more than 30 years. 
School enrollment is snowballing, he said, because of the baby boomlet of the 1980's, when the largest number of baby boomers began having children, and because Westchester's housing market attracts many families with young children. In addition, since Sept. 11, 2001, a small number of families has moved to Westchester from New York City, Mr. Bishop said.
As more families move to Westchester communities for the good schools, they add even more children to districts already burdened with too many students. In just about every district, where class size is negotiated as part of teacher contracts, more children mean more classrooms. So school boards have raised money to renovate old schools and build new ones, "since the residents are paying big taxes and quality education is the reason they moved there in the first place," Mr. Bishop said.
Indeed, school quality is a top priority for house hunters with families, said P. Gilbert Mercurio, the chief executive officer of the Westchester County Board of Realtors. But although real estate agents always provide detailed information about test scores and class size, agents never provide information about overcrowding issues, he said.
Terrie Kaplan, office manager of Prudential Centennial Realty in Scarsdale, agreed that she never discusses school overcrowding with clients. 
"Scarsdale presells itself because of the reputation of the schools, and parents are predisposed to being very happy with it," she said. "In general, people feel that the Scarsdale schools are generally worth the taxes." What happens, though, when overcrowding leads to tax increases?
"There is building and bonding going on, and that has budgetary implications," Mr. Mercurio said.
There is no doubt that Governor Pataki's proposed budget to curtail education spending "will force school districts to raise taxes to meet students' needs," said Assemblyman Adam T. Bradley, a Democrat who represents the 89th District, which includes Katonah-Lewisboro, Harrison, White Plains, New Castle and Mount Kisco. Mr. Bradley, who characterized the proposed budget as "terrible on education," added that it unfairly shifts the taxpaying burden from New York State onto local school districts.
THAT prospect is enough to put rebellious thoughts into the minds of some taxpaying Westchester parents.
Eduardo Macial, 39, a systems manager for I.B.M., moved to Irvington with his wife and two children nine months ago, specifically because he had heard the schools were excellent. Paying more than $1,000 a month in school taxes, Mr. Macial said, "we don't live in a situation where we have endless pockets." If the school district can't figure out how to do more for less money, Mr. Macial said that he would consider moving to Greenwich, Conn. .
Other parents choose to stay put, but to send their children to private schools. "Our school district is getting alittle too overcrowded, making it difficult for children to get the individualized attention they should have," said Diana Harris, 48, an accountant in Goldens Bridge, who sent her 12-year-old daughter to the Harvey School in Katonah. Her 15-year-old son decided to stay in public school. Although the family pays $22,000 a year in taxes to the Katonah-Lewisboro School District, Mrs. Harris said it is worth the additional $18,000 in tuition for her daughter to learn in classes of no more than 10 or 12 children.
When school districts become overcrowded, communities usually vote to build and pay for new schools.
All 38 of Westchester's fast-growing school districts have applied recently for permits from New York State to renovate schools, to add portable classrooms or to begin new construction, based on records of the New York State Education Department's Office of Facility Planning. During the 2000-2001 fiscal year, local school districts spent $161.3 million on 76 such projects in Westchester County; in 2001-2002, the schools spent $291 million on 71 projects, according to Chuck Szuberla, coordinator of school operations in the New York State Education Department. School building projects hit a peak statewide last year, because New York State's building incentives were highest between 1998 and 2000, Mr. Szuberla said. Because it takes several years for approvals and contracts to be completed, there is a lag of several years, he explained.
The initiative to build in Irvington began five years ago, said Vincent T. Beni at the time he was named superintendent. Two years ago, Irvington residents passed a $47 million bond, and received 18 percent, or about $8.4 million, in building aid from New York State to be paid over 30 years. Although Irvington's first building aid payment from New York State is scheduled to begin this June, administrators expressed some doubt about whether it will happen, despite the fact that voter approval of the bond was based on the promise of state aid.
The district had no choice but to build, however.
"I've never seen school growth happen so fast, it's very scary," Mr. Beni said. The district's elementary school, which was originally built to hold 650 students, now houses 1,000 in kindergarten through fifth grade, making it the largest elementary school in the county, he said. Until the new middle school and the addition to the high school are completed -- expected to be this September -- elementary school students are being taught in nine portable classrooms. 
"Under Governor Pataki's proposal, there will be less money set aside for school construction," Mr. Szuberla acknowledged; he added, however, that the decrease should apply only to bonds approved by voters after July 1, 2003. 
Those with years of experience dealing with New York State education budgets remain skeptical about such promises. 
"I don't have a great deal of confidence in the state as a whole," said James Reese, the assistant superintendent for business in Irvington.
Although Briarcliff Manor voters approved a $36.8 million bond almost four years ago, Frances Wills, the schools superintendent, said that she expects to receive a cut of at least $300,000 a year in state aid for building costs, based on the proposed cutbacks. New York State had promised the Briarcliff Manor school district 40 percent building aid, or about $22 million, for the nearly completed additions to the elementary school and the middle/high school. But next year's school budget, she said, will probably have to allow for steep cuts by the state. 
Other districts, not as far ahead of the building curve, have received voter approval for a bond referendum, but have not yet begun construction. For them, building aid promised by the state is even more doubtful. 
In the Katonah-Lewisboro Union Free School District, for instance, voters passed a $29 million bond last June, on a second try, after being guaranteed 24 percent of the cost by the state. The plan assumes that the state will subsidize the district for about $7 million to expand the high school and the middle school, a project scheduled to begin this summer.
"There is limited money available for state aid for school construction projects, even those already approved by the public," said Robert Lichtenfeld, schools superintendent of Katonah-Lewisboro. "Our school district had a reputation as the hidden gem of Westchester County," he said of the 53-square-mile district. But even with all that open space and horse country splendor, the schools are bursting at the seams: Enrollment has grown 45 percent over the past 10 years, to 4,120 students.
That is why Gail Bergman teaches eight children in what used to be a storage closet for cleaning equipment. The room, which has no windows, has several fans "to get the air circulating, and we get some air if we leave our door open to the classroom next door," Mrs. Bergman said. Still, she said, "I'd rather have windows, because you need some air flow to perk things up." 
Because the Katonah-Lewisboro district approved a $44 million bond in 1995 to expand the schools, voters were distressed to find themselves asked to pay off yet another major loan only seven years later. The issue became so divisive that an attempt in February 2001 to pass a $50 million bond failed dramatically.
"People with grown children were quite angry, because they already pay a lot of money in taxes," said Mady Wengrover, 45, a Goldens Bridge mother of three who was a member of a school-sponsored bond-approval committee for the second bond attempt. "It took a lot of persuasion to make them see how desperately we need the extra space," she said.
IN the Scarsdale Union Free School District, which has grown 25 percent during the last decade, residents were faced with two large bond issues over a two-year period. In 1998, voters passed a bond for $18 million to build additions to several elementary schools, and in 2000, they passed another, for $59 million, to renovate the middle school and high school. At that time, the state promised the Scarsdale schools 24 percent, or $13.9 million in building aid over 20 years.
The new construction in Scarsdale, which is expected to be completed by fall of 2004, was essential, because "the front edge of the enrollment wave hit ninth grade this year, and we expect it to build over the next seven or eight years," said Dr. Michael V. McGill, the schools superintendent. But officials there said that they are uncertain about how much, if any, of the promised aid from the state will materialize.
There is no similar problem in the Rye City School District, because the superintendent did not include a provision for state aid on the $22 million bond issue passed last October.
"We did not count on any state aid, and we built in a reduction in aid to our budget for next year," said Edward J. Shine, the schools superintendent.
Most school districts in Westchester, however, do not have the luxury of dismissing the possibility of state aid. A few, like the Yonkers City School District and the Union Free School District of the Tarrytowns, have only now begun to consider the need for new construction. Such districts may have missed the best economic and political moment to reap state aid, said Paul Abramson, president of Stanton Leggett and Associates, an educational consulting firm in Mamaroneck. 
"New York State offered an extra 10 percent in building aid when Governor Pataki was campaigning to be re-elected," Mr. Abramson said. "But he doesn't have to run now, so this is the year our education governor is going to cut back on education." .
As a result, some school superintendents are reluctant to request community financing for school construction.
"Our schools have large hallways and are very, very crowded," said Angelo Petrone, interim superintendent in Yonkers, who noted that the average class size there is 28 or 29 children. The Yonkers school district has grown 39 percent over the last decade, and overcrowding has become a problem in many of its 42 schools.
Ideally, Mr. Petrone would build a new high school by next September, he said. But asking the city for a bond issue now is bad timing, he said. So the dream of a new school is on hold.
In Tarrytown, though, potential state cutbacks are not yet a deterrent.
"Right now, we're a month or two away from adopting a master plan to renovate and expand all of our school facilities," said Howard W. Smith, superintendent of the Public Schools of the Tarrytowns. This November, he will put a bond proposition up for a referendum, although he wouldn't estimate how much money the district will need.
Mr. Smith hopes that the state will provide aid for at least 17 percent of the cost of the new project, but even that will be "a far cry from large aid ratios in the past," he said. As an interim measure, the high school is switching to block scheduling next fall, and many students will take extended 90-minute classes, to accommodate increasing enrollment.
Ultimately, some of Westchester's school districts "are going to get left behind a bit further, because they don't have the political clout and they don't have the wealth," to build new schools, Mr. Abramson said. "This is not education, this is politics." 

How Tax Bills Vary
The amounts of school taxes that homeowners in Westchester County pay can vary considerably, depending on the assessed value of their homes, and most important, where they live. 
In Scarsdale, for example, the average annual school tax for a homeowner is about $12,600. But it ranges from a low of $3,700 to a high of about $83,700 a year, according to Nanette Albanese, the village assessor. 
In Bronxville, where school enrollment has increased 43 percent in the last decade, school taxes average about $16,700, but range from about $1,170 to $20,1000, according to Robert Fels, the village treasurer. 
Residents of Rye pay school taxes of $8,945 on average. But school taxesrange from a $3,350 to $40,200 a year, according to Robert Walsh, the assistant schools superintendent for the Rye City School District . 
I In the town of Ossining, the average school tax is $4,200, according to Gloria Fried, receiver of taxes for the town, but the tax ranges from $2,400 for newly built moderate-income housing to $97,800 a year for a 97-acre estate. CARIN RUBENSTEIN

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
The Art of the Lure

BYLINE:  By MAREK FUCHS 

 BODY:
WHEN a company is considering a move to Westchester, the county's Industrial Development Agency will likely be deployed. Agency officials sit down with company officials, possibly the power company and others and hammer out financial packages designed to induce companies to relocate jobs here. The inducements can amount to any combination of millions of dollars in tax breaks, deals on energy, loans at low rates, help in applying for grants, good deals on public transportation for workers, bond financing and sales tax abatement on equipment. 
 Two weeks ago, the county offered the New York Life Insurance Company incentives worth $1.7 million to move 1,000 workers into the county. Last week, the company signed a tentative agreement to buy the 383,000-square-foot Mount Pleasant Executive Center in Mount Pleasant. 
 The list of companies that have received help from the Industrial Development Agency reads likes a who's who of big, medium and small local corporate residents, as well as nonprofit organizations. It includes Morgan Stanley, Allied Irish Bank, Heineken USA, the Pepsi Bottling Group, the Jacob Burns Film Center, the Winward School and Purchase College. The agency works to keep companies in the county too, working out deals that offer incentives for companies that are thinking of moving to stay put. 
The seven-member agency, based in the County Office Building in White Plains, is a county-sponsored public benefit corporation that was created by the State Legislature in 1977, and officials say it has been in high gear lately. They credit its fast pace of incentive-giving for the county's low unemployment rate. Not so long ago, they point out, the county was overly reliant on several large corporations, like I.B.M. and Texaco. 
"The I.D.A. has been very aggressive and the incentives have been a tremendous factor in turning around the economy," said County Executive Andrew J. Spano, referring to Westchester's low unemployment rate. "We've maximized benefits for a lot of companies with sales tax breaks for equipment, energy savings and help with bonds. It has created more jobs locally."
Deals like those with New York Life and Morgan Stanley, which, with agency help, recently agreed to buy the former Texaco world headquarters in Harrison and move 2,000 jobs there "have been the events," said the agency's executive director, Theresa G. Waivada, "but we also do a lot with smaller companies that bring in 50 to 100 jobs." 
But in an age of constricted budgets and high residential property taxes, critics complain that the process of offering incentives to business is wasteful and biased toward the powerful. "Some call it economic development," said State Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky. "It's also called a handout." 
Mr. Brodsky added that incentives, the effects of which were impossible to measure, usually go to the richest and most powerful companies, those with the clout to demand it. "It's corporate socialism at a time when we are begrudging a welfare mother adequate care," he said. 
Mr. Brodsky is also critical of what he sees as the arms-race nature of such inducements. Westchester has an industrial development agency, but so do most localities. "These incentives pit city against city, state against state and region against region," he said. "It's geographic blackmail, and no one has the courage to stop the cycle." 
But Mr. Spano waves away such criticism. "Critics say it's corporate welfare," he said, "but we get jobs out of it." 
When the county attracts batches of new workers, said Mrs. Waivada, the benefits are immeasurable. "Think of all that shopping, the lunches, right down to the newspapers they buy," she said. "They are always paying sales tax, which is distributed to the municipalities and schools." She also pointed to the benefit of increased local job opportunities for working parents, who might prefer working closer to home than in New York City and also observed that the housing market stands to gain when a portion of the workers transferred to Westchester look for houses nearby. 
Mrs. Waivada said that when an office building sits vacant, its tax assessment goes down, meaning residents ultimately have to pay more, a thought echoed by Kevin Barry, a computer network consultant who lives in Somers. "When an I.B.M. and Texaco leave, my taxes go way up," he said. Nevertheless, Mr. Barry added, "it all has to be done carefully," so as not to be wasteful. 
Mrs. Waivada said that almost all the companies the county loses are ones that merge or are acquired, as in the cases of Texaco and Prodigy. 
Not all companies look to the county when they are considering a move. When the Entergy Corporation was considering buying the Indian Point nuclear plant, "there was discussion of going to the I.D.A. as a mechanism to set up tax agreements," said Jim Steets, a company spokesman. But the company instead went straight to the municipalities and school districts to cut deals, which entailed larger tax payments upfront that would dwindle as time went on. "We came in and, of course, had to figure out what to do about taxes," Mr. Steets said. "There are a lot of ways to do it, but it mostly boils down to negotiating what your taxes should be." 
"In the end this is all about competition," said Lawrence J. White, a professor of economics at the Stern School of Business at New York University. "States are in competition with each other, cities are in competition with each other and counties are in competition with each other. Is it worth it to pay a dolloar to have a big company stay? Yes. Is it worth it paying $10 billion? Probably not. Somewhere between $1 and $1 billion is the answer, so you better have smart officials."
But is all this competition beneficial? That is totally dependent on the deal that is cut, Mr. White said. Those done to attract sports teams, for example, have not worked. "Sports teams are not tourist magnets," Mr. White said, "so they attract revenue but just at the expense of the local movie theater or local restaurant. It's like robbing Peter to pay Paul." 
Plenty of other deals are a net gain, he added, bringing in jobs and filling the streets with workers who throw off many times the cash the government offered up front.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
A New Yankee Remembers a Legend

BYLINE:  By TYLER KEPNER

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 15 

 BODY:
When Roger Clemens leaves the Yankee Stadium bullpen after warming up before a start, it is part of his ritual to rub Babe Ruth's plaque for good luck. Clemens and Ruth have much in common -- as former Red Sox, after all -- but Ruth died years before Clemens was born.
 One new Yankee does not have to imagine a man on a monument. Chris Hammond was a friend of Joe DiMaggio's, which might say a lot about Hammond. DiMaggio, the Hall of Famer and one of five Yankees with a monument in his honor, was famously reclusive and guarded. 
 Hammond, who replaces Mike Stanton as the Yankees' primary left-handed reliever, was able to break through. When Hammond pitched for the Florida Marlins, he volunteered at the Joe DiMaggio Children's Hospital in Hollywood, Fla. He impressed DiMaggio with his unassuming, regular-guy manner, and the two became friends. 
"When I walk into a room, I don't make it known that I play baseball," Hammond said. "I'm quiet. I think he kind of liked that. I don't know -- I didn't do anything to make him dislike me."
Before he met DiMaggio on a visit to the hospital, Hammond had been warned to be careful around him. But a mutual friend introduced them, and DiMaggio warmed to Hammond instantly. Hammond and his wife, Lynne, spoke easily with DiMaggio, "just like we were friends, not like I was asking him a thousand questions," he said.
Hammond pitched for the Marlins from 1993 to 1996 and again in 1998, the year before DiMaggio's death. The two had gone to dinners, and Hammond has a keepsake of their relationship. On a signed photo of the two of them, DiMaggio thanked Hammond for their time together.
Now Hammond is playing for DiMaggio's team, the latest stop in a baseball career that seemed finished a few years ago. He thought about the connection before signing his two-year, $4.8 million deal.
"I think it'll mean a lot more once the season starts, when I can get out there and see the things that he's done and the plaques," Hammond said.
The Yankees gave Hammond that chance based on what their scouts saw last season, when he turned in one of the most spectacular seasons ever by a reliever. Pitching for the Atlanta Braves, Hammond did not allow a run after June 28. In 63 games over all, he went 7-2 with an 0.95 earned run average. He became just the third pitcher since 1900 to have a sub-1.00 E.R.A. while pitching at least 70 innings.
The Yankees evaluated several relievers for Stanton's spot, including the former Met Mark Guthrie and Stanton himself. They presented the pitchers with the same offer, which Guthrie and Stanton turned down. Hammond accepted.
"We liked all three, and it kind of came down to an economic deal," said Mark Newman, the Yankees' vice president who was instrumental in the signing. "Of course, this guy had the best year of all three."
It was a dream season for Hammond, 37, especially considering what preceded it: a year in the minors and two full years, 1999 and 2000, out of baseball.
Hammond had undergone elbow surgery in 1997, when he pitched for Boston, and with his velocity waning, he struggled the next season. When the Marlins sent him to Class AAA, Hammond took the rest of the year off to be with his wife, who was pregnant.
Another baby came the next year, and Hammond decided that was it for baseball. He retired to his 220-acre farm in Wedowee, Ala., the Southpaw Ranch, and enjoyed life.
"At some point, you feel you've had all you want, and he kind of reached that point: he'd had all he wanted," said Sammy Dunn, Hammond's coach at Vestavia Hills high school in Birmingham, Ala. "He had started a family, and the baseball life had just gotten old. He'd made enough money to have a good life, not an elaborate one.
"When he came back, everybody thought it was for money. It wasn't about that. He just missed it so much, and he told me he wanted his kids to see him play."
It was like something from the movie "The Rookie." Hammond went two years without picking up a baseball before starting to throw in the fall of 2000. He had stuffed all his old gear in a box in his attic, and his three children -- all born since 1996 -- had no memories of his career. When Cleveland signed him to a minor league deal in March 2001, their lives changed.
"I've been at home with them their whole lives," Hammond said. "They're like, 'What are you doing, Dad? Where are you going?' "
Hammond was going places. He split the year between Buffalo and Richmond -- in the Braves' system -- and struck out more than one hitter an inning despite a fastball that never touched 90 miles an hour. The reason was simple: Hammond has a killer changeup.
Hammond has thrown the pitch since he was 10. It got him to the majors with Cincinnati in 1990, and brought him back a decade later.
"Very few pitchers really want to throw the changeup," Hammond said. "I was talking to John Rocker a few years ago about it: 'If I were you, I would sit down and that's all I'd do in the off-season, work on my changeup.' And he goes, 'I can't. If I'm going to get beat, I don't want to get beat on my changeup.' "
Hammond was incredulous at that logic. For him, the changeup is a devastating weapon, evaluated at a score of 80 -- the highest possible -- by the Yankee scouts. 
"It has different action on it," Newman said. "He has great arm speed and command of it. The funny term people use for it is the 'Bugs Bunny change,' because it's like it stops in midair. It's so good he throws it to left-handers and right-handers."
Hammond held right-handers to a .206 average last year, and left-handers were more helpless, batting .174. He delivers his changeup awkwardly, stomping hard on the mound with his right foot and then releasing it. The harder he stomps, the more he is concentrating. 
"It looks funny," Newman said, "but more importantly, hitters think it looks funny."
The Yankees' bullpen is stuffed with hard throwers -- Mariano Rivera, Steve Karsay, Antonio Osuna -- and Hammond gives them a different look. As it is with all newcomers, he must prove he can handle the pressure of being a Yankee. But wherever he is, Hammond said, he will always be nervous. 
"I get nervous every game, no matter where we're at," he said. "If you don't get nervous, if you don't get butterflies, you shouldn't pitch. If you're not waiting for that phone to ring, you might as well retire."
Hammond retired once, but it did not take. When the call comes for him this season, he will exit toward the Yankee Stadium field through Monument Park. If Hammond is superstitious, he can always call on an old friend for good luck.

INSIDE PITCH
Reliever STEVE KARSAY, who had back surgery in November, threw off a mound for the first time on Saturday and felt no stiffness. He said he was not concerned about being ready for opening day. "The way my body feels now, no," Karsay said. . . . If JOSE CONTRERAS seems ahead of the other pitchers, he has a reason. "I've been throwing for three months," he said through an interpreter. "I'm ready for games right now." Contreras, a Cuban defector, has an unusual style of warming up. Before throwing his fastball, slider and splitter, he practices each with a softball and a weighted baseball. Throwing with a softball, Contreras said, makes a baseball feel smaller. Throwing with the heavy ball -- which weighs 12 ounces, more than twice the weight of a regular baseball -- makes it feel lighter. But catchers must beware. "If that ball hits their shin, it'll break their bone," he said.
