HEADLINE: Fees, as Surely as Taxes, Will Rob the State of Jobs, Critics of Pataki Budget Say 

BYLINE:  By AL BAKER 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 15 

 BODY:
In a letter accompanying the budget plan he released last month, Gov. George E. Pataki upheld the importance of jobs and vowed his proposal "preserves promised tax cuts and avoids job-killing tax increases," so that businesses will stay in New York and flourish.
 But after reading the fine print, some lobbyists, lawmakers and labor and business leaders said they have found a contradiction: the budget is less business friendly than it may first appear. 
 While the governor has avoided calling for across-the-board corporate or income tax increases, he does propose $1.4 billion in new fees and surcharges that would hit the insurance and health care industries hard, and affect other businesses like tire sales and nuclear power. Advocates for those industries, and some lawmakers, said it would raise the cost of doing business here, perhaps resulting in job loss or even the flight of businesses from the state. 
The complaints are part of the negotiation process that goes on after a governor's budget is introduced and the Legislature is about to put its stamp on the annual spending plan. But the fees are the biggest boost of new revenue in a budget proposed to close a cumulative $11.5 billion gap.
A large chunk, or about $400 million worth, are levied on the insurance industry, with the governor proposing, among other things, a $52 million to $117 million increase in surcharges on policies for auto insurers; a $35 million increase in assessments on state insurers to pay for an increase in the state's Insurance Department budget, and millions more in increases on the surcharges that health plans must pay.
"Despite his facile rhetoric condemning job-killing taxes, the governor's budget adds over $400 million in taxes, assessments, fees and mandates on insurers of all types," said Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis, a Democrat from Manhattan who is the insurance committee chairman. "As sure as night follows day, insurers will pass these new costs on to consumers."
Mr. Pataki's proposed menu of surcharges also includes a $400,000 increase in the annual fee paid by nuclear plant operators; that is estimated to raise $2.4 million for the state. Another proposal would add a $2.25 fee for every new tire sold, raising $45 million.
As for the health care industry, the budget not only cuts Medicaid, which reimburses providers of medical services for the poor, it also temporarily reinstates charges on hospital revenues, to raise $192.2 million, and on home care services, to raise $17 million. Each would be reduced by 25 percent annually and phased out by 2007, according to the plan.
"I am not going to say to you that it is the budget I would have crafted," said Mark P. Alesse, director of the state chapter of the National Federation of Independent Business, which represents 1.3 million small businesses in New York. "If I had drafted it, it would have cut spending more dramatically and I would not have included anything that would have increased the cost of insurance."
In proposing a $90.8 billion spending plan that slightly shrinks the size of state government, the governor has pledged to fight against efforts to "tax our way back to fiscal health." In a series of speeches made in the week before the budget was released last month, he repeatedly said that raising taxes to balance the state's books would cause businesses to flee New York. In fact, he vowed to cut taxes further to attract businesses.
The governor's goal, said past and current advisers, is to create a fiscal climate in New York that allows business to flourish, thus pulling the state from the economic doldrums that created the budget gap. The actions Mr. Pataki is proposing for the next fiscal year, which begins April 1, will enable the state to spend on programs later, the advisers said.
Further, they said, the governor's budget includes a sweetener for the insurance companies, even as it seeks more money from them. The governor has offered an additional $125 million in tax credits for insurance companies that provide funding for new small companies in the tech and biotech fields, officials said.
But officials in the health care and insurance industries say they are the economic engines of the state, accounting for some one million jobs in the state's work tforce of eight million, according to the latest statistics available from the state's Labor Department. Driving up their costs will further depress the economy by forcing them to lay off workers and pass costs on to consumers, they argue.
For the health care industry, the combined impact of increased fees and $500 million in Medicaid cuts would have a devastating economic impact, industry representatives said.
"It is safe to say that these cuts would close hospitals," said Kenneth E. Raske, the president of the Greater New York Hospital Association.
Craig M. Burridge, the executive director of the Pharmacists Society of the State of New York, said that the budget cuts would cause 1,500 independent pharmacies to close and prompt the loss of 12,600 jobs in the field, mostly in New York City.
An analysis by aides to Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver found that the cuts to Medicaid would lead to the loss of 38,000 jobs overall in health care.
"The budget is not business friendly in the context of the health care industry, which is the largest industry in the state, in terms of jobs," Mr. Raske said.
"I think that the governor is totally sincere in his mind about the need to grow jobs," he said. But, he added, the government funding formulas for health care are so complicated that the impact of Mr. Pataki's budget proposals is more severe. 
Some in the insurance industry are withholding their criticism, hoping to negotiate a deal with the governor and Legislature to spare the industry hundreds of millions of dollars in new fees.
Still, Thomas E. Workman, the president of the Life Insurance Council of New York, a nonprofit trade association, said he was perplexed by the budget.
"We really do believe it was not thought through to fully understand how it would impact us, especially the companies based here in New York," he said. 
"Some of our larger members are household words or household names," he said. "They are gems for this state and we want to foster their success; we want to encourage their success, not unintentionally impair their success." He added: "I have tried not to say that we are going to pick up our marbles and go away. That is not what you say when you are looking for relief or some more reasonable proposal."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: INSIDE BASEBALL; 
A Fountain of Youth Between the Lines

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
The first week of last month was eventful for Major League Baseball's seniors class. On the same day, David Cone and Edgar Martinez turned 40. Within the next few days, Jeff Fassero and Norm Charlton joined them.
 When Cone celebrated his baseball-significant birthday, he had no idea he would be in spring training. He is certainly not alone. In fact, he and his birthday mates are not close to being the oldest players in the major leagues. 
 That distinction belongs to Jesse Orosco, who was six months away from his 30th birthday when he struck out Marty Barrett for the last out of the 1986 World Series. Sixteen years later, he is still striking out hitters (22 in 27 innings last season). 
Orosco, a left-hander, is 45 but will turn 46 as a member of the San Diego Padres bullpen when the coming season is 3 weeks old. The next-oldest player under contract is named Franco, but is his first name John or Julio?
John, the Mets' relief pitcher, is 42. Julio, who is back with the Atlanta Braves after batting .284 in 125 games last season, is 41 or 44, depending on which book you believe. Players, especially those from the Dominican Republic, have been known to make themselves younger before they begin playing professionally, but Julio Franco seems to have made himself younger after he began playing in the majors.
The Philadelphia Phillies' 1982 media guide lists Franco's birth date as Aug. 23, 1958. He was traded to Cleveland after that season, his first, and when the 1983 season began, the Indians' guide listed his birth date as Aug. 23, 1961. Just like that, Franco was 3 years younger.
The guides of the teams he has since played for have maintained the younger age, but baseball encyclopedias list him as the older Franco.
Rickey Henderson is 44, but he is also unsigned. Although no one seems inclined to sign him, he has been unemployed before and has wound up with a job. Mike Morgan, 43, also continues to unsuccessfully seek employment.
Next on the list of employed seniors are Andres Galarraga and Dan Plesac, who are 41. Galarragawill be in the San Francisco Giants' spring camp with a minor-league contract, but Plesac began his spring training Friday as a Phillies relief pitcher with a $2 million salary.
The Seattle Mariners have three 40-year-olds, two of whom will play critical roles. They retained Jamie Moyer, one of their most effective starting pitchers, with a three-year, $15.5 million contract, and Martinez, their most valuable hitter, with a one-year deal that will pay him $4 million in salary and possibly another $4 million in bonuses.
They also brought back Norm Charlton, a left-handed reliever, with a minor-league contract.
The Yankees' Roger Clemens, who turned 40 last August, then signed a $10.1 million contract, needs 7 victories to become a 300-game winner. Cone, who last week signed a minor-league contract with the Mets, will try to win the job as their fifth starter and needs 7 victories for 200. 
Fassero is another of those left-handed relievers who seemingly have lifetime jobs; he will work for St. Louis under a $1.5 million salary.
Randy Hendricks said his 40-year-old client, Chuck Finley, "fully intends to play in 2003," but he has not signed to pitch with anyone. Pat Rooney said his 40-year-old client, Dennis Cook, a longtime reliever, would like to play, but he continues to rehabilitate his left shoulder and work on resolving a family issue. 
"But I'm trying to get a job for Paul Assenmacher," Rooney said, referring to the left-handed reliever, who has not played the last two years. At 42, Assenmacher is almost a youngster compared with Orosco.
Orosco is nearly 5 years older than the man who gave him an $800,000 salary for this year. Why did Kevin Towers do that?
"I hadn't had much of an opportunity to see him pitch when he was with Baltimore," the Padres general manager said, referring to the stretch Orosco did with the Orioles from age 38 through 42. "You look at his age and say no interest, but when he pitched for the Dodgers, I saw why people kept giving him a chance to pitch. He kept getting major league hitters out." 
Towers said he never liked to see Orosco enter a game in the late innings if the Padres had one of their left-handed hitters, Ryan Klesko or Mark Kotsay, coming up.
"It would be difficult to get the big hit we needed," he said.
The key to Orosco's effectiveness, Towers said, is using him correctly. Last year he pitched only 27 innings in 56 games for Los Angeles, meaning he averaged slightly less than one and a half outs each appearance. The last time his innings pitched was a higher number than his games pitched was 1990. 
"He's a true situational lefty you use for a couple left-handers, then get him out of the game," Towers said. "We don't look to use him more than an inning. We'll bring him in to face Shawn Green or Luis Gonzalez or Larry Walker. With his experience and the angle of his pitches and his ability to locate, we felt we needed a guy like that."
His condition has enabled Orosco to continue pitching well into his 40's.
"He's probably in as good shape as guys 10, 15 years younger," Towers said. "He's been in San Diego going through our off-season conditioning program. He was the first to arrive and the last to leave. He's in tremendous shape."

Just Hanging On
David Cone is one of 72 players who have played for both the Mets and the Yankees. If he wins a job with the Mets, he will become the first to play for one of the New York teams, then the other, then go back and play for the first team.
In agreeing to play for $550,000 if he makes the team, Cone is also an example of the players who have earned a lot of money in their careers and now put their egos aside to continue playing. 
Terry Mulholland signed for $500,000, Roberto Hernandez and Wil Cordero for $600,000 each.
Among other players who have agreed to minor-league contracts, Lee Stevens, Pete Harnisch and Pat Mahomes would each have a $400,000 salary; Andres Galarraga, John Valentin, Dave Burba, Mike Fetters, Norm Charlton, Ron Villone, Rickey Bottalico, Mike Jackson, Charles Nagy, Carlos Baerga and Keith Lockhart $500,000 each; Jay Bell and John Vander Wal $550,000 each; James Baldwin $575,000; and Julio Franco, Alex Ochoa and Ruben Sierra $600,000 each.
"There are guys who would walk away, but others love it enough where at this stage in their lives it's not about economics; it's about showing they can still play and enjoy the game and stay young," the agent Arn Tellem said. "They can make decisions based on their desires and what they want to do with their lives."

It's the Pitching, of Course
When teams change managers, it is not always because the next guy can do it better, though that is the explanation given.
For example, commenting last week on his replacement of Jerry Narron with Buck Showalter, the Texas Rangers' owner, Tom Hicks, said, "The culture in the clubhouse for the last three years hasn't been good."
If Hicks was watching closely, he would have seen that it was the Rangers' pitching that was not good. Pitching, not culture, wins games. 
In 2000, the Rangers had the worst pitching staff in the league, but Hicks that off-season spent a lot of his money on Alex Rodriguez, and the next season the Rangers again had the league's worst pitching, this time with an even higher earned run average. The pitching improved to No. 12 last season, but the staff earned run average still exceeded 5.00.
No amount of culture will overcome those performances, no matter who the manager is.
In the clubhouse of an even worse team, the Tampa Bay Devil Rays, Lou Piniella has replaced Hal McRae as manager and, on the first day of spring training promised that the team would play hard and aggressively, as if the Devil Rays had played lethargically under McRae.
McRae was one of the most aggressive, intense players of his era. He did not become soft when he became a manager.
The Devil Rays lost under McRae for the same reason they lost under their first manager, Larry Rothschild: they have been a bad team.
They will continue to be a bad team under Piniella because they have been constructed poorly, changing plans two or three times in their five-year existence. The only difference between Piniella and McRae will be their salaries. The Devil Rays are paying Piniella a lot more to lose than they paid McRae.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jesse Orosco, 45, now with San Diego, is baseball's oldest player. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Doctors Plan Rally Over Malpractice Bills 

BYLINE:  By JANE GORDON 

 BODY:
DR. HENRY E. JACOBS is a desperate man. He is desperate enough to make a house call to the State Capitol on March 26, dressed in his white lab coat, along with hundreds of his colleagues. He is asking for reforms that may reduce his soaring malpractice insurance rates.
 The Connecticut State Medical Society is calling the event its "White Coat Rally," the first of various moves that will put doctors in a place they have long struggled to avoid: the spotlight. But now the spotlight has begun to look like just the thing they need. 
 The event is not a walkout, not a strike, medical society spokesmen throughout the state say, carefully avoiding the terminology used in recent physician work stoppages in West Virginia, New Jersey and Quebec. Indeed, while the doctors gathering in Hartford that day won't be working, other doctors are expected to fill in for them.
The state medical society has held a Doctors' Day for years at the State Capitol, and doctors have trickled in to testify before the General Assembly's committees. The past several years have often seen them sitting before committees on insurance and real estate, public health, and the judiciary, asking for tort reform for medical malpractice. This year, they want more than a chat.
The Fairfield County Medical Association expects about 500 of its doctors to attend. Hartford and New Haven County were still waiting for attendance figures from their doctors. "Your participation in this event is critical," says a message to members on the Web site of the Connecticut State Medical Society
The society said that malpractice insurance premiums have risen 30 percent for obstetricians over the last year, to $125,000 a year; 72 percent for neurologists, to $30,000; 30 percent for neurosurgeons, to $125,000, and 55 percent for family doctors and those in internal medicine, to $21,400.
The society is seeking legislation that caps pain and suffering awards in malpractice lawsuits. The issue has been misrepresented to the public, said Tim Norbeck, the executive director of the medical society. The group does not want limits on economic damages such as lost wages, medical expenses for the present and future, home health care and other costs. "But the pain and suffering part, that has to be capped," Mr. Norbeck said. "The cap will arrest the growth of premiums and stabilize the system. The floor and the ceiling have come together here and doctors are being crushed."
Many hospitals, including Yale-New Haven, Bridgeport and Hartford, said that emergency rooms would be fully staffed on March 26 and that doctors were arranging for coverage in their offices for Doctor's Day. 
"We neither condone nor condemn this action," said Lee Monroe, a spokeswoman at Hartford Hospital. "We are sure patient care will not be disrupted, and the E.R. will be fully staffed."
Bridgeport Hospital and Yale-New Haven were still trying to determine if Doctors' Day would prove a popular event for their doctors. "We are adding extra emergency department staff to handle any possible increase in volume," said John Cappiello of Bridgeport Hospital. "It could be a huge problem, or it might not be a problem at all." 
"We don't expect any impacts on patient care here," said Mark D'Antonio of Yale-New Haven. "But it's a month away."
Physicians such as Dr. Jacobs will look to colleagues to fill their shoes for the day. Dr. Jacobs is what is termed a "solo practitioner" in Hartford, and he is angry over the malpractice insurance issue. He is getting by this year, he said, and he may get by the next, but after that, he isn't so sure. He said many doctors are just quitting.
"These are desperate times and the public is underestimating it," he said. "This will be a major access issue for them. You think middle-class women are going to want to line up at the clinic and take a number and wait all day long? That's not the way our society works.
"I simply cannot afford to stay in practice and not make a living," he said. "Unlike municipal work, there's no pension plan waiting for me at the end of the road. The stock market decimated what savings I had, and nobody's been able to save anything for the past several years because of the economics of medicine."
The average obstetrician earns about $150,000 in Hartford County and works about 80 to 90 hours a week, said Dr. Jacobs, who is president of the Hartford County Medical Association; primary-care physicians earn under $100,000 per year.
"They're working their butts off," he said, "and to me, and I'm not speaking for the medical association here, I think it's pathetic that we passively accept that Michael Jordan makes $60,000 a minute bouncing a ball, and we tell a doctor who's making $100,000 he's a fat cat and he should be hammered down. Michael Jordan will never hold your life in the palm of his hand."
The public doesn't understand the magnitude of the problem, doctors said. But they may soon enough, because the medical society's next move is to broadcast its case on billboards -- an unusual move for publicity-shy doctors and evidence of the level of their alarm. "As doctors, we have always been victims of our own dignity," said Dr. Ed Volpintesta, who has run his family practice for 27 years from the same office at 165 Greenwood Avenue in Bethel. He switched his insurance company this year after his malpractice premiums almost doubled to $14,000.
"We were never trained to be politicians," he said. "But this has been smoldering for a long time, and doctors are desperate. We don't seem to be getting anywhere and our dilemma is, how do we balance that individual patient who obviously deserves compensation with the greater needs of the health-care system?"

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET; 
Nonprofit Groups Face Cuts and Hard Choices

BYLINE:  By YILU ZHAO 

 BODY:
IT has been a winter of mood swings for directors of nonprofit organizations as politicians in the county and state have wrangled over a particularly difficult budget. They have been worried, cautiously optimistic, disappointed and, finally, resigned. They attended countless budget meetings and lobbied hard for their special cases over coffee and lunch. 
 With the county budget passed this week, they say, their causes will suffer --from sheltering abused women to low-income housing development to teaching children about Hudson River ecology. The county government will reduce its aid to all the nonprofit organizations it helps to support by 20 percent. 
 Some of them fear going out of business; some expect to cut existing programs; others talk about laying off staff members. 
The county's original 2003 budget, passed in December with the assumption that the State Legislature would allow a one-cent sales tax increase, was scratched last week because Westchester's delegation in Albany, led by Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, opposed the sales tax proposal. 
The budget that was finally passed raises county property taxes by about 15 percent and sheds an extra $15 million in spending. The cuts made to the nonprofit groups will mean $3 million to $4 million in savings for the county. The total budget for the year is $1.38 billion.
The county will lay off administrators, assistant district attorneys and accountants, according to the budget made public on Tuesday. It will also shrink its travel and equipment accounts and freeze salaries for most county employees. 
"These are extremely difficult choices," said Lois T. Bronz, chairwoman of the county Board of Legislators. 
Now it is the turn of the directors of the nonprofit agencies to make the decisions about what to cut.
Victoria Lutz, who runs the Pace Women's Justice Center, was at a loss. A former law professor who helped build the legal aid organization, Ms. Lutz receives 65 percent of her annual operating budget, around $400,000, from the county. The center, which provides legal assistance to the poor in six languages --English, Spanish, French, Mandarin, Gujarati and Italian --runs a legal hot line for housing, Medicaid and divorce issues and offers emergency assistance around the clock.
"Now what do I cut?" asked Ms. Lutz. "Do we cut one-fifth of the year and stop working in October? Which attorney do I let go? The one speaking Spanish? The one speaking Mandarin?"
The Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, which displays paintings of the Hudson River School and demonstrates the ecology of the river, will decrease the number of its educational programs for schoolchildren and arts programs for the elderly, said Dennis Power, a director there.
My Sister's Place, which provides shelter and legal and psychological counseling to battered women, will need to eliminate three or four front-line workers, said Julie Domonkos, its executive director.
Women's Enterprise Development Center, which provides five 15-week programs on how to start a business for women going off welfare, single mothers and immigrants every year, will reduce classes, said Anne Janiak, its executive director. 
Many were bitter and questioned why nonprofit organizations had been asked to shoulder the deepest cuts at 20 percent, more than any government agency. 
"We are willing to take some cuts and help the county out at this difficult time," said Barbara Finkelstein, executive director of Westchester/Putnam Legal Services, "but not 20 percent."
Ms. Lutz said she thought the county should raise its share of the property tax by one or two more percentage points than the proposed 15 percent. Since the county takes 20 percent of the total property tax, and the median property tax for a single family house in Westchester is slightly more than $8,000, according to 2000 Census figures, one or two more percentage points would mean $16 or $32 a year.
"In tough times, the first items to cut are the luxuries," Ms. Lutz said, "but helping the poor is not a luxury."
Deputy County Executive Larry Schwartz said the county government had already been "cut to the bone." Raising property taxes, on the other hand, is always unpopular and has scuttled political careers.
Andrew J. Spano, the county executive who had ridden to an impressive re-election with 72 percent of the vote partly because of his ability to keep down property tax, had hoped to keep the county property tax constant by raising the sales tax, but Mr. Brodsky, the Democrat who heads the county delegation in the State Assembly, led the opposition against the sales tax bill in Albany. Mr. Spano and Mr. Brodsky have long been political adversaries. 
"We have to give our state delegation the benefit of doubt and believe that they deliberated long and hard" about the sales tax proposal, said Richard G. Wishnie, chairman of the Budget and Appropriations Committee of the county Board of Legislators. "Whatever the reason, we need to put it behind us and continue to work with them."
But Alan Gordon, the deputy director for Housing Actions Council, an organization that helps develop affordable housing, said he did not believe that the deep budget cuts can be easily put behind by the nonprofit groups. 
In times of economic hardship, he said, the number of poor people grows and more people need help. He said he was concerned that the cuts would wipe out entire nonprofit groups. "If they do," he warned, "it would take a tremendous amount of effort to resurrect these groups."

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: DOMESTIC SECURITY; 
Balancing Act For Washington In Terror Alerts

BYLINE:  By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 

 BODY:
Shortly before 7 a.m. and 3 p.m. every day, video cameras and banks of television monitors flicker to life at the White House and in small studios at the F.B.I., the C.I.A., the Pentagon, the Department of Homeland Security and a handful of the other agencies responsible for trying to track down terrorists who might strike on American soil.
 In these twice-daily supersecret videoconferences, begun shortly after the Sept. 11, 2001, terror attacks, the agencies are expected to share their latest intelligence on the whereabouts of terrorists of Al Qaeda and their possible plans for attack. 
 Administration officials say the intelligence about Al Qaeda in the 17 months since the attacks has often been alarming. But this month the evidence became "downright terrifying," a senior law enforcement official said. He said interrogations of captured terrorists and other intelligence suggested an imminent terrorist attack that might even involve chemical, biological or radioactive "dirty bombs" aimed at lightly guarded targets like hotels or apartment buildings. 
Two weeks ago, officials said, the intelligence was so frightening and so specific -- some information pointed to attacks that were timed to coincide with the end of the hajj, the Muslim pilgrimage that concluded Thursday -- that they decided the public had to be notified.
That conclusion set in motion a sequence of events that by late this week had led millions of people to stock up on duct tape and plastic sheeting, with some parents pulling their children out of school and topping off their gas tanks to be ready for a quick evacuation -- an expression of public anxiety not seen since the first days after the Sept. 11 attacks and rarely seen since the height of the cold war.
On Friday, Homeland Security Secretary Tom Ridge tried to calm the public, saying that there was no new intelligence to suggest the need to raise the alarm any further.
But even as he suggested that some people had overreacted -- "We do not want individuals or families to start sealing their doors," he said -- Mr. Ridge insisted that the administration was pleased by how its new color-coded public-warning system was working.
"The federal government, the state and local authorities and the private sector have all taken very important steps to ramp up protective measures to do whatever they can to prevent a terrorist attack," Mr. Ridge said.
The administration's critics, including private security specialists, see the events of the last two weeks very differently, arguing that the government's system for analyzing terrorist threats and sharing the information with the public is not making the public any safer. The critics say it is only frightening them.
"The public is being scared, unnecessarily," said Michael Cherkasky, the president of the private security agency Kroll Inc., who said he had spent much of the this week trying to calm his frightened corporate clients. "These draconian announcements from the government are taking away any perspective that people should have about their lives."
Within the administration, even supporters of what is known as the Homeland Security Advisory System admit that the system is more art than science -- much more -- and that the analysis of often scant intelligence and decisions about whether to alert the public to its contents must often be subject to hunch.
If not handled properly, they concede, the system can lead to unnecessary panic, or to public complacency that could be equally dangerous. And they acknowledge that the much ridiculed color-coded system may have added to the confusion, with few people understanding the difference between a warning level of yellow ("elevated") and orange ("high").
"Every day we see information that suggests that terrorists are going to hit some American target," said a senior law enforcement official. "But is it worth creating panic if the intelligence is sketchy, or if there is no real way for people to protect themselves?"
Officials say that whatever the criticism, the new procedures for analyzing threats and making the information public have brought order to the slapdash process that existed in the first days after the Sept. 11 attacks, when the administration issued a series of vague terror alerts without offering the public any substantive guidance about how to respond, apart from a repeated call for "vigilance."
The decision to raise the public's alarm this month can be traced to the discussions held in the twice-daily intelligence video conferences in the first days of February, when intelligence analysts reported a sudden burst of evidence that Al Qaeda was nearing an attack.
George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence, testified to Congress this week that the intelligence was "the most specific we have seen" since Sept. 11. He pointed to "plots that could include the use of a radiological dispersal device, as well as poisons and chemicals."
Administration officials said that by Feb. 6, the evidence had grownso alarming that it was the subject of an urgent White House meeting that afternoon of the No. 2 officials from most of the nation's intelligence and law enforcement agencies.
Those officials urged that there be a special meeting the next day of the Homeland Security Council, including Vice President Dick Cheney, Mr. Ridge, Mr. Tenet and Attorney General John Ashcroft, to decide how to notify the public.
The council, which was established six days after the attacks as a domestic counterpart to the National Security Council, met the next morning at 9, with Mr. Cheney included by video conference from outside the White House.
Officials said the conversation in the White House situation room, a vaultlike suite of wood-paneled offices beneath the West Wing that effectively serves as a war room, was straightforward. "It wasn't a brief meeting, but the principals were pretty unanimous on their feeling," said an administration official.
After the meeting, Mr. Ashcroft and Mr. Ridge walked to the Oval Office to recommend to the president that the national alert level be raised from "elevated" to "high," a move that would lead to a significant tightening of security precautions across the federal government. Officials say Mr. Bush quickly agreed.
The alert level had been raised only once before, for two weeks last year around the first anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks.
Administration officials said one element of the discussions on Feb. 7 was the impact the alert would have on industries that would also be expected to step up security. Many companies have complained that, especially in the midst of a difficult economy, it is expensive to fortify themselves against a hidden enemy.
Within hours, Mr. Ridge had organized a conference call with 66 chief executives. Aides say they were urged to step up security in the lobbies of their buildings, to limit access to uninvited visitors, and to monitor ventilation systems.
Mr. Ridge and Mr. Ashcroft went before television cameras at 12:30 p.m. to notify the public. "We are not recommending that events be canceled or travel or other plans be changed," Mr. Ridge said. "But we do recommend that individuals and families in the days ahead take some time to prepare for an emergency."

HEADLINE: Plum Island Nears A Crossroads 

BYLINE:  By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
PEOPLE on the North Fork have long been ambivalent about the Plum Island Animal Disease Center, the high-security Agriculture Department laboratory one and a half miles off Orient Point that is closed to all but its 200 employees and the occasional invited guest.
 Elected officials and local residents are quick to point out that the island laboratory, now nearly 50 years old, has become a fixture and a source of steady jobs on the front lines of protecting domestic herds worth billions to the national economy. "Plum Island provides jobs for a lot of people out here and it has been part of the scenery for as long as I can remember," said Linton Duell, the owner of the Orient Country Store, who described himself as "one of those people who feels it is important for our national defense." 
 David Kapell, the mayor of Greenport, said jobs at the island were precisely the kind needed to retain working families who risked being priced off the North Fork. 
Yet the proximity of the laboratory, where scientists do research on some of the most virulent and highly infectious animal diseases in the world, also gnaws at some residents and second-home owners who worry about accidents and wish the laboratory would just go away.Now it appears their wish could come true. A senior federal official asserted last week that Plum Island "is now on track to be closed within five years" and reported that the lab's animal disease research would be transferred to more welcoming locations elsewhere, possibly at an Agriculture Department laboratory in Ames, Iowa.
Government officials have also said that when the Department of Homeland Security takes over Plum Island in June, the work there could be expanded to research infectious agents that could be used against the country's civilian population. The senior federal official, who insisted that he not be identified, reported that until new laboratories come online, Plum Island would fill a Department of Homeland Security need for a Biosafety Level 3 laboratory for bioterrorism research. The official said that Homeland Security "will want to expand the menu of diseases" studied at the laboratory to include "potential biological weapons agents like anthrax, plague and tularemia -- but not smallpox." The official said that for the immediate future only Plum Island had "the available Biosafety Level 3 space to fill this gap in national security, which is why the president decided to transfer this facility from the U.S.D.A. to the Department of Homeland Security."
The official speculated that "the patriotic citizens of New York and Connecticut will support solutions to national security needs for all Americans, but in return demand that D.H.S. immediately resolve many longstanding and troubling issues at the facility."
The issues involve a series of recent incidents including power losses, a lengthy labor strike leading to the use of replacement workers in key positions and the growing perception among elected officials and some residents that the government is skimping on laboratory security.
The official stressed that he had no knowledge of any official decision on the future of Plum Island, but rather was concerned because of the evidence he has seen to date.
If the official's information is an accurate reflection of Bush administration intentions, safety concerns would be likely to grow on Long Island and Connecticut, which is eight miles from the laboratory. For the more immediate area on the North Fork, it would mean potentially greater risk in the short term followed by the loss of the laboratory and its jobs within five years.
"It's a disaster if we lose Plum Island, a real disaster," Mr. Kapell said. Alluding to the strikers on the picket line, he added: "It means that people like my neighbors who are spending the winter in that horrible tent alongside the Main Road in Orient are going to be obsolete on the North Fork. Those jobs on Plum Island are a lifeline for future opportunities for working families to live on the North Fork."
The Southold Town supervisor, Joshua Horton, also said keeping the lab was vital. "It provides a lot of stimulus to the local economy," he said. "There is a broad understanding in Southold of the cutting-edge research that takes place on Plum Island. It has vast implications locally, nationally and globally, and I think people recognize that."
But the possibility that the Department of Homeland Security would use the laboratory for research on bioterrorism agents brought pause. "Patriotism is great, but if you feel you have become a bull's-eye at some point common sense takes over," said Joseph L. Townsend, the owner of an insurance company in Greenport. "It's sortof a vulnerable spot." 
The disclosures about Plum Island came just as local concern about safety and security at the laboratory was at a peak, fueled by two electrical outages in December that many here believe are a result of the bitter six-month strike by 76 laboratory workers who are members of the International Union of Operating Engineers. 
The strikers, many of them local residents, have charged that LB&B Associates, a Maryland-based company that holds a maintenance contract at the laboratory, has brought in replacement workers who are unqualified, raising the risk of serious accidents.
They have received powerful backing from Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has agreed with them that LB&B had treated them unfairly in negotiations and expressed bewilderment that the Agriculture Department has allowed the strike to continue. The department has said the issue is between the contractor and the union. 
Last Sunday, the depth of local concern was evident when more than 500 residents filled the auditorium of the Mattituck-Cutchogue High School for a public forum on Plum Island convened by Mrs. Clinton and the East End's new congressman, Timothy Bishop.
Mr. Bishop, a Southampton Democrat, was loudly applauded when he said that "as citizens of this community we have a right to be satisfied that the island is operated at a level of safety appropriate for the work that goes on there."
Neither Mrs. Clinton nor Mr. Bishop mentioned a possible future closing of the laboratory, but both 
said they expect that a new mission for the Plum Island laboratory is likely once it is transferred to the Department of Homeland Security. Mrs. Clinton said they were meeting resistance in trying to learn the details. Mrs. Clinton said it was unusual that Plum Island was the only Agriculture Department laboratory to be shifted to Homeland Security. "It strikes me that this is a facility that some in the government may have other plans for, and we will do everything we can to prevent that," she told reporters after the meeting. The transfer decision, she said, "certainly leads back to the White House."
In the public forum, she said she had originally believed that the Agriculture Department would "continue to control the research and the Department of Homeland Security would basically protect the facility."
"Now we learn through the administration's budget that the U.S.D.A. will control only half the research funds, which means that the Department of Homeland Security will have a significant amount of control over the direction of the work done at Plum Island," she said.
In a remark that drew sustained applause, Mrs. Clinton then added, "There may be a reason why, given the security challenges we face, we have to change the kind of research and the level of biohazard associated with that research that is done at Plum Island. But that is not a decision that should be made in secret. That is not a decision at should be made without fully informing the community that is involved with the future of the island." 
She also suggested that the return of the strikers to their jobs was important for safety now and in the near future. 
"These are highly trained people who have done an important job for a long time," Mrs. Clinton said. "If we believe what we hear coming out of Washington about a higher threat level and increased chatter about potential targets, why would we not want to have the very best on the front lines?"
She blasted LB&B for not sending a representative to the meeting and said the company and the Agriculture Department had been unresponsive. 
Edward Brandon, an LB&B vice president, said Mrs. Clinton had no basis for assuming that the replacement workers were unqualified. "She hasn't interviewed any of these employees," he said. "How can she make such statements? It's pretty obvious she is running for president in 2004 and she is looking for the union vote and will say anything in the world to get it."
Mr. Brandon said the company had a contractual obligation at Plum Island that left no recourse but to hire replacement workers when union members walked off the job on Aug. 13. The replacement workers, he said, were "people equal to or better qualified than the people who were there before."
The strikers adamantly disagree. "You have people out there who have no experience running the place," said Ronald Grilli, a striking maintenance worker from Greenport. "When the generators didn't work, they put duct tape on the animal rooms. Are you kidding me? These are supposed to be airtight doors. What good is duct tape?"
Asked why workers were not able to start three emergency generators during a three-hour power interruption on Dec. 15, Mr. Brandon seemed to imply that the equipment was the problem. "I don't want to get into that because it is our customer's equipment," he said.
At the Sunday forum, volunteer fire department officials pointed out those strikers who served as firefighting volunteers at Plum Island had not been replaced. Edward Hanus Jr., the chief of the Mattituck volunteer fire department, said five departments on the North Fork had passed resolutions not to respond to fires at Plum Island. "We don't know what's there," Mr. Hanus said. He said volunteers had no training in fighting a fire at the high-security laboratory. "As for an evacuation plan, there is none," he added.
David Huxsoll, the laboratory director, defended the laboratory's firefighting capability. "We are adding more volunteers all the time," he said. "We are doing our best." 
Paul Connor III, the chief executive officer of Eastern Long Island Hospital in Greenport, said the hospital would be relied on to treat people in the event of an accident at the island but had received no money for emergency preparedness. He said communicating with laboratory officials was difficult. "It's hard to get their attention," he said.
Mr. Bishop said he would try to arrange a meeting between local fire and health officials and Plum Island officials to develop emergency response plans.
In a letter dated Feb. 11 to Tom Ridge, the Secretary of Homeland Security, Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Bishop asked for a meeting to discuss "the safety and security of the facility as well as the ability of the surrounding communities to respond to an emergency situation." 
"This situation needs immediate attention, even before ownership of the Plum Island Animal Disease Center is transferred to the Department of Homeland Security, to ensure the safety and security of the facility, the surrounding community, agriculture, and this country at large," the letter said.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: THE SCENE -- Berlin; 
New German Unity At Old Dividing Line

BYLINE:  NYT 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Feb. 15 

 BODY:
There are few more powerful symbols of German unity than the Brandenburg Gate, at the meeting point of east and west Berlin. It was here in 1989 that Germans celebrated the tearing down of the Berlin Wall. It was also here, after Sept. 11, that Germans gathered to show solidarity with the United States. 
 On this cold afternoon, however, the monument stood for German unity of a different kind, as hundreds of thousands of people peacefully marched here to protest the likelihood of an American-led war in Iraq. 
 "Old Europe" peace stickers and antiwar balloons distributed by the organizers set the general tone. Many marchers also displayed their viewpoints in homemade signs written on cardboard or spray-painted on cloth. "No War for Oil," was one popular slogan. "Warmonger Go Home!" read another, displaying a picture of President Bush. 
Henrik Buchhorn, 20, a student who traveled seven hours by bus with his classmates to take part in the rally, said he was here to protest the war, not the United States. "I'm not anti-American," he said. "I'm against the way the Bush administration has handled Iraq." 
Starting around midday, the protesters formed two giant processions from separate staging areas in east and west Berlin. The marchers gradually approached the Brandenburg Gate from opposite directions and converged in the early afternoon. 
The police estimated that about 500,000 people took part in the demonstration -- which would make it the largest in Germany since World War II.
"What happens in the end should be up to the taxpayer," said Freimut Schwarzkopf, 47, an employee of Volkswagen in Braunschweig, who came to march with 25 co-workers. "A war in Iraq is going to cost lives and damage the world economy." 
Participants who were alive during World War II expressed concern about the collateral effects of an attack on Iraq. "I lived through the bombing of Germany as a child," said Gisela Baumann, 68, a retired veterinarian. "America has never experienced that. It's the civilian population, not Saddam, who will suffer." 
Along the Unter den Linden, the avenue leading to the Brandenburg Gate from the east, the atmosphere was calm and police control was sparse. The entrance to the nearby American Embassy, however, was fortified with barricades, a row of police vans and a tank.
Lutz Meyer, 50, a psychologist who grew up in the former East Germany, said he was taking part in his first protest since German reunification. "When we were growing up, we always looked to America as a sign of hope, and I'm very depressed to be demonstrating against the United States," he said. "But there is this arrogance and missionary zeal about Iraq right now that makes no sense to me."

HEADLINE: Your Taxes; 
Shelters Can Turn Perilous

BYLINE:  By CHARLES DELAFUENTE 

 BODY:
WHEN William T. Esrey, the departing chief executive of Sprint, disclosed this month that he was being audited by the Internal Revenue Service for using a tax shelter created by the accounting firm Ernst & Young -- and said he could be ruined financially if the I.R.S. ruled against him -- many other Americans wondered about the tax advice they were getting. 
 The 1990's boom gave many people big and sometimes unexpected gains, prompting some to seek ways to avoid taxes, and perhaps to consider tax shelters. Following are questions and answers about some of the basic issues.

Q. Are tax shelters illegal?

A. Not per se. But different people use the term to mean different things. Broadly speaking, a shelter is anything that lets a taxpayer defer or avoid tax on some amount of current income. Anyone of even modest means can have what might be considered a benign shelter, like a mortgaged house or municipal bonds. The law specifically allows a shelter, in the form of tax credits, for restoring historic structures and investing in low-income housing.
 But "tax shelter" has commonly come to mean an arrangement or procedure that lets very wealthy people avoid tax on all or most of their income. The Internal Revenue Service calls many of the strategies used, especially by the wealthy, "abusive tax shelters."

Q. In what sense is the I.R.S. using the word "abusive"?

A. The I.R.S. says on www.irs.gov, its Web site: "Abusive tax shelters exist solely to reduce taxes unrealistically. Abusive tax shelters are often marketed by promising a larger write-off than the amount invested. These schemes involve transactions with little or no economic foundation." However, it acknowledges, "There is no hard and fast definition of abusive tax shelter arrangements."

Q. How do the arrangements work?

A. Many tax shelters involve an investment that creates deductions or involves transactions intended to shield income from taxation. The seller of an investment or the architect of the plan to move assets around is considered the promoter and usually earns a hefty fee.

Q. What did Ernst & Young promote?

A. One of the strategies involved taking millions of dollars in profits from stock options and delaying taxes for 30 years by passing money to family members.

Q. How could I figure out whether a shelter is abusive?

A. Remember the old adage that if something seems too good to be true, it probably is. A more precise way would be to ask an accountant or a lawyer who specializes in tax issues for an opinion. But no one can offer an ironclad guarantee. And if a promoter insists that the details of the shelter not be shared with advisers, that might well be a red flag.

Q. How would the I.R.S. know if I had a shelter?

A. It might find out in one of several ways. If the shelter created deductions disproportionate to your income, that imbalance might lead to an audit. Very wealthy taxpayers' returns might be scrutinized every year. And because many shelters involve partnerships or other joint enterprises, if one participant is spotted, the I.R.S. might look at anyone else involved.

Q. What happens if someone has followed a promoter's advice and the I.R.S. says the shelter is abusive?

A. If the I.R.S. can prevail, then, in its words, "investors in abusive tax shelters whose returns are examined may be required to pay more tax, plus penalties and interest."

Q. Should I go ahead if I like the idea?

A. The answer depends in part on risk tolerance. Some people like living on the edge. But for someone who is going to lose sleep every night over a questionable shelter, the emotional price is probably too high. A potential investor could seek a ruling in advance from the I.R.S., but many shelter investors fear the answer, and are in part playing the odds that their shelter will escape notice.
For a middle-income taxpayer, the savings might not justify the fees involved in buying a shelter, and sophisticated shelters may require the investment of a significant amount of cash to create the promised deductions.

Q. Will the I.R.S. always prevail?

A. If a taxpayer who is challenged does not agree to pay, and there is enough money at stake, the case could well wind up in court. Many shelters exist on a frontier where three parties -- Congress, which writes the tax laws; the I.R.S.; and some accountants and lawyers, who look for loopholes -- are engaged in a constant border war.

HEADLINE: Your Taxes; 
Too Many Pennies From Heaven?

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
THIS time around, even many Republicans are gasping for breath. As President Bush campaigns for his second big tax-cutting package in two years, he has sent out a barrage of proposals that are more sweeping than anything that even Ronald Reagan might have contemplated.
 First, Mr. Bush came out with an "economic growth package" that, with a projected cost of $674 billion over 10 years, was twice as big as either supporters or opponents had expected. 
 It would speed up rate cuts now scheduled to phase in over several years, accelerate relief from the so-called marriage penalty, send parents a $400 check for each of their children and, at a cost of more than $300 billion over 10 years, eliminate most taxes on stock dividends. 
The plan would help set record budget deficits this year and next, and the administration now projects that instead of enjoying a huge surplus, the nation will have a 10-year budget deficit of $1.3 trillion. 
But that was only the beginning. Mr. Bush's latest budget also calls for new "financial incentives" to promote charitable contributions, solar energy, insurance companies and even the value of leftover food.
More startling, Mr. Bush unveiled a radical plan to revamp retirement plans and expand tax breaks with new Lifetime Savings Accounts and Retirement Savings Accounts. In essence, the new savings accounts would allow many people to shield almost all investment income from taxation -- profits from capital gains, interest on bank deposits and corporate bonds, profits from real estate investment trusts. 
"I can't really take seriously all the proposals he has put out there," said Bruce Bartlett, an ardent believer in supply-side tax cuts who worked in Congress during the Reagan era and later in the first Bush administration. "I can't believe he really wants all of those things right now, so I'm frankly quite curious to see what his real bottom line is."
Taken together, Mr. Bush's proposals would radically transform the way people invest in stocks, think about taxes and save. Critics and supporters alike say this is simply the first installment in a plan to overhaul the tax system from one that taxes income to one that taxes consumption.
But can he get what he wants? Mr. Bush has an exceptionally strong track record in that regard: he won approval for his first round of tax cuts in 2001, keeping Republicans solidly behind him and persuading Democrats to break ranks. Now the Republicans have a slim majority in the Senate and a virtual lock on the House. Even so, lawmakers and political analysts say Mr. Bush is trying to juggle too many explosive issues at once and will face opposition. 
"It doesn't look to me like the complete set of proposals has much chance of enactment," said Rudolph Penner, a former director of the Congressional Budget Office. "If he had put forward a less bold proposal, I think it would have gone through quickly."
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, warned bluntly last week about a trend toward uncontrollable deficits and disparaged as premature the White House arguments that the economy needs a fiscal stimulus.
Beyond the tax cuts, Mr. Bush is also pushing for a radical overhaul of Medicare -- and has run into so much opposition from Congressional Republicans that the White House is struggling to refine the plan.
House Republicans also complain privately that they were not consulted in advance on the new tax plans and say they are skeptical about many of the details.
Representative Bill Thomas of California, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, has emphasized his intention to discuss alternatives to eliminating taxes on most stock dividends, and he has studiously avoided talking about the plan for the new savings accounts. After-tax money would go into the accounts, but earnings on the accounts would be tax-free.
Representative Rob Portman, Republican of Ohio and an architect of other legislation on retirement accounts, was stunned by the administration's proposal and suggested that it might be too much to tackle any time soon.
The Senate could be even tougher. Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, chairman of the Finance Committee, has pledged his support for the president but remains worried about his ability to push the dividend plan through a closely divided Senate. He continues to plead quietly for flexibility from the White House because some moderate Republicans are openly resistant to the plan, while no Democrats have yet shown any willingness to break ranks. In contrast, 12 Senate Democrats supported Mr. Bush's $1.35 trillion tax package in 2001. 
At a hearing last week, Senator Tim Johnson, Democrat of South Dakota, one of those who voted for the tax cuts two years ago, said, "Frankly, I am appalled at the president's recklessness in proposing a massive tax cut for the rich." 
Administration officials are dispatching cabinet officials and others to sell the tax plan nationwide. "We're in a marathon here," said John W. Snow, the Treasury secretary. "The question is who gets across the finish line, not who's ahead in the first mile."
The $674 billion "economic growth package" comprises three main elements: an acceleration of the rate reductions passed in 2001 and scheduled to be phased in over the next several years, the elimination of taxes on most stock dividends, and an expansion of tax breaks for small businesses.
The rate reductions would lower taxes for virtually all taxpayers, but the biggest benefits would flow to the rich. CCH Inc., a provider of tax information and software, estimates that a sample family of four with an adjusted gross income of $100,000 would see its federal tax drop to $9,820 from $12,162, a savings of $2,342. A family of four with an income of $300,000, and with higher levels of deductions, would see its taxes drop by $8,840, to $60,767 from $69,607.
The Bush administration has estimated that 92 million taxpayers would receive an average tax cut of nearly $1,100 in 2003. But average is not the same thing as typical. Millions of taxpayers in the bottom half of income earners pay little or no federal income tax, so many would receive tax cuts of $100 or less. In contrast, people with incomes of more than $1 million a year could save about $90,000.
But many people may not care. Millions of middle-income families would receive more under the Bush plan than under the leading Democratic alternative, which would provide a $300 one-time rebate to every family in the country.
WHEN Mr. Bush's other proposals are added to the "growth package," the costs total more than $1.3 trillion over the next 10 years. And the president has yet to estimate the full impact of what could be the biggest proposal: the overhaul and expansion of tax-favored accounts for retirement and education savings.
Under the proposals, a married couple with two children would be able to set aside up to $45,000 a year for new savings accounts. Their contributions would be taxed, but the investment income would be tax-free. That tax relief would not really hit the Treasury until 10 or 20 years from now, when people withdrew the money, but it could add up to even more than Mr. Bush's proposal to quit taxing corporate dividends.
"The ultimate budget cost could be massive, with much of the damage occurring in the same period that the baby-boomer generation will be retiring in large numbers," said Robert Greenstein, director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal Washington research group. 
Republican Congressional leaders are likely to handle these proposals separately. Representative Thomas, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said he planned to hold hearings on the growth package in March and hoped to get a bill to the House floor in April. But he and others plan to move much more slowly on the retirement and savings proposals. 
Even within the "growth package," Republicans are debating quietly which proposals are crucial and which might well be trimmed.
The biggest single proposal, costing the Treasury about $385 billion over 10 years, would end taxes on most dividends. Proponents of that plan contend that corporate profits are now taxed twice, first at the corporate level and then at the shareholder level. The proposal has won praise from many tax experts, but it is complex and costly; most benefits would flow to 5 percent of income earners. 
The second-biggest change, worth about $260 billion over 10 years, is to accelerate rate reductions and other tax breaks for individuals that are currently scheduled to be phased in through 2010. A third change, worth about $15 billion, would triple the amount of money, $24,000 for 2002, that a small business could deduct as an immediate expense for the purchase of new equipment, as opposed to depreciating it over several years. 
Even enthusiastic Republican tax-cutters are weighing the importance of faster rate cuts versus the dividend proposal.
Martin Anderson, a former policy adviser to President Reagan and an adviser to George W. Bush in his election campaign, said the top priority must be on speeding up individual rate reductions. "Sure, we should reduce the tax on dividends," said Mr. Anderson, now a senior fellow at the Hoover Institute at Stanford. "My first choice by a long fat margin would be to reduce those marginal tax rates, to do it now and make it retroactive."
Senator Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma and chairman of the Budget Committee, suggested a similar willingness to cut back on the dividend proposal. "If we don't get the whole loaf on dividend repeal, we could go for a 50 percent exclusion," Mr. Nickles said. "There are lots of different things you can do." 
The question now is what Mr. Bush is willing to do.

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES; 
There's a Futures Contract for Everything (Even Iraq's Fate)

BYLINE:  By MARK HULBERT; Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a service of CBS MarketWatch. His column on investment strategies appears every other week. E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
FEW people would disagree with the forecast that stocks would drop if war started tomorrow in Iraq. But two Stanford economics professors, Eric Zitzewitz and Justin Wolfers, go further, predicting that the market would drop 5 percent. 
 Academics rarely make precise short-term market predictions. The professors arrived at theirs by using standard econometric analysis and an unusual derivative that trades at www.tradesports.com, based in Dublin. At this Web site, you can bet on whether Duke will win the N.C.A.A. basketball title, whether "Chicago" will win the Oscar for best picture or where the Dow Jones industrials will end 2003. According to John Delaney, the site's chief executive, most of its active users are traders from Wall Street or Chicago futures exchanges. 
 The derivative on which the professors base their unpublished research is indeed unconventional: a futures contract on Saddam Hussein's presidency. The contract, which was trading at $7.50 on Friday, will pay $10 if Mr. Hussein is not Iraq's president on June 30; otherwise it will pay nothing. Because the professors assume that Mr. Hussein won't step down voluntarily, they argue that the contract reflects traders' assessment of the probability of a war resulting in his ouster. The contract's current price suggests that the market assesses this probability as 75 percent between now and midyear.
The professors acknowledge that the contract may seem too bizarre to be the basis of serious research. They further concede that its trading volume is low, just over $140,000 over the last five months. Yet, for a variety of reasons, they say its price accurately gauges the probability of an Iraqi war. 
To counter concerns about the contract's volume, the professors point out that it is still higher than that of the Iowa Electronic Market, a real-money futures exchange administered by the University of Iowa that allows speculating on the American presidential election. Despite trading volume that has averaged just $108,000 an election, these Iowa contracts have had an excellent track record. Their average forecast error for the popular vote in the last four presidential contests has been 1.37 percentage points, about half the average error of nine major polling organizations, according a study by four professors at the university. 
Professors Zitzewitz and Wolfers say they believe that markets in general reflect more wisdom than any single person can possibly have, and thus do a better job of assessing probabilities. That holds true not only for large markets, they say, but also for small and unconventional ones.
The professors concede that Web-based futures, which are largely unregulated, could be skewed by someone willing and able to place sizable buy or sell orders well above or below the current price. But they doubt that this is the case for the contract on Mr. Hussein's ouster, believing that no one has an obvious motive to do so. 
Once the professors were satisfied that this contract was a legitimate basis for research, arriving at their conclusion was straightforward. First, they measured how much the Standard & Poor's 500 index fell, on average, when the price of the contract increased, and vice versa. These measurements let them estimate how low the S.& P. 500 would drop if the contract approached $10, which they believe would be likely on the day a war breaks out. They also calculated how high it would go if the contract fell to zero, reflecting zero probability. Their study, conducted with the assistance of Andrew Leigh, a Harvard graduate student, is at http://faculty-gsb.stanford.edu
/zitzewitz/Research/iraq.pdf.
THEIR analysis projects a 20 percent difference in the S.& P. 500's level at the contract's two price extremes. From this, they concluded that on the day a war begins, the cumulative effect of the buildup to war would be a 20 percent drop in the S.& P. 
With the $10 contract trading at $7.50, the professors believe that 75 percent of the overall 20 percent drop has already occurred. That implies that when a war begins, the market would drop no more than an additional 5 percent.
If their forecasts prove accurate, the professors will overcome at least some of the concerns about the Saddam Hussein futures contract. In any case, with a proliferation of such unconventional trading instruments, we should anticipate more analyses like theirs in coming years.

HEADLINE: A Bad Element 

BYLINE:  By Robert F. Kennedy Jr.; Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is a lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council.

 BODY:
Here's why the environmental community isn't ecstatic over President Bush's call to spend more than $1 billion over five years to develop a hydrogen-powered car to wean us from our addiction to Middle East oil. 
 Certainly, fuel cells that use renewable resources like wind and solar power to extract hydrogen from water promise America a safe, clean energy solution. However, in a sop to the energy industry, the White House wants to extract hydrogen instead from coal and natural gas (without controlling carbon emissions), thereby increasing global warming and fouling our landscape. Worse, the president wants to build a new generation of nuclear power plants specifically for hydrogen production. 
 The president's hydrogen plan will further reduce our national commitment to renewables by cutting our already anemic financing for research into wind, solar and other energy-saving technologies.
Fuel cells offer bright prospects but it will be 10 to 20 years before economical hydrogen vehicles are on the road. Meanwhile, Americans are buying 17 million new cars, trucks and S.U.V.'s a year -- vehicles that could be much more fuel efficient. It's no secret that right now we have the technology to make cars that get better mileage and pollute less. But the administration has repeatedly scuttled efforts to put these innovations in place, fighting tougher fuel economy standards for all vehicles, refusing to compel S.U.V.'s to meet the same mileage standards as cars and creating tax incentives for Americans to buy the largest gas guzzlers. Last week, in an astonishing move, government lawyers joined General Motors and DaimlerChrysler in a federal lawsuit challenging a California law that rewards carmakers for selling low-emission, gasoline-electric hybrid vehicles.
Hybrids are just one of the proven technologies that could start saving oil right now. They can increase fuel economy 50 percent, and never need plugging in. Other technologies that can lift fuel economy include moreadvanced transmissions; improved engine and valve train design; and tires that promote fuel-efficiency. Available now, these solutions won't be widely used until Washington gets serious about the arithmetic of oil security: we use a quarter of the world's oil, yet we have only 3 percent of the known reserves. 
Requiring cars to average 40 miles per gallon by 2012 would save nearly 2 million barrels a day; that's more than we imported from Saudi Arabia last year, and three times our Iraq imports. Raise that to 55 miles per gallon by 2020, and daily savings grow to nearly 5 million barrels, almost twice our current Persian Gulf imports.
We have an oil security problem and we have an air pollution problem. We also have the technology to fix these problems -- if only we would have the will to use it.

HEADLINE: DataBank; 
Bargain-HuntingSnaps a Losing Streak

BYLINE:  By JEFF SOMMER 

 BODY:
Thanks to a rally on Friday, all three major stock market gauges rose for the first week in the last five.
 Worries about war and a weak economy drove the markets lower most of the week, but a bit of bargain-hunting began late Thursday. 
 On Friday, the technology sector led stocks up. Dell Computer shares climbed 11 percent on positive earnings and an upbeat forecast. The chip maker Nvidia jumped 22 percent after its earnings exceeded analysts' expectations by a plump margin.
 In addition to corporate reports like these, testimony by Hans Blix, the top United Nations weapons inspector, gave the markets some comfort. He indicated that he believed some progress had been made in inspections in Iraq, bolstering the view that a United States attack on Iraq might not be near.
 On Friday, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.1 percent, its biggest daily gain since Jan. 6. For the week, the index rose 5.2 points, closing at 834.89, a gain of 0.6 percent. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 44.57 points last week, closing at 7,908.80, also up 0.6 percent. The Nasdaq composite index, however, advanced by 2.2 percent, or 27.27 points, closing at 1,310.17. JEFF SOMMER

HEADLINE: The Nation: On the Home Front; 
What Is Patriotism Without Sacrifice?

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. KENNEDY; David M. Kennedy, a professor of history at Stanford University, is the author of "Freedom From Fear: The American People in Depression and War 1929-1945."

DATELINE: STANFORD, Calif. 

 BODY:
PRESIDENT BUSH may believe that a war against Iraq can be waged without disrupting home-front business as usual. But the gods of war have always demanded sacrifice.
 From time out of mind, warriors have been asked to lay down their bodies on the martial altar. Modern wars have also visited agonies of deprivation on civilian populations, immolating countless noncombatants as well. 
 But sacrifice is about more than death and mayhem. The word itself literally means "to make holy," a reminder that sacrifice has a spiritual and symbolic rationale more venerable than its military one. 
In a total war like World War II, the lines between battlefront and home front blurred, compelling far-reaching economic mobilizations and requiring civilian moral and material support -- not to mention political approval -- to maintain a fighting force in the field.
War leaders have long understood the utility of nurturing the feeling that "we're all in this together," combatant and noncombatant alike, whether the privations on the home front were truly necessary or not. The sentiment of shared sacrifice binds soldier to civilian. For better or worse, that sentiment is what has made modern warfare -- industrialized and full throttle -- possible.
Woodrow Wilson took America into its first modern war in 1917 with a blizzard of propaganda about the need for citizens to conserve food with "meatless Tuesdays" and "wheatless Wednesdays." But Wilson's studied refusal to require rationing suggested that his real aims had as much to do with stimulating patriotic fervor and a sense of citizen involvement as with conserving food. 
In World War II, Franklin D. Roosevelt's administration elevated the spirit of sacrifice to a high art. Some 405,000 American soldiers, sailors, marines, airmen and merchant mariners, along with a handful of civilians, made the ultimate sacrifice to defeat Germany, Japan and Italy. Yet after the short-lived post-Pearl Harbor panic, residents of the continental United States had virtually nothing to fear from enemy malice. But to sustain the martial spirit -- and sanctify the dead -- Americans safe at home nonetheless needed to feel they, too, were making sacrifices in the pursuit of victory. 
ROOSEVELT'S Treasury secretary, Henry Morgenthau Jr., recognized that necessity, organizing a mammoth campaign to urge Americans to curtail consumer spending and buy war bonds instead. The bonds helped pay for the war, of course, and also soaked up income that might have fueled inflation. But Morgenthau admitted that "60 percent of the reason" for the bond drive was "to give the people an opportunity to do something," and "make the country war-minded." He would use the bonds, he explained, to "sell the war, rather than vice versa." 
The government soon removed some items altogether from the stream of commerce. Home construction was sharply restricted, for example, conserving lumber and skilled labor alike for military uses. The manufacture of new cars was prohibited. 
But other efforts made more psychological than strictly economic sense. Boy Scouts trundled little wagons through their neighborhoods, collecting empty tin cans, wads of used foil and old toothpaste tubes made from zinc. None of those metals proved to be in critically short supply, but the scouts got the satisfaction of doing their duty.
Then on April 27, 1942, President Roosevelt announced a seven-point program for economic mobilization. It included bond sales, heavier taxation, controls on wages, prices and credit, and the rationing of "all essential commodities which are scarce." Roosevelt explained in a fireside chat that for homebodies denied "the privilege of fighting our enemies in distant parts of the world," rationing would offer the chance for "equality of sacrifice."
Within weeks, every man, woman and child in America received a little cardboard-bound ration book, containing coupons that had to be presented for the purchase of specified items -- including canned goods, meat, butter, sugar, shoes and, notoriously, coffee (ostensibly because of its demands on ocean shipping). 
A separate system restricted gasoline sales. Gasoline was not in scarce supply, but fuel rationing curbed driving and thereby saved rubber, which was, thanks to the Japanese seizure of rubber plantations in Southeast Asia. 
For the most part, Americans did not chafe under the restrictions. Many cheerfully gave up tinned foods and hoed their way to more healthful diets by raising fresh fruits and vegetables in Victory Gardens.
The rationing system itself was designed along free-market lines. Like latter-day weight-control programs, it gave individuals considerable freedom in using their monthly allocation of 48 ration points -- to allow splurging, for example, on things like steak, footwear or caffeine. Black markets everywhere provided additional goods. If this was sacrifice, it was almost painlessly borne.
What's more, the World War II production miracle ultimately rendered both the scrap drives and rationing economically irrelevant. The United States managed to lift its civilian standard of living even while fielding a multimillion-man fighting force and supplying its allies with prodigious stocks of munitions.
While the war shredded the economies and drastically depressed the living standards of all other belligerents, the American civilian sector grew by nearly 15 percent -- a uniquely American achievement.
That was some kind of miracle, indeed, and it suggests that for the stateside members of the greatest generation, their sacrifices amounted to sentimental gestures rather than genuine hardships.
But they mattered nonetheless. During the Vietnam War, the Johnson administration scarcely dared ask the affluence-intoxicated American public to share even a modicum of the afflictions endured by the troops in Asia.
The contrast between the country's sorry experience in Vietnam and its achievement in World War II suggest that some measure of civilian sacrifice, illusory or not, may be necessary to sustain the will to go the bitter distance.
