HEADLINE: THE POP LIFE; 
The Osbournes Plan for Summer

BYLINE:  By Neil Strauss

 BODY:
The Osbournes opened their Beverly Hills home for a news conference on Tuesday to announce the lineup of Ozzfest, the summer hard-rock tour led by Ozzy Osbourne.
 The location for the announcement was a savvy move on the part of Sharon Osbourne, Mr. Osbourne's wife, manager and television co-star. Allowing the news media into a home famous as the setting for the family's beloved reality show was a surefire way to coax extra publicity for the opening of the tour in the highly competitive summer festival season. And it was little nuisance for the Osbournes, who are used to having television cameras in their home. 
 In the past it would have been improbable to have walked onto the set of "Seinfeld" or "The Cosby Show" and interacted with the players while they were still in character. But since the comedy that is "The Osbournes" is a reality show, and regular exposure on MTV has let its family get comfortable simply being itself in front of strangers, the Osbournes are almost always in character.
Tuesday's news conference may remain a great lost episode; the show's cameras were absent because the permit required to hold the event did not allow them. The guests included members of Korn, Marilyn Manson and Chevelle, who are to perform at Ozzfest when it begins on June 28 in San Antonio, where Mr. Osbourne's shows were banned for years after he urinated on the Alamo. (The tour comes to the New York area on Aug. 18, at the PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J.)
The entire Osbourne family was on hand -- pets and all -- with the matriarch looking radiant. "Unlike Michael Jackson, I've had more than two operations," she said in a one-on-one interview. Shortly afterward she admonished her son, Jack, threatening to have Mr. Jackson baby-sit for him if he didn't behave.
The news conference began with a reporter asking Mr. Osbourne if his pioneering heavy-metal band, Black Sabbath, would ever reunite. "I'll never say never again," Mr. Osbourne replied, breaking his word two seconds later by continuing, "because you never know."
Ms. Osbourne quickly cut the questions short with a comment that began politely, "Excuse me," but ended with a string of profanities directed at that reporter for not asking about Ozzfest. 
Mr. Osbourne grinned: "She told you, mate."
Mr. Manson said he had been invited to join the tour after having "phone sex" with Ms. Osbourne. Mr. Osbourne looked at him admiringly and said, "That's more than I've had." 
On a more serious note, Mr. Osbourne said that last year he was not prepared to go on the road after colon cancer was diagnosed in his wife. This year, however, she is recovering, and Mr. Osbourne said he was preparing by exercising five days a week for two hours a day. 
Was he still drinking, someone wanted to know? "I'll tell you what my drinking problem is," Mr. Osbourne replied. "I've only got one mouth."
As all this unfolded, the Osbournes' dogs scratched noisily at the windows outside, and Kelly Osbourne flitted in and out of the rooms, complaining about the catered food and pet smells. 
In a famous news release several years ago, Sharon Osbourne said she had stopped managing the Smashing Pumpkins for medical reasons. "Billy Corgan was making me sick," she elaborated, referring to that band's leader. When asked on Tuesday whether she had tried to recruit Mr. Corgan's current band, Zwan, for Ozzfest, Ms. Osbourne replied, "I did, because we needed new catering."
Nowadays Ms. Osbourne does not manage other bands, she said.
Explained Jack, "Mom's a TV star." 
After the news conference Mr. Osbourne agreed to sit down for a one-on-one interview with characteristic magnanimity. "I thought that the whole point of a press conference was so that I didn't have to do these," he complained to his publicist. 
"I got two careers -- the TV career and the rock 'n' roll career," he said after easily relenting. "And the love of my life is music. I've watched barely half an episode of 'The Osbournes.' " 
Besides, that show, he said, "is just me using profanities and trying to be a father."
Ozzfest, which began in 1997, has become one of the most successful summer tours. This year the main-stage lineup also includes Disturbed. Among the acts scheduled for the second stage, and booked in part by Jack Osbourne, are Cradle of Filth, Trust Company and Hotwire. 

Festival Frenzy
Competition for the dwindling disposable income of Americans seems as if it will be fierce this summer. In recent days many of that season's most anticipated festivals have announced their lineups and ticket prices. In deference to the economy, Ozzfest is even selling a limited number of lawn seats for $10 directly at the box office of each show.
Perhaps Ozzfest's closest competition is Metallica's Summer Sanitarium tour, which is almost entirely made up of bands that have performed previously at Ozzfest, among them Linkin Park, Deftones, Limp Bizkit and Mudvayne.
Lollapalooza, the alternative-rock road show that inspired Ozzfest and most of its other summer festival competitors, has returned after five years. It even outwrestled Ozzfest to book the hard-rock band Queens of the Stone Age. Also appearing at Lollapalooza, scheduled for July and August, are Incubus, Audioslave, Jurassic 5, and Jane's Addiction. 
The punk-heavy Vans Warped Tour has survived to see its ninth year, with A.F.I., Rancid, Andrew W. K., the Ataris, Dropkick Murphys, Less Than Jake, Pennywise, Suicide Machines and the Used. 
Two major nontouring festivals also announced their lineups this week. The eclectic Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival is set for April 26 and 27 in Indio, Calif. It will include the in-demand Queens of the Stone Age along with Underworld, Ben Harper, Jack Johnson, the White Stripes, Primal Scream, N*E*R*D, Cafe Tacuba, Kinky, Ladytron, Badly Drawn Boy, Ben Folds, Fischerspooner and Felix da Housecat. 
The Bonnaroo Music Festival will run from June 13 to 15 in Manchester, Tenn., with Ben Harper, Jack Johnson, the Roots, Moe, Galactic, Robert Randolph, James Brown, the Allman Brothers, Sonic Youth, Tortoise and Medeski, Martin and Wood. Headlining the festival will be Widespread Panic and the Dead. The latter act was the Grateful Dead, but after the death of Jerry Garcia in 1995 its members retired that name and performed as the Other Ones. Last week, however, the band members met their former name halfway and rechristened themselves the Dead at a Valentine's Day concert in San Francisco.
Other major packages expected this summer include the pairing of Kiss and Aerosmith, as well as Christina Aguilera and Justin Timberlake.

HEADLINE: Military Contractor Gets Deal To Limit Its Losses in Britain 

BYLINE:  By ERIC PFANNER, International Herald Tribune

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 19 

 BODY:
BAE Systems, Europe's largest military contractor, said today that it had reached an agreement with the British government to limit its losses on two major contracts that have been plagued with cost overruns. The deal lifted a cloud from the company's financial prospects and inspired investors to bid up its shares by more than 10 percent.
 News of the problems with the two weapons programs -- Astute-class submarines and Nimrod MRA4 surveillance aircraft -- had depressed the value of BAE's shares by about 40 percent over three days in December, and had undermined confidence in the company's leadership. 
 Doubts were growing about BAE's ability to deliver profits from a huge new contract it has just won, a $4.6 billion order to build two aircraft carriers for the British Navy. BAE will subcontract much of the work on the carriers to its main rival for the order, Thales of France.
"They've received a get-out-of-jail card this time, but one wonders how many times they will keep getting them," Gareth Evans, a consultant at A. T. Kearney who follows the military procurement industry, said of BAE's agreement today. 
Analysts said Britain had little choice but to agree to absorb most of the cost overruns on the Astute and Nimrod programs. Western European countries generally spend proportionally much less on weapons than the United States. Big weapons contracts are few, and production runs are short, making economies of scale hard to achieve.
To maintain a viable European weapons industry, governments will have to live with the need to insulate suppliers from catastrophic losses when a program runs into problems. 
The new agreement provides for BAE and the British Ministry of Defense to share future cost overruns (or savings if there are any) on the two programs.
For the cost overruns already incurred, BAE will take a charge of $:750 million ($1.2 billion) against 2002 earnings, which are scheduled to be reported Thursday. The British government will also provide some new money for each weapon system.
Both programs are years behind schedule. The Nimrod aircraft, originally planned for delivery this year, is now expected in 2009; the first Astute submarine, once meant to see service in 2001, will probably not be completed until 2008.
"Addressing these issues has been important but it should be recognized that the balance and majority of the company's business has continued to perform well," said Mike Turner, the company's chief executive.

PERSON: Richard Orme Wilberforce 

HEADLINE: Lord Wilberforce, 95, Keeper Of an Antislavery Tradition 

BYLINE:  By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Richard Orme Wilberforce, a retired member of Britain's highest court and keeper of his family's antislavery tradition, died on Saturday at a hospital in London. He was 95.
 He was a prominent judge in postwar Britain, known for handling both criminal and civil matters with a keen intellect, clarity and patient civility. Knighted in 1961, he was created a life peer and law lord three years later, when he became Lord Wilberforce, Baron of the City and County of Kingston-upon-Hull. 
 Lord Wilberforce was a great-great-grandson of William Wilberforce (1759-1833), an English statesman associated with William Pitt the Younger, the great British prime minister. William Wilberforce was a religiously inspired antislavery politician who helped pave the way for the Abolition of Slavery Act of 1833.
Three years ago his descendant, Lord Wilberforce, warned Parliament of a modern kind of "bonded labor." This, he declared, had taken the place of slavery that William Wilberforce had denounced in the House of Commons as early as the 1780's.
He said that whereas people may be freed from chattel servitude by breaking their chains, modern bonded labor enmeshes them in a whole skein of complex economic and political circumstances.
"You have to provide a system of good employment, schools for the children, and some system of land reform so that people can earn a living," he told Parliament. "Bonded labor certainly is servitude, and in many ways it is worse."
Richard Orme Wilberforce was raised in India, the son of a judge of the high court in Lahore under the Raj. He graduated from Oxford University and was called to the bar in 1932.
His career as a barrister was interrupted by six years in the army in World War II. He served in Norway, France and Germany, earning the rank of brigadier and decorations that included a United States Bronze Star. He ended the war in the army's legal branch and was under secretary of the Control Office for Germany and Austria in 1945-46, helping to repeal Nazi-era legislation and set up a new legal framework.
He started his judicial career in 1961 as an appointed High Court, or Chancery, judge. He was promoted directly to the House of Lords as a lord appeal in ordinary. Historically the House of Lords served as Britain's court of final resort but delegated that function to a committee of law lords, making it the country's highest tribunal.
He contributed especially in the fields of international law, and administrative and commercial law. He was also remembered for issuing the judicial report ending the coal miners' strike that crippled Britain in the winter of 1971-72.
After he retired from the law committee in 1982, Lord Wilberforce advocated human rights, legal reforms and a simpler legislative process. He also sought to inspire the judiciary to become more aware of social needs and imperatives when applying the law.
His survivors include his wife of 55 years, Yvette Marie Lenoan, daughter of a French judge; a daughter, Anne Catherine Burn; and a son, Samuel Herbert.

HEADLINE: The Worst Defense 

BYLINE:  By Daniel Benjamin and Steven Simon; Daniel Benjamin and Steven Simon, members of the National Security Council staff from 1994-1999, are authors of The Age of Sacred Terror."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
In announcing his "Ready Campaign" to prepare Americans for terrorist attack, Secretary of Homeland Security Tom Ridge declared yesterday: "Terror forces us to make a choice. We can be afraid or we can be ready." Mr. Ridge's remarks, meant to calm people unnerved by two weeks of life at Code Orange, might have more resonance if the Bush administration were investing more wisely in national defenses against a catastrophic attack.
 As much as $160 billion in new financing has been poured into national security since 9/11, yet only a small fraction has been used to make Americans safer at home. In fact, the bulk of the money has been used for troops, conventional weapons systems and traditional military investments, not for confronting terrorism. This trend will accelerate with the president's 2004 budget: at $380 billion, spending on the military is expected to grow $40 billion over last year and almost a third since 2001, an extraordinary jump by historical standards. 
 Higher salaries for soldiers and a new aircraft carrier may be welcome in the unlikely event that Al Qaeda ever hijacks another state, as it did Afghanistan. But after the punishment meted out in late 2001, it is unlikely that United States forces will again face Qaeda fighters on the battlefield. 
In fact, the most significant defense increase that will directly help the counterterrorism effort is $1.1 billion for Special Operations Forces, which will be used more and more to destroy terrorist cells in places where the local authorities lack the ability.
On the defensive side of the ledger, the administration will increase to $9 billion the financing for national missile defense. But as the government's National Intelligence Estimate asserts, America is far more likely to be attacked by terrorists using weapons of mass destruction delivered in a car, truck or airplane than by a rogue nation with missiles. 
By comparison, the funds being allocated for security in the United States -- through the new Homeland Security Department and other agencies -- are much skimpier.
Certainly, the administration has rightly poured $12 billion into aviation security, vaccine research and a stockpile of vital drugs that would mitigate the effects of a biological weapons attack. Yet even these efforts remain uneven: no comparable security upgrades have been made for United States carriers at foreign airports -- an inexplicable failure given that Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, an architect of the 9/11 attacks and someone who plotted to blow up a dozen American 747's over the Pacific in 1995, is still at large. Moreover, the effort to equip and train first responders -- the emergency personnel who would deal with a catastrophic attack -- has fallen woefully behind because of budget wrangling.
Skeptics argue, rightly, that a perfect defense is impossible. A more systematic approach, however, is not only possible but essential. Here are some key threats that must be addressed:
Unmanned aircraft and cruise missiles. On 9/11, commercial jets were used as missiles; their payloads were jet fuel. Today, recreational kit airplanes can be built for a few thousand dollars and converted into remote-control weapons. These planes can take off from a grass strip shorter than a football field and give terrorists an easy means to attack from within America's borders. 
And then there are cruise missiles. A growing number of countries, including Pakistan and Iran, have anti-ship cruise missiles that, if stolen or diverted, could be converted into land-attack cruise missiles. These missiles can be transported in nondescript containers and guided by inexpensive Global Positioning System devices to targets mapped with available satellite imagery. Freighters provide the ideal platform for launching these cruise missiles, which can travel more than 100 miles; Al Qaeda is reported to have 15 such vessels. 
Creating a perimeter at sea to keep suspicious ships out of range would mean drastically expanding the Coast Guard's mission. Although the United States has excellent air defenses against a conventional military attack, both slow-flying remote-controlled aircraft and terrain-hugging cruise missiles present a formidable challenge. Military radar that tracks supersonic aircraft cannot distinguish a terrorist plane or cruise missile from a commercial puddle-jumper; creating a new radar system that knows what to look for would be complicated and expensive -- yet it's essential if the United States is to even contemplate shooting down such a vehicle. A starting estimate of the cost of safeguarding American airspace from these dangers is $40 billion. 
Shoulder-fired anti-aircraft missiles. The recent information about a possible attack at Heathrow Airport in London and the firing of two missiles at an Israeli plane taking off from Mombasa, Kenya, in November are frightening harbingers. The world is awash in thousands of these Stinger-type missiles, including ones made in the United States, Russia, China, the former Yugoslavia and North Korea. They have been used dozens of times against commercial aircraft, mostly in African war zones. Twice during the Clinton administration, reports of impending attacks with such missiles caused intense security scrambles abroad. A single hit on an American jet would bring commercial aviation to a halt and cripple the economy.
It is possible to defend against these missiles. Because the projectiles have a ceiling of about 10,000 feet, the danger is greatest for aircraft taking off and landing. While it is impossible to secure every rooftop around urban airports, much can be done to map the safest routes for planes and to watch over airports with cameras, patrols and helicopters. Some of the mapping work has already been done at American and foreign airports, but a global effort is required.
Countermeasures -- the so-called chaff and flare -- used on military aircraft can also be employed on commercial planes. After Mombasa, Israel started to install all its commercial jets with this equipment. In the late 1990's, the United States government raised the issue of countermeasures with the airlines. The industry blanched upon learning that it would cost $1 million to $2 million per plane. Airlines are in worse economic shape than they were a decade ago, making them even less willing to adopt these measures. Washington needs to step in, at a cost of around $5 billion. 
Loose nuclear weapons, chemicals and pathogens. If the conflict with Iraq sharpens, Al Qaeda will get its best chance of acquiring a weapon of mass destruction since all constraints on Saddam Hussein's behavior will evaporate if his regime is in danger. Over the longer term, the terrorists will look to acquire key ingredients from the former Soviet Union, where tons of chemical, biological and nuclear materials remain poorly guarded. The United States spent $4 billion in the 1990's to destroy weaponry and safeguard materials. After much initial skepticism, the Bush administration embraced this program. Last year, the leading industrial countries promised to join in with pledges of $18 billion. 
Now, the United States must keep this a top priority on the international agenda. It also needs to extend this program to other countries where there is a serious possibility of proliferation, including Pakistan, some of whose scientists have met with senior Qaeda members.
Whether driving a bomb-laden skiff into a warship or flying a wide-body jet into a skyscraper, Al Qaeda has shown extraordinary tactical ingenuity. Against this innovative and resilient foe, the United States needs to muster the resources and creativity for an effective defense, instead of overarming for battle with the rogue regimes that its military can already easily defeat.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Renewed Fears of Iraq War Cause Share Prices to Falter

BYLINE:  By Reuters

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday, ending a two-day rally that had lifted the Dow Jones industrial average almost 300 points, as renewed fears of war with Iraq unnerved investors.
 "What we're seeing is reaction to yesterday's call that war is not likely," said Subodh Kumar, chief investment strategist at CIBC World Markets in Toronto. "I don't think we can make that call." 
 The United States and Britain worked to draw up a United Nations resolution authorizing force, in hopes that such a resolution would placate global opposition to a war. 
The Dow fell 40.55 points, or 0.5 percent, to close at 8,000.60, recovering from a decline that reached 105 points. 
The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 6.04 points, or 0.71 percent, to 845.13.
The Nasdaq composite index declined 12.22 points, or 0.91 percent, to 1,334.32. 
Investors looked past an upbeat economic report. Low mortgage rates helped housing starts rise unexpectedly in January, climbing 0.2 percent to their highest rate since mid-1986, the government said. 
Fears of an American-led war with Iraq also pushed oil prices higher. In New York, crude oil for March delivery rose 20 cents, or 0.5 percent, to $37.16 a barrel, its highest close in 29 months. 
"Longer-term investors aren't willing to come in and be buyers," said Paul Cherney, a market analyst at S&P Marketscope. "That's the plight of the market, and it will remain that way until we have some resolution with Iraq." 
Among the most active issues on the New York Stock Exchange was MBNA, which fell more than 12 percent, or $2, to $14.50. 
MBNA, the independent credit card company, had earnings estimates cut by several analysts after it reported higher-than-expected credit losses in January. 
Shares in chip equipment companies fell a day after the industry's trade group reported that orders to North American suppliers fell 10 percent in January. Applied Materials Inc. lost 33 cents, to $12.41; Novellus Systems dropped $1.02, to $29.36; and KLA-Tencor lost 46 cents, to $34.65. 
Lucent Technologies, the telecommunications equipment maker, gained slightly for most of the day after its chief executive, Patricia F. Russo, said the company was sticking by its projection of returning to profitability this fiscal year, citing growth in the industry. 
Shareholders also voted to approve giving Lucent directors authority to perform a reverse stock split, aimed at preventing shares from being delisted and reducing volatility in its share price. 
By the end of the day, Lucent lost 2 cents, to $1.77.
Qwest Communications International, the provider of local telephone service, fell 32 cents, to $4.05. The company, which is facing federal investigations of its accounting practices, posted a fourth-quarter profit because of one-time gains, but revenue fell on slack demand for telephone and data services. 
Shares of J. M. Smucker, the maker of peanut butter and jelly, fell as much as 12.5 percent after the company forecast only slight earnings growth for the coming year. Smucker shares slid $4.02, or 10.3 percent, to $35.02. 
A bullish call from Morgan Stanley barely lifted semiconductor stocks. 
The brokerage firm said a new product cycle, lower unit costs and pricing power should "drive earnings power sharply higher" in the next one to two years at Intel, the industry giant. Shares of Intel rose 9 cents, to $16.80. 
Morgan Stanley also increased its rating on Texas Instruments and Xilinx. Texas Instruments gained 17 cents, to $16.41, and Xilinx added 1 cent to $22.10. The rating increase "was totally ignored," said Andrew Baker, senior trader at the regional investment bank Wedbush Morgan in Los Angeles. 
In the bond market, the 10-year Treasury note increased 16/32, to a price of 99 29/32 . The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 3.89 percent, from 3.95 percent on Tuesday. 
The 30-year bond rose 24/32 , to 108 16/32 . Its yield fell to 4.82 percent, from 4.86 percent.

HEADLINE: Incumbent Is Favored as Armenia Holds Presidential Election 

BYLINE:  Reuters

DATELINE: YEREVAN, Armenia, Feb. 19 

 BODY:
Using see-through ballot boxes to help fight fraud, Armenia voted today for a president, who will have to tackle the protracted dispute over the Nagorno-Karabakh region with Azerbaijan and revive a ravaged economy.
 Opinion polls in the former Soviet republic, which is situated in a region important to Western oil interests, showed that the incumbent, Robert Kocharian, was likely to clear the 50 percent mark needed for a first-round victory over eight rivals. 
 Mr. Kocharian, 48, has been in power since 1998 in this country of 3.2 million. "I never step into battle without counting" his chances, he told reporters after voting, but he avoided further questions. 
His main rivals are Artashes Geghamian, the Communist-era mayor of Yerevan, and Stepan Demirchian, the son of a Soviet-era leader, Karen Demirchian, who challenged Mr. Kocharian in 1998.
"I am going to vote for Kocharian as I like how he works and I want stability," said Gagik Barsegian, 53, a driver from Yerevan. "Another candidate could destroy everything." 
Previous voting in Armenia has been marked by intimidation and ballot-box stuffing.
Many voters cast their ballots in transparent boxes imported from the West as part of efforts to ensure a clean vote.
Four of Mr. Kocharian's opponents, including his two main rivals, issued a statement today saying that they had witnessed large-scale voting irregularities that showed "free and fair elections and the country's international image" were in danger. 
Whatever the outcome, analysts say, new talks over the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region are unlikely until after elections in Azerbaijan in November.
Armenians in Nagorno-Karabakh broke away from Azerbaijan in 1988. Six years of fighting left more than 35,000 dead and nearly a million homeless, with Armenian forces seizing much territory. A cease-fire took hold in 1994, but no long-term solution has proven attainable, despite recent attempts by Russia, the United States and France to mediate.
Armenia has a close strategic relationship with Russia. The United States, which has considerable oil interests in the region, has made it clear that it wants a fair vote that will produce leadership able to tackle the Nagorno-Karabakh issue.
But for most voters, the Nagorno-Karabakh issue is secondary to raising living standards. Average monthly salaries stand at the equivalent of $40.
"I want Stepan Demirchian to be our president," said Sevan Ayvasian, 64, an engineer from Yerevan. "I believe that he will fight corruption and restore order in our country."
Armenia relies on support from up to six million ethnic Armenians in the United States. Two million ethnic Armenians live in Russia, and virtually all candidates call for close ties with Moscow.
Surveys predicted a turnout of over 70 percent and there were long lines at polling booths despite bad weather.

HEADLINE: Kraft Announces Pension Costs 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Feb. 19 

 BODY:
Kraft Foods Inc. said today that it would have 5 cents a share in noncash expenses next year because it spread out low returns from a pension program. 
 The company may also spend about 2 cents a share for a compensation program that gives executives restricted stock in lieu of options, the co-chief executives, Betsy Holden and Roger Deromedi, said in a presentation to analysts and investors in Arizona. 
 Companies have had to invest in their pension programs because declining value in equity investments and interest rates cut the funds' returns. Kraft's costs for next year assume the pension assets have a 9 percent rate of return. The company will have 9 cents a share in pension, health care and stock compensation expenses in 2003. 
Kraft still expects to earn $2.10 to $2.15 a share this year, an increase of as much as 6 percent from 2002. The company will save $140 million to $150 million from plant closings and other measures taken after its parent, Altria Group Inc., bought Nabisco more than two years ago.

HEADLINE: BLOCKS; 
Blight Is Issue at Proposed Site for The Times

BYLINE:  By David W. Dunlap

 BODY:
WELL-REHEARSED drama is a staple of 42nd Street, even in the legal battles that have accompanied each step of its state-sponsored redevelopment.
 The acts play out like this: The government condemns properties as blighted. Owners sue, in part for bargaining leverage. The state prevails. Cases are settled. Awards, fees and expenses are paid. Sites are cleared. And new towers emerge. 
 At first, Prof. Marci A. Hamilton of the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law of Yeshiva University, who specializes in constitutional law, said she discerned another "cut-and-dried application of the law" in the case involving owners on the block of Eighth Avenue, between 40th and 41st Streets, whose property has been acquired by New York State to create a development site for The New York Times Company's new headquarters.
But this case differs from earlier battles in that it is being fought at a time when blight and Times Square are no longer synonymous.
Professor Hamilton is persuaded that the case presents an important federal issue and is hoping, against high odds, that the United States Supreme Court will agree to hear the matter, which it is expected to review soon.
"The real question is: can a government take private property for the benefit of other private owners when the blight findings they're relying on are done after the decision to take the property?" Professor Hamilton said.
By that, she meant that the official determination of blight was issued in November 2001, after a tentative agreement reached by the Empire State Development Corporation with the Times Company and its development partner, Forest City Ratner Companies. Earlier blight findings, she said, were of questionable relevance since they were in some cases almost 20 years old.
Professor Hamilton argued in her petition to the Supreme Court that federal and state courts were split on whether the constitutional requirement of a public purpose for the taking of property could be satisfied by blight findings that were, in essence, a pretext for economic development plans.
Her clients are Sidney, Markus and Joseph Orbach, brothers and partners in Three O Realty, who owned a 110,000-square-foot office building at 265 West 40th Street that the state condemned in August, along with 10 other properties, to create a development site for The Times. Their tenants included a Donna Karan Home showroom and the richly stocked B & J Fabrics store. "This whole 16-story building -- they offered $7 million," Markus Orbach said. "That's a nice bargain."
And an unconstitutional one, Professor Hamilton said. "The taking was not a taking for the public purpose of removing blight, but solely for the purpose of transferring private property to another, more powerful and 'connected' private owner, The New York Times," she said in her petition. In response, Empire State Development dismissed the federal claim as preposterous. "No case has ever held that a pretextual blight finding is sufficient to satisfy the constitutional public use requirement," the state said in its brief, prepared by Carter, Ledyard & Milburn.
And no pretext was involved, state officials argued. "Without public intervention, there is no reason to believe blight will cease to exist," they said, meaning prostitution, drug use and loitering; the "shabby gateway" that the buildings present to Times Square; and the general underdevelopment of the block.
"The fact that the project may advance incidental private interests of The New York Times Company and the developer of additional office space is not unlawful and does not detract from its public purpose," the state said.
As for the Orbachs' building, the state said that even if "isolated pockets" of the block were not blighted, the whole site was.
Speaking for the Times Company, Catherine Mathis said yesterday: "The courts have repeatedly upheld, as recently as last year, the state's determination that the area is blighted. We believe that our proposed new headquarters will significantly enhance the area."
HAVING prevailed in state courts, Empire State Development is now clearing the block. Sussex House, a private 140-bed dormitory at 260 West 41st Street, has already closed. Officials say that residents received relocation payments and the owner accepted a multimillion-dollar settlement.
From the building at Eighth Avenue and 40th Street, the Taylor Business Institute and the SAE Institute of Technology have found new quarters, said Michael Rikon of Goldstein, Goldstein, Rikon & Gottlieb, which represents eight owners and 37 businesses, none of which have yet settled their claims. Arnold Hatters, the most distinctive store on the block, is searching for space it can afford, Mr. Rikon said, but has not found anything.
The Donna Karan showroom will be moving and B & J Fabrics will have a new home nearby on Seventh Avenue after 48 years in the Orbachs' building.
As they watched their property empty, the Orbachs reflected on their efforts not long ago to renovate it and build up its tenancy. "Besides the money," Sidney Orbach said, "we invested an awful lot of ourselves."

GRAPHIC: Photo: From left, Joseph, Sidney and Markus Orbach were offered $7 million for a 16-story building. (Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times, 2001)

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: MENTAL HEALTH; 
Long-Term Effects of Post-Trauma Events

BYLINE:  By ERICA GOODE

 BODY:
Among New Yorkers who suffered from post-traumatic stress disorder after Sept. 11, 2001, those who have lost family members, lost jobs or experienced other stress since the attack are the most likely to still be having symptoms, researchers have found.
 People with midlevel incomes and those under the age of 30 or over 60 were also likely to have persistent symptoms. 
 The findings were based on a preliminary analysis of data collected by scientists at the New York Academy of Medicine in a survey of 1,939 residents of the New York metropolitan area. The participants were surveyed 6 to 9 months after the attack and again after 12 to 15 months. 
The survey findings have not yet been submitted for publication, but they were presented on Monday in Denver at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
Dr. Sandro Galea, a medical epidemiologist and the associate director of the academy's Center for Urban Epidemiologic Studies, said the findings suggested that "what happens after the event matters."
Whatever people have gone through in the last few months, Dr. Galea said, "is probably interacting with people's experiences after Sept. 11."
In the earlier survey, the researchers found that 152 of those interviewed reported symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder in the six to nine months after the attack. Of those 152, 41.6 percent reported that they were still having difficulties several months later, a figure that corresponds roughly to that found in previous studies of trauma victims.
The symptoms of the disorder include nightmares, hypervigilance, flashbacks, jumpiness, avoidance of reminders of the traumatic event and unusual irritability.
Dr. Galea said the factors that predicted the development of post-traumatic stress disorder in the earlier survey -- proximity to the World Trade Center or having lost a family member in the attack, for example -- werenot associated in the new survey with continuing symptoms.
"The things that predict the development of P.T.S.D. to begin with seem to be very different from those that predict persistent P.T.S.D.," he said. "It's surprising, but it makes sense."
Dr. Galea and his colleagues, who include Dr. David Vlahov, the center's director, found that people who had experienced two stressful events since the Sept. 11 attack, like divorce or the death of a family member, were 47 times as likely to have persistent symptoms as those who had the symptoms several months earlier but had not faced such stress. Those who had gone through only one stressful event were 4.5 times as likely to have continuing symptoms.
Among survey participants with incomes from $50,000 to $75,000, the stress disorder was 7.2 times as likely to persist as it was among people with higher or lower incomes. Similar rates were found for the survey participants who were over age 70 or who were unemployed in the 6 to 12 months after Sept. 11. People under 30 were 4.4 times as likely to still have symptoms.
The researchers also found that of the participants who had post-traumatic stress symptoms in the earlier survey, persistent symptoms were more common among those who felt another terrorist attack was likely.
Sixty-two percent of the survey respondents who called another attack "very likely" had continuing post-traumatic stress disorder, while only 20 percent of those who said it was "not at all likely" had continuing symptoms.
But Dr. Galea cautioned that it was not clear whether this finding meant that people who had continuing psychiatric difficulties were more likely to be afraid, or that higher levels of fear helped maintain the symptoms.

HEADLINE: As Animosity Grows, Pataki And Silver Take Rift on the Road 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 19 

 BODY:
Both the Republican governor and the Democratic speaker of the Assembly went to western New York today and trumpeted their sides in an increasingly bitter debate over the state budget, another sign of a growing animosity between the two men.
 Gov. George E. Pataki gave speeches in Buffalo and Rochester, reiterating his vow to stand firm against raising broad-based taxes to close a cumulative $11.5 billion shortfall in the budget for this fiscal year and the next, which begins on April 1. "We need more jobs, not job-killing taxes," he said in Rochester, "and you can't have both." 
 Speaker Sheldon Silver, the Legislature's top Democrat, tried to upstage Mr. Pataki in Buffalo, going to a preschool to denounce the governor's attempts to cut education programs by $1.2 billion. He made a similar visit to a school in Manhattan last week. "The governor is proposing balancing the budget on the backs of children," he said.
The dueling public appeals by the state's most powerful Republican and Democrat underscore not only the sorry state of bipartisan cooperation here in the capital, but also a breakdown of trust between the two men, legislative aides and people who know both politicians say.
"It's mortal combat," a senior Democratic official said. "Frosty is an inane understatement. The staffs hate each other."
Mr. Silver has become more and more strident in his public criticisms of the governor over the last two months. The governor has nimbly counterattacked with the assertion that the Assembly leader has blocked anti-terrorism legislation, which Mr. Pataki considers critical.
Mr. Pataki has also pleaded with Mr. Silver to authorize about $4 billion in new borrowing, backed by annual payments from a court settlement with tobacco companies, to help balance the state's books. Mr. Silver has refused to act on that proposal, too.
"It's getting frosty at this point, as nothing is happening," one person close to the governor said.
The speaker has made it plain that his chamber will not give the governor the ability to use the borrowed tobacco funds until the entire budget for next year is negotiated.
"I don't like cuts; I don't like taxes; I don't like borrowing long term for short-term expenditures," Mr. Silver said today. "Obviously some combination of these will be the budget of New York. No part of that plan should get put in place until the entire thing is put in place."
Some Democrats say that Mr. Pataki's strategy is to force them to take the blame for a tax increase that is inevitable if the state is to maintain the health-care and schools programs the governor himself promoted in his re-election campaign.
"We are trying, one time, to stick this guy with something where he has to pay the price if he wants to take credit for anything," one aide to Mr. Silver said, referring to the governor.
For his part, Mr. Pataki insists he is not bluffing. Speaking to business leaders in Buffalo and Rochester, he repeated his contention that the tax cuts his administration put in place in 1995 had turned the economy around. The only way to save the state's programs in the long run, he said, is to prime the economy again.
"Unfortunately, there are those in the Legislature who are already urging us to take the path that New York and other states have taken before, massive job-killing taxes," the governor said.
Mr. Silver has harped on the fact that Mr. Pataki's budget does include increases in the sales tax on clothing and surcharges on hospital bills. He has asserted, too, that the cuts to school aid will lead to local property tax increases as districts scramble to make ends meet. 
The speaker has attacked the governor over his plan to raise tuition and delay scholarships at state universities, as well.
"I think it's important to show people how his budget affects them and present to them what is actually there," Mr. Silver said.
Underlying the policy debate is a personal animosity that each has voiced to aides and other lawmakers. Mr. Pataki and Mr. Silver have never been close, but their relationship has gone through rocky and smooth phases. They manage to maintain civility in public and have even met over dinner on occasion. But their relationship has become strained during political crises. This is a particularly bad phase, aides say.
It has galled Mr. Silver that every year Mr. Pataki has stripped from his budget the speaker's top priorities, among them preschool classes and all-day kindergarten. It vexed Mr. Silver, as well, that Mr. Pataki won re-election while taking credit for Democratic initiatives, like tax-free business zones and health insurance for poor children.
On a personal level, Mr. Silver, who lives a modest life, is uncomfortable with the governor's lifestyle -- his Ivy League education, his mansion in Garrison, N.Y., his use of state aircraft and chartered jets.
Mr. Pataki, meanwhile, finds Mr. Silver's passion for gamesmanship and his poker-face tactics tiring, people close to the governor say.
"He gets frustrated with the guy," one friend of the governor said. "It's not a love or hate thing. It's more frustration that he can't get answers, can't get decisions made."
Some lawmakers, however, said the two men had that in common: they are both difficult to read and are not always up front about their tactics, irritating each other in the process.
After winning re-election in November, Mr. Pataki reached out to Mr. Silver, seeking his help in closing the current year's budget deficit, Mr. Pataki's aides said. The speaker rebuffed these entreaties, letting the governor know he was not happy that Mr. Pataki had avoided talking about the financial crisis during the election, a fellow Democrat said.
Then Mr. Silver declined the governor's request to call Assembly members back to Albany in December to authorize borrowing against future payments from tobacco companies. The governor is depending on $1.5 billion from the tobacco borrowing to close the gap in this year's budget.
"He can't manage the state without coming to some agreement with Shelly," one Democratic legislative aide said.
Which politician will win the hearts of taxpayers remains to be seen. Both men plan more appearances to spread their messages.
Mr. Pataki's pledge to oppose tax increases was generally well received among the business leaders he spoke to today. But the mood was subdued as he spoke to the Rochester Business Alliance, and some who listened to his address to the Amherst Chamber of Commerce, just outside Buffalo, said his budget would lead to higher local school taxes.
"He's shifting the burden onto the local taxpayer," said Yasmin M. Dara, the president of the Williamsville PTA Council.

HEADLINE: New-Home Building Reaches The Highest Level Since 1986 

BYLINE:  AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 

 BODY:
The construction of new homes reached the highest level in January since 1986, the Commerce Department reported today, noting the lowest mortgage rates in four decades. 
 The report said work was started on 1.85 million single-family homes and apartment units last month, at a seasonally adjusted annual pace. That was up 0.2 percent from December, when construction rose 4.9 percent from the month before. 
 Construction of single-family residences rose 2.1 percent, to an annual pace of 1.51 million units, the fastest in more than two decades. But construction of apartments fell 8.7 percent, to an annual 303,000 units. 
Sales of both new and existing homes set records last year. And home prices have risen as the stock market has declined, making home ownership look to many people like a good investment.
Joel L. Naroff of Naroff Economic Advisers, said, "With sales at or near record levels and prices still rising, you would expect that new construction activity would be robust, and it is."
David Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders, said there might be some setback in the February construction activity because of the recent blizzard in the mid-Atlantic states and the Northeast. 
Total permits to start housing construction, an indicator of builders' confidence in future business, fell 5.6 percent in January, the Commerce Department reported.
Growing worries about a war in Iraq may make people cautious about committing to a big-ticket purchase like a home, but Mr. Seiders said this effect would be temporary and would be offset by continued low interest rates. 
He forecast that construction activity this year is likely to decline to 1.65 million units, down from last year's 1.71 million units, the best showing since 1986. 
By region, housing starts posted the biggest January gain in the West, an increase of 9.9 percent to an annual pace of 522,000 units.Construction was up 3.8 percent in the South, to an annual 839,000 units.
The two other regions had declines in January, reflecting the winter weather. The bigger drop was in the Northeast, where housing starts fell 16.7 percent, to an annual pace of 135,000 units. Construction activity dropped 11.9 percent in the Midwest, to an annual 354,000 units.

HEADLINE: Shifting the Burden of Funding Pensions 

BYLINE:  By MARY WILLIAMS WALSH

 BODY:
The savings accounts proposed by the Bush administration are meant to produce fundamental changes in the way Americans think about saving for retirement and to shift the primary responsibility from the business community to the individual.
 Many of the most popular savings vehicles now involve an immediate tax break. Consequently, Americans have been trained to focus on saving for retirement just once a year, at tax time, when they remember they can shrink the Treasury's bite by parking some money in, say, an individual retirement account. 
 The new accounts would replace such upfront breaks with the promise that all future withdrawals would be tax-free. The idea is to wean Americans off their fixation on tax deductions in the here and now, and train them to think instead about tax-free wealth in the future. 
While the accounts may not be enacted in their current form, their tax features shed light on the administration's broader economic goals. Unlike most existing tax-deferred savings accounts, devised by the financial services sector, these came from the White House and are consistent with its philosophy that capital should not be taxed at all. Glenn Hubbard, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, similarly favors scrapping the estate tax and doing away with taxes on dividends if corporations have already paid taxes on the money. And in his recent economic report to Congress, President Bush praised the potential advantages of a consumption-based tax over the income tax.
Taken to their logical extension, the administration's beliefs about taxes and saving for retirement could have far-reaching implications for such cherished features of middle-class life as the company pension and the Social Security system.
"We're looking at a global shift in the bearing of responsibility and risk from the business community to the individual," said J. Mark Iwry, the Treasury's benefits tax counsel during the Clinton administration. "It's not unlike the proposed shift of responsibility and risk to the individual through the privatization of Social Security." 
America's system of work-based pensions has grown up over the better part of a century, encouraged by tax breaks to companies that sponsor pension plans, he said. Policy makers have long believed that a strong system of employer-sponsored pensions would lighten the burden borne by Social Security and related government programs.
White House theorists suggest that if Americans have the chance to discover the pleasures of tax-free investment withdrawals, they will buy into its broader ideology of individual self-reliance.
But in the meantime, a wide range of critics have lined up against the savings proposals, saying the accounts would favor the rich and hamper the government's ability to collect taxes in the future. 
Even those inclined to favor administration ideas are withholding their support for this one. Republicans in Congress complain that they were inadequately briefed on the savings accounts, and large business interests see the plans as a distraction from other legislation they want more. The ouster in December of the president's chief economic adviser, Lawrence B. Lindsey, an ardent champion of the administration's theories on taxation and saving, adds further doubt about whether the administration will be able to put its theories into practice.
"I don't know of anybody still in the administration, at a level anywhere near as senior as Lindsey, who has the passionate, true-believer structure on these issues to be able to keep pushing them like a bulldozer that never stops," said Dallas Salisbury, president of the Employee Benefit Research Institute, a Washington group that is funded by businesses.
Mr. Salisbury said he saw the new savings plans as part of an ideological continuum that stretched back for decades, to when the tax-favored individual retirement account was created, and which will continue into the future.
"There's been a lot of talk about how it's radical, but at one level it's just an incremental step in a process that's been vigorously debated for decades," Mr. Salisbury said. "It's a shifting of the philosophy from make the contribution deductible and tax the benefit to have the contribution be after tax and don't tax the benefit."
Of the two proposed individual savings accounts, the Retirement Savings Account is the less radical, and perhaps therefore more likely to take root. It would offer no upfront tax break, but would let all withdrawals be free of federal income tax.
In addition, the Retirement Savings Account would multiply the amount of tax-advantaged money that households may salt away each year. A saver can now put up to $3,000 a year into an I.R.A. But he or she could put $7,500 annually into a Retirement Savings Account.
That enlarged tax advantage would multiply further in conjunction with the other Bush savings proposals. The administration also wants to create an all-purpose, tax-free saving plan -- the Lifetime Savings Account -- which could be used for any purpose, including retirement savings. And it proposes to raise the current contribution limits on existing work-based retirement savings plans, like the 401(k).
To pay for such tax breaks, White House economists have at least deliberated another idea in keeping with their broader economic vision: the elimination of the tax deduction that companies now get when they contribute to retirement plans.
Since 1942, companies have been able to deduct pension contributions from their taxes as long as they offer proportional benefits to both executives and rank-and-file workers. In effect, the tax treatment is a subsidy to companies that help provide for their workers in old age. Thousands of companies make use of the provision, which also applies to contributions for more recent retirement plans, such as the 401(k).
After six decades, these tax deductions are well established and add up to a lot of money. The government will forgo some $112.6 billion from workplace retirement-plan deductions this year, according to the Employee Benefit Research Institute.
The amount is expected to grow. Stock values have declined over the last three years, and many pension funds have shrunk to the point that companies must contribute large amounts, making possible still more tax deductions. The institute predicts that from 2003 to 2007, the taxes lost because of retirement contributions in the workplace will total $615 billion.
If the government could get that money back, it would be more than enough to cover, say, the $385 billion that the administration's plan to end taxes on some dividends is expected to cost in the first 10 years. But to get the money, the government would have to end the deduction for employee retirement-plan contributions.
Late last year, Mr. Salisbury said he began receiving phone calls from lobbyists asking whether he was aware that the administration was about to do that very thing.
"I called a bunch of people to see if this had legs," Mr. Salisbury said, noting that the idea had made the rounds in other administrations.
"No matter how I've ever managed to track it, my ultimate conclusion has been, 'Goodbye pension system,' " Mr. Salisbury said of the discussion. "People have proposed doing this in the past, but just technically, doing it would be excruciating."
Mr. Lindsey, who is now the president of the Lindsey Group, an economic consulting firm, said eliminating the deductions would make sense for a number of reasons. He cited the general trend toward taxing savings plans of all types at the beginning, with contributions, rather than at the end, on withdrawals. 
If this approach were applied to pensions, he said, it would protect retirees from the risk that a future administration might raise taxes, eating into their benefits.
Mr. Lindsey also spoke of the dizzying complexity of today's pension rules, the perverse incentives that they can give companies to game their pension numbers, and the competitive burdens that pensions place on American industries in a global economy. Using the tax code to subsidize problems like these is not good public policy, he said.
At the moment, he added, there are no plans to scrap pension deductibility, but America is moving in that direction gradually. 
"Everybody is evolving," Mr. Lindsey said. "I don't think we're ever going to do a sharp break."
William F. Sweetnam Jr., the Treasury's pension and benefits tax counsel, confirmed that he knew of no plans to repeal pension deductibility.
The only live plans to change the tax treatment of company retirement benefits involve something called the Roth 401(k), which is a different plan from the existing Roth I.R.A. This little-publicized savings plan will let employees contribute after-tax money and to receive withdrawals tax free after retirement. This tax treatment is identical to that of the Retirement Savings Accounts, but the Roth 401(k) has already been signed into law by President Bush. The accounts are scheduled to appear in 2006, but the administration wants to move the debut up to 2004. 
(Companies would then choose which tax treatment to offer with their 401(k) plans, or whether to offer retirement plans at all. The 401(k) plan would also get a new name, the Employer Retirement Savings Account.)
Critics of the savings proposals have called them a stepping stone to the privatization of Social Security. The administration expressly denied this, saying that the savings accounts are intended to increase savings, plain and simple, and that goal is separate from any changes in Social Security. 
"I see no reason not to take the administration at their word," Mr. Iwry said, adding that changing retirement-saving habits would be compatible with the administration's Social Security proposals, even if one was not meant to cause the other. "If you really believe in that overall vision, why wouldn't you try to do both?"
